Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minors. The course
introduces students to the mathematical techniques necessary for the study of economics at the
undergraduate level. Amongst other topics, the course will cover univariate and multivariate calculus,
optimization and linear algebra.

description:
Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Eesha Kumar [eesha.kumar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, we will approach the question of form from a few distinct directions. We will think about form as genre, and consider the affordances of the novel, ghazal, haiku, epic, essay, manifesto, etc. We will understand form as constraint, learning about poetic forms such as the sonnet, villanelle and sestina, and the experimental fictions of the Oulipo group. We will read formalist thinkers from different traditions (eg. Cleanth Brooks, Kenneth Burke, Viktor Shklovsky) to understand their views on technique and device. We will ponder the ways in which concepts (or conceits) might give shape to fiction (as in Goethe’s Elective Affinities). We will reflect on connections with structure and grammar in philosophy. We will learn from literature how to think about the forms of our life in community, with readings from Mark Fisher, Meredith Martin, and Caroline Levine. 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

'Forms of Literature' is the first ‘gateway’ course into the English major/minor at Ashoka—a gateway we enter to consider, together, some significant literary modes as they have emerged historically. The course will seek to understand what ‘form’ is, in literary studies and beyond. Over the course of the semester, we will study epic, tragedy (and drama more broadly), lyric poetry (and many subgenres shelter beneath that rubric!), the tale, the short story, the novel, graphic narrative, and film. Our focus on the making of these genres will allow us some freedom in the worlds we roam—from the classical to the contemporary, traversing many parts of the globe through different literary cultures.

In thinking through form historically, we will begin by assuming that literary genres articulate the material foundations we recognise in their social and historical contexts, and ask how they in turn affect those material foundations. We'll dip into certain theoretical accompaniments that consider form in literature and in the world. Along the way, we’ll think about the many ways in which human beings have considered their place in the world, about what it means to be, live, love, act, work, desire, write and create—questions that seem to reach out beyond the particular places and times in which they are asked, even as they tell us all the more about how those places and times were inhabited and imagined. 

 

Learning Outcomes

Course objectives:

  • To help students become conversant with the primary modes and genres of English literature (understood fluidly, expansively, and globally, in keeping with the Ashoka English major/minor);
  • To help students become more critical readers of literature, recognising that literary knowledge and production is linked to other forms of knowledge and their production;
  • To locate texts and their cultural significance—closely and in context, rather than deifying their canonical status
  • To offer students foundational experience in writing criticism.

Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Is there such a thing as Indian civilization? Is it one or many? How far back in time do we have to travel in order to discover it? Starting from the dawn of history and taking a long view of the past, how can we make sense of the seemingly endless detail, the bewildering variety and uneven textures, the striking continuities shot through by even more striking changes? Does civilization reveal itself in the everyday life rhythms of village folk, city dwellers or forest tribes? Is it represented in artefacts or ideas, in simple objects or grand monuments, in folk songs or classical literature? This course answers such questions by looking at Indian civilization through the coexistence of contradictions across time. We will see the coexistence of unequal societies with promises of salvation for all; of social prudery with a celebration of sexuality; of misogyny with the worship of goddesses; of religions teaching nonviolence with a politics marked by war and violence; of religious dialogue with religious conflict; and of an insularity despite centuries of lively interactions with the world. By exploring such contradictions, the course will show that the past is neither dead nor dull, and that we need to understand its pluralities and complexities in order to understand our present.

Learning Outcomes

Students will understand how to analyze and understand the complexities, pluralities and contradictions that mark Indian history and culture over the centuries.

description:
Introduction to Creative Writing [CW-1001] [CW-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Janice Erica Pariat [janice.pariat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course invites students to discover the power of storytelling in its many shapes — the spoken and the sung, short or long fiction, and poetry. Emphasis is placed on regular writing, exploration, and attentive listening and reading as ways to develop one’s craft and creative confidence.In fiction, students will experiment with the building blocks of narrative. Through weekly prompts, we will learn how stories emerge from image, memory, or a single line of dialogue, and how revision turns raw drafts into artful, intentional pieces. In poetry, we will explore the music and movement of language — how rhythm, sound, image, and line shape emotion and thought. Prompts will encourage writing from observation and imagination alike. Workshop sessions will offer a space to share work, listen closely, and respond generously. By semester’s end, students will have built a small portfolio of original writing and developed a sustainable practice of writing and reading as daily acts of attention and discovery. Students who wish to earn this minor or take further creative writing courses, must successfully complete this introductory course. There are no prerequisites for this course.

Learning Outcomes
  • Recognise and apply the fundamental elements of storytelling—including image, character, dialogue, and narrative structure—to create short pieces of fiction.
  • Compose original poems that demonstrate an understanding of rhythm, sound, imagery, and line, and how these shape meaning and emotion.
  • Generate new writing regularly through prompts that draw on observation, memory, imagination, and attentive engagement with the world.
  • Revise drafts effectively, using feedback and self-reflection to transform exploratory writing into intentional, polished pieces.
  • Offer and receive constructive critique by participating actively and respectfully in workshop discussions, demonstrating close listening and thoughtful response.
  • Build a small, cohesive portfolio of fiction and poetry that reflects growth in creative practice and a sustainable habit of reading and writing as daily acts of attention.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings:

Prose

  • Excerpt from The Reader by Bernard Schlink (translated by Carol Brown Janeway)
  • “The Stone Mattress” by Margaret Atwood
  • “The Magic Spell” by Jahnavi Barua
  • Excerpt from “Nutshell” by Ian McEwan
  • “The Child” by Ali Smith
  • “Temporary Matter” by Jhumpa Lahiri
  • “The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas” by Ursula le Guin
  • “Vast Hell” by Guillermo Martínez

Poetry

  •  “First Memory” by Louise Glück
  • “Premonition” by Jeet Thayil
  • “The Sea is History” by Derek Walcott
  • “Lint” by Vijay Nambisan
  • "Imaginary Conversation" by Linda Pastan
  • “The Red Wheelbarrow” by William Carlos Williams
  • “In a Station of a Metro” by Ezra Pound
  • “Oranges” by Gary Soto
  • "Oranges & the Ocean" by Ada Limon
  •  Sappho 34
  •  “Sunset” by Basho
  • “Wind” by Ted Hughes
  • “Ithaca” by Cavafy
  • “Archaeology” by Katha Pollitt
  • “The Weary Blues” by Langston Hughes
  • “Variation on the Word Sleep” by Margaret Atwood
  • “We Real Cool” by Gwendoline Brooks
  •  “The Lull” by Molly Peacock
  • “Ghazal 605” by Monica Mody
  • Brand New Ancients” by Kate Tempest

Podcasts

  • Everything is Alive; Episode 1 and 7

Short Films

  • Movie excerpts from The Beat
  • “Push to Enter” by Anthony Nicolau

description:
Econometrics [ECO-2400] [ECO-2400-1]

Faculty Name
Compulsory Econ [compulsory.econ@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This will be an introductory course in econometrics. It will build on the concepts of statistical inference with the aim of applying them to data. The course will have both a theoretical and an application-based part. The theory will involve understanding the method of least squares estimation and the application part will involve data visualization and analyses using STATA software.

Learning Outcomes

The crux of econometrics is to be able to test hypothesis about a population using a sample. We begin by building on our understanding of a population and a sample and the basics of hypothesis testing. The course then moves onto the methods of estimation to understand causal relationships between variables. These methods are not just restricted to economics but are also relevant to the study of political science, sociology and public policy in general. The emphasis will be on inferring causality throughout the course. By the end of this course, you should be able to understand and apply the econometric methods taught to test a relevant hypothesis of interest using data, interpret the results and draw appropriate conclusions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks and Articles

  • Jeffrey M. Wooldridge [JMW], Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition
  • Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K [CT]. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010
  • Mastering Metrics, Joshua Angrist (Optional)

The crux of econometrics is to be able to test hypothesis about a population using a sample. We begin by building on our understanding of a population and a sample and the basics of hypothesis testing. The course then moves onto the methods of estimation to understand causal relationships between variables. These methods are not just restricted to economics but are also relevant to the study of political science, sociology and public policy in general. The emphasis will be on inferring causality throughout the course. By the end of this course, you should be able to understand and apply the econometric methods taught to test a relevant hypothesis of interest using data, interpret the results and draw appropriate conclusions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks and Articles

  • Jeffrey M. Wooldridge [JMW], Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition
  • Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K [CT]. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010
  • Mastering Metrics, Joshua Angrist (Optional)

description:
Multivariable Calculus [MAT-1004] [MAT-1004-1]

Faculty Name
Rajendra Bhatia [rajendra.bhatia@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In diverse areas one comes across quantities that depend on several variables. For example, the temperature at a place and the price of some goods are such quantities. The objective of this course is to study the calculus of such functions. 

The course also gives an opportunity to understand better what has been learnt in the course Calculus 1000, and to prepare for the next level courses in Analysis.

Learning Outcomes

Understanding the calculus of several veariables. Undrestanding basic ideas of mathematical analysis. Developing the ability to solve problems and to write clear proofs.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The primary text is James Stewart, Calculus Chapters 12-16.

Also recommended is S. Lang, Calculus of Several Variables.

It is essential the the student is thoroughly familiar with the material covered in the course Calculus 1000. 

 

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: Regular attendance is essential for keeping up with the course. It is expected that you put in six hours per week of work in addition to the classes.

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-1]

Faculty Name
Chandan Singh Dalawat [chandan.dalawat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is meant for students who have had very little exposure to mathematics, and are unlikely to take other mathematics courses. 

 

It will provide a gentle introduction to some elementary mathematical ideas. Many of these ideas have had a profound impact on our society and culture. 

 

We will discuss elements of logic, inductive and deductive reasoning, sets and mappings, graphs and networks, number systems, plane geometry, modular arithmetic, linear and quadratic equations, exponential and logarithmic functions, and elements of probability.

 

The approach will be very concrete, with an emphasis on understanding as well as computation.

 

Notes of most lectures will be provided.   

Learning Outcomes

Student are expected to be able to distinguish between a proper mathematical argument and educated guesswork. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Mathematical Excursions, 

by Richard N. Aufmann, Joanne Lockwood, Richard D. Nation, and Daniel K. Clegg

description:
Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Overview:

The contemporary world is beset with growing environmental problems. The global focus on economic growth and development has led us onto an unsustainable path: growing scientific evidence now suggests that the Earth may not be able to cope with the demands imposed on it.  This has created an urgent need to critically examine complex environmental issues from a variety of perspectives. It is necessary to inculcate holistic thinking on environmental challenges and their purported solutions, that includes concerns of social and ecological sustainability.  

This course will discuss some of the most current concerns related to the environment, as well as societal responses to them, from a multidisciplinary perspective. Water scarcity, climate change, forest degradation, biological extinction, pollution and agrarian distress are some of the issues that will be studied. This course is intended to familiarise students with environmental problems  and engender a holistic perspective in understanding causes and possible solutions through the lenses of both science and equity. This course will encourage students to synthesize information across a variety of sources.

Practically the course will be taught using a combination of lectures, documentaries, slideshows, guest lectures and in-class discussions. Discussion on assigned readings will engender critical thinking and debate in class. Students will undertake group projects on current case studies (such as river pollution, tiger tourism etc.). Assessments will be based on in-class tests, essays, group projects and class participation.

Course Topics (Each module=1.5 lecture-hour)

Module 1: Introduction to Contemporary Environmental Challenges

The students will be introduced to contemporary environmental issues such as climate change, biological extinction, pollution, food security, waste, water scarcity and forest degradation. The concepts of social equity and ecological and economic sustainability   will be introduced as ways of understanding environmental challenges globally and in developing societies such as India. 

Module 2,3: Population Growth and Sustainability

This module focuses on the relationship between population and the environment. Issues of population growth, stability, consumption patterns, demographic transition, coupled with human development challenges, social security, disease and scarcity will be addressed.

Module 4: Environment as a Commons

This module explores the understanding of  'environment' as a common. If indeed it is difficult to set up exclusive access to the environment then what kind of challenges may one anticipate in sharing the environment as a common? The module expects the students to familiarize themselves with Hardin's argument wherein commons are understood to fail, thus qualifying as a tragedy. A  counter to this argument is presented through Elinor Ostrom's work which argues for the possibility of successfully governing commons.

Module 5: Resource Scarcity at the Margins

This module explores the relationship between poverty, and environmental degradation, asking the larger questions of who suffers the most from environmental problems and disasters, and who pays the price. Do the interests of biodiversity and human well-being necessarily coincide? This module delves into the forms of resource and environmental governance that exist. We revisit the critical role of commons and the varying implications of environmental governance for social-ecological sustainability of ecosystem-dependent livelihoods at the margins.

Module 6,7: Climate Change I : Science and Impacts

In this module, the students will be introduced to the scientific debates on climate change and the symptoms and manifestations of global warming, which will be interpreted in context of climate history. The students will explore the impacts of climate change on agriculture, health, livelihoods and biodiversity, based on analysis of three short movies on climate-induced displacement.

Module 8,9: Climate Change II: Mitigation and Adaptation

In this module, we discuss climate change mitigation and adaptation, particularly in the context of current international agreements and initiatives. We focus on the apparent inequities between the developed and developing world, and how these may affect the mitigative pathways being adopted, such as recent ‘net-zero’ commitments. There will be a focus on climate justice and carbon markets particularly in the context of the latest international negotiations on climate change at COP-26 held at Glasgow, 2020.

Module 10,11: Biodiversity Loss

The students will be introduced to the causes and consequences of species extinction and ecosystem degradation from the scientific and socio-political perspectives.  Varied paradigms of biological conservation in terms of  their socio-economic, political and biological implications and impacts.

Module 12: Water Scarcity and Conservation

Water, the source of all life, has become one of the most contentious issues on the planet. Growing scarcity and pollution of water, as well as the increasing unpredictability of floods and droughts, has necessitated a deeper look at the traditional strategies for water conservation, and how they can be revived.

Module 13: Water Bodies and their Governance

Using Indian rivers and lakes as examples, we explore the complex interplay amongst religious traditions, local needs, governmental authority, policy-making and ecological factors in perpetuating water pollution and mismanagement, one of the major environmental issues we are living with. Break-out sessions, created around different stake-holder groups, will debate the problem of river pollution.

Module 14,15: Agrarian Crisis and Livelihoods

The agrarian crisis in India has serious implications for rural livelihoods and food security. In this module, we explore the ecological and political perspectives on the abandonment of agriculture and declining productivity in India.

Module 16,17: Human-Wildlife Conflicts

With growing degradation and fragmentation of natural habitats, and expansion of human settlements, conflict situations with wildlife are occurring more frequently, resulting in grievous human injury and losses. In this module, we explore the causes and consequences of such conflict from different perspectives- behavioural, economic and social. Students will be encouraged to apply the concept of environmental commons to conflict management.

Module 18: Development as Disaster ?

A large number of environmental problems are created by large-scale industrial development and infrastructure that are undertaken without sufficient precautions. Thus it is necessary to explore the repercussions of the adopted development models for ecology and local livelihoods. We then explore the development processes and amelioratory laws and policies for environmental damage caused by infrastructural development in India.

Module 19,20: Governmental Responses: Environment Laws, Policies and Regulation

This module explores the historical context of environmental law-making and implementation in India. The role of government in environmental conservation will be analysed by the students, through discussion on key environmental laws in India such as the Forest Conservation Act, Forest Rights Act, the Wildlife Protection Act and the Environmental Protection Act. Regulatory laws such as Environmental Impact Assessment and Coastal Zone Regulation will also be covered. The aim will be to explore not only the contours and details of these laws but also their implementation, as well as their impacts on society and biodiversity.

Module 21: Role of Local Government

Local Governance is of utmost importance for environmental sustainability and conservation and rural well-being. Students will be introduced to local governmental mechanisms and institutions in India. The case study of Western Himalaya will be discussed based on the role of forest councils in environmental conservation.

Module 22,23 People’s response: Environmental Movements

Environmental movements in India are significant for their grassroots base and role in highlighting (and resolving) growing resource conflicts, particularly in view of the visible contestation among rural communities, corporate sector and governments. Students will compare and contrast various environmental movements in India from the points of view of sustainability. Three landmark environmental movements will be discussed in class: Chipko Andolan, Ralegaon Siddhi and Narmada Bachao Andolan.

Module 24: Ecosystem Services and their Valuation

Monetization of ecosystem services has emerged as one of the possible solutions for safe-guarding nature. We will discuss the concept of ecosystem services, their valuation and the potential of such understanding for conservation. The advantages and pitfalls of using this approach will be debated. The concept of green GDP will be introduced as a way to stem the degradation of ecosystem services globally.

Module 25, 26: Traditional Knowledge and the Environment

Traditional knowledge has historically been the crucible for understanding and conservation of nature, which empowers indigenous communities and economies. It is important to explore the concept, as well as its applicability and usefulness for human well-being in modern times. Convention on Biological Diversity and Biological Diversity Act will be discussed in the context of safe-guarding indigenous people’s intellectual Property Rights.

Indicative Readings (full list to be updated):

Shahabuddin, G. and K. Sivaramakrishnan (Eds.) 2019. Nature in the New Economy, People, Wildlife and the Law in India. Orient Blackswan, Delhi.

Srinivasan, U. and N. Velho (Eds.) 2018. Conservation from the Margins. Orient Blackswan, Delhi.

Kothari, A. 2021. The Net-Zero Greenwash. Wall Street Journal, July 13, 2021. https://wsimag.com/economy-and-politics/66356-the-net-zero-greenwash

Nepstad,D. 2021. The Net-Zero Bridge to Saving the Amazon. Mongabay.com, November 3, 2021. https://news.mongabay.com/2021/11/the-net-zero-bridge-to-saving-the-amazon-commentary/

Gadgil, M. 2023. A Walk up the Hill: Living with People and Nature. Penguin Random House, India.

Nagendra, H., & Mundoli, S. 2023. Shades of Blue: Connecting the Drops in India’s Cities. Penguin Random House, India.

Sharma, M. 2012. Green and Saffron, Hindu Nationalism and Indian Environmental Politics. Permanent Black & Ashoka University.

Guha, R. 2006. How Much Should a Person Consume? Thinking through the Environment. Chapter 2 (Pgs 67-90); Chapter 7 (Pgs 224-243); Permanent Black/Black Kite, Delhi

Plotkin, M.E. 1993. Tales of a Shaman’s Apprentice. Chapter 1: Through the Emerald Door (Pgs 1-18); Chapter 3: Among the Maroons (Pgs 53-80).Penguin, USA

Nabhan, G.P. 1997. Cultures of Habitat, On Nature, Culture and Story. Chapter 4 (Pgs. 209-223). Counterpoint, Washington DC, USA.

Ghosh, A. 2019. Disastrous delta: Daily struggles against nature in the Sunderbans. Pp. 29-36 In. Ghosh, A. (Ed.). The Tides of Life: Surviving Between the Margins. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts, India.

Mahmud, S. 2019. Adapting to change in the Sunderbans ecosystems: Lay people’s perceptions. Pp. 129-141 In. Ghosh, A. (Ed.). The Tides of Life: Surviving Between the Margins. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts, India

Baviskar A. 2020. Uncivil City: Ecology, Equity and the Commons in Delhi. Sage Publications and Yoda Press, India.

Richard, A. 2022. The Sloth Lemur’s Song, Madagascar from the Deep Past to the Uncertain Present. William Collins.

Rangarajan, M. 2015. Nature and Nation: Essays on Environmental History. Chapter 5: Striving for a Balance: Nature, Power, Science and India’s Indira Gandhi (Pgs 151-189). Permanent Black & Ashoka University.

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will create an awareness of, and sensitivity to the complexities of contemporary environmental challenges;
  • Students will learn to analyse environmental issues from a multidisciplinary perspective;
  • Students will learn to think and write analytically about complex issues
  • They will be taught to synthesize knowledge from different sources including scholarly papers, visual media and traditional knowledge.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-3]

Faculty Name
Asmita Kabra [asmita.kabra@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Saving the Planet? Ten Questions on Environment and Society

The course aims to introduce students to a complex, interdisciplinary understanding of environmental issues and challenges, going beyond simplistic discourses of crisis. The pedagogic design is built around ten questions, framed in very simple terms but designed to crack open disciplinary silos to build a multivalent understanding of linked socioecological systems. It exposes students to a diversity of environmental issues, challenges, processes, perspectives, and actors. The objective is to enable students to gain a more nuanced and historicized understanding of the politics of environmental policy and practice.

Weekly Teaching Plan
Week Module Key ideas
Curtain-raiser Welcome to the Anthropocene!

Revisiting SDGs; The poly-crisis; Wicked problems; The Great Acceleration
Question 1

Are there too many people at this party?

 Population and the environment; food security; food sovereignty; Green Revolution
Question 2 How did we get here?

Colonialism; Capitalism; Development; Dependency
Question 3

How has the world changed since World War II?

 Globalization; fictitious commodities; Capitalism and its crises
Question 4

Why is everyone angry?

 Counter-movements; Resistance; Precariat
Question 5

What is everyone doing about the polycrisis?

 State; civil society; gigantism; knowledge and expertise; human scale development
Question 6

Can markets solve the polycrisis?

 Ecosystem valuation; Nature-based solutions; Carbon markets; Commodification
Question 7

Are mainstream solutions working (for everyone)?

 Green grabbing; Environmentalism of the poor; Environmental justice
Question 8

What can we do in villages?

 Community-based natural resource management; Soil and water conservation; Micro-credit
Question 9

What can we do in cities?

 Green buildings; Just transition; Decentralised renewable energy; Degrowth
Question 10 What can I do? Climate anxiety; Reframing the questions; Resilience dividend
Prologue

Where do we find hope in dark times?
 

 Pedagogies of hope; Radical ecological Democracy

 

Learning Outcomes
  • To destabilise simplistic binaries of rural-urban, North-South, environment-development, local-global etc.
  • To foster meaningful dialogue among diverse disciplinary and ideological perspectives
  • To nudge students to think of their own role as embedded actors operating within structural constraints, but with agency to bring about change
  • To understand socio-ecological systems as complex, contingent, and messy
  • To generate critical hope and action pathways
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prior requirements.

Part I of the course walks students through the history of environment-development linkages, showing how these linkages have changed over time and are connected specifically to global geo-politics of the 20th and 21st centuries. Part II focuses on extant environmental solutions, mainstream as well as radical, again teasing out their ontological and epistemological foundations. The course draws on theoretical insights from development studies, political economy, environmental and ecological economics, and cultural and political ecology.  
The course will use videos, podcasts, blogs, and other online resource material, in addition to the book secions, articles, and other readings listed below. We will also try to invite experts and practitioners to the class to discuss workable solutions for the 21st century. 

Reading List

  • Alier, J.M. (2009), Socially Sustainable Economic De-growth. Development and Change, 40: 1099-1119. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-7660.2009.01618.x
  • Chua, Liana, and Hannah Fair. (2019) 2023. “Anthropocene”. In The Open Encyclopedia of Anthropology, edited by Felix Stein. Facsimile of the first edition in The Cambridge Encyclopedia of Anthropology. Online: http://doi.org/10.29164/19anthro
  • Gadgil, M. and R. Guha (1994). “Ecological conflicts and the environmental movement in India”. Development and Change, Vol. 25, 101-136
  • Harry, Steven J., Tomas Maltby, and Kacper Szulecki. 2024. “Contesting Just Transitions: Climate Delay and the Contradictions of Labour Environmentalism.” Political Geography 112:103114. doi:10.1016/j.polgeo.2024.103114.
  • Kimmerer, Robin Wall (2013). Braiding Sweetgrass: Indigenous Wisdom, Scientific Knowledge, and the Teachings of Plants. Minneapolis, MN: Milkweed Editions (select excerpts)
  • Kumar, Richa. 2019. “India’s Green Revolution and Beyond | Economic and Political Weekly.” Economic & Political Weekly 54(34):41–48.
  • Li, Tania Murray. “After Development: Surplus Population and the Politics of Entitlement.” Development and Change 48, no. 6 (2017): 1247–1261. https://doi.org/10.1111/dech.12344.
  • Martinez-Alier, Joan, Leah Temper, Daniela Del Bene, and Arnim Scheidel. 2016. “Is There a Global Environmental Justice Movement?” The Journal of Peasant Studies 43(3):731–55. doi:10.1080/03066150.2016.1141198.
  • McMichael, Philip. 2010. “Introduction, Food, Energy, Environment: Crisis of the Modern World-System.” Review (Fernand Braudel Center) 33(2/3):95–102.
  • Rist, Gilbert (2007) Development as a buzzword, Development in Practice,17:4-5, 485-491, DOI: 10.1080/09614520701469328
  • Robbins, Paul, John Hintz, and Sarah A. Moore. 2014. Environment and Society: A Critical Introduction, 2nd Edition. 2nd edition. Hoboken, New Jersey: Wiley-Blackwell. Chapter 7.
  • Schumacher, E. F. 1993. Small Is Beautiful: A Study of Economics as If People Mattered. Latest edition. London: Vintage. Chapter 1.
  • Scott, James C. Seeing like a State: How Certain Schemes to Improve the Human Condition Have Failed. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1999. Introduction.
  • Solnit, Rebecca. 2016. Hope in the Dark: Untold Histories, Wild Possibilities. Haymarket Books (select excerpts)
  • Standing, Guy. 2015. “The Precariat and Class Struggle.” RCCS Annual Review. A Selection from the Portuguese Journal Revista Crítica de Ciências Sociais (7). doi:10.4000/rccsar.585.
  • Weis, Tony. 2011. “The Ecological Hoofprint and the Population Bomb of Reverse Protein Factories on JSTOR.” Review (Fernand Brodel Centre) 33(2/3):131–52.
  • Zafra-Calvo, Noelia et al. 2020. “Plural Valuation of Nature for Equity and Sustainability: Insights from the Global South.” Global Environmental Change 63:102115. doi:10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2020.102115.
Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

The course will consist of twelve modules, each covering a week with two lectures of 1.5 hours each. Students are expected to prepare in advance by reading short pieces and/or watching films or studying online resources. Classroom time will be devoted to lectures, discussion, and in-class activities, with follow-up readings assigned to dig deeper into the ideas thrown up during class.We will also try to invite experts and practitioners to the class to discuss workable solutions for the 21st century.

Econometrics 1 [ECO-5401] [ECO-5401-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Sardana [kavita.sardana@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Description

This course provides a rigorous introduction to econometric methods built around linear regression models. By the end of the semester, students will be comfortable with specifying econometric models, understanding and testing the assumptions underlying them, and critically evaluating empirical results.
The course combines theoretical lectures with hands-on computer sessions using STATA. These practical sessions introduce students to real-world empirical problems and reinforce their understanding of econometric concepts.

The curriculum covers:

The classical linear regression model

Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) estimation and hypothesis testing

Violations of classical assumptions

Simultaneity, endogeneity, and instrumental variables

Single-equation and system-equation estimation techniques

Introduction to empirical project design and execution

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Understand the assumptions of the Classical Linear Model (CLM), recognize violations, and apply appropriate econometric solutions.

Formulate and analyze research problems involving continuous random variables using econometric modelling techniques.

Implement econometric methods in statistical software and interpret empirical results.

Design, conduct, and present an empirical research project.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Textbooks:

Jeffrey M. Wooldridge (JMW) – Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition.

Jeffrey M. Wooldridge – Econometric Analysis of Cross Section and Panel Data, 2nd edition, MIT Press, 2010.

description:
Introduction to Economics [ECO-1001] [ECO-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Compulsory Econ [compulsory.econ@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is intended to introduce you to the way economists think, and provide you with some

of the tools, language, and rigour to assess and understand the world around us.

Learning Outcomes

You will be introduced to certain aspects of economic history, principles of decision making in a world marked by scarcity, strategic interaction, the behaviour of firms and consumers, and the concept of a market. We will also go on to cover other topics, including economic fluctuations and their impact on unemployment, globalization and trade, inequality and poverty. By the end of the course, you should be able to critically think from an economist’s point of view about a number of topics and policy questions facing economies around the world.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The Economy, by The CORE project/team: Publicly available at https://www.core-econ.org/project/core-the-economy/

Economics, by Acemoglu, Laibson & List (2016), Global Edition, Pearson Education; Available in the Ashoka Library

courseTitle: Physics Lab 1:Introduction to Physics through Experiments
description:
Physics Lab 1:Introduction to Physics through Experiments [PHY-1010] [PHY-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a gateway course introducing students to experimental physics. It is mandatory for those intending to major or minor in physics, though also of more general interest. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the way in which physicists observe the world around them — what they notice, how they design experiments and make observations, how they analyse the information collected, how they match them against theory-based expectations, and how in general they draw inferences. Anyone with an interest in experimental science is welcome — there are no pre-requisites.

Learning Outcomes

Designing (and appreciating the design of) experiments.

Understanding instruments, appreciating their design, and using them appropriately.

Acquiring data correctly, using appropriate instruments.

Understanding the limits of your measuring instruments, which are related to their least count and, in the case of time measurement, also to your reaction time. This leads to what is usually called error (but perhaps better called precision).

Recording data appropriately in your logbook, with the correct units.

Graphing your data, and fitting lines and curves to them if necessary.

Doing the necessary calculations, with sensitivity to dimensions and units.

Drawing conclusions, and stating them correctly. This includes understanding how measurement errors propagate into your conclusions.

Writing lab reports.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
Attendance
Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.

Additional Comments:

At least 75% attendance is mandatory to get a pass in this course. Other than the Tue, Thurs lab sessions, no arrangements can be made for extra/makeup lab time.

description:
English Graduate Proseminar: Thesis Writing [ENG-4002] [ENG-4002-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The proseminar is designed to help thesis writers advance through the stages of planning and composing the thesis while also providing a collegial environment in which writers can analyze and improve their writing. Writing, rewriting, and re-rewriting is a process that we will undertake together. To that end, the spring proseminar will be structured around a series of workshops that will move from targeting specific aspects of writing, such as introductions, argumentation, conclusions, etc. to the drafts as a whole. The class will culminate in the submission of the thesis itself, as well as a public research presentation at the end of the semester.

Learning Outcomes

Microeconomics 2 [ECO-5102] [ECO-5102-1]

Faculty Name
Ratul Lahkar [ratul.lahkar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a course on game theory and applications. We will study the four fundamental types of games. They are (1) static games of complete information, (2) dynamic games of incomplete information, (3) static games of incomplete information and (4) dynamic games of incomplete information. In each of these topics, we will study the fundamental game theoretic solutions and important economic applications.

Learning Outcomes

1. Static games of complete information: Dominant strategies, rationalizability, Nash equilibrium and applications like oligopoly and externalities. 

2. Dynamic games of complete information: Backward induction, subgame perfection and applications like limit pricing, bargaining and repeated games. 

3. Static games of incomplete information: Bayesian Nash equilibrium and applications like auctions and mechanism design.

4. Dynamic games of incomplete information: Perfect Bayesian equilibrium and applications like adverse selection and moral hazard.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. "Microeconomic Theory" by Mas-Colell, Whinston and Green,

2. "Game Theory-An Introduction" by Steven Tadelis.

Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.

prerequisites.RequiredCourses: Microeconomics 1 [ECO-5101]

description:
Macroeconomics 2 [ECO-5202] [ECO-5202-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a compulsory Economics course offered by the Department of Economics at Ashoka University for all MA Economics and PhD students. This is the second course in the macroeconomics sequence for first-year MA and PhD students. Having been exposed to ideas and models of macroeconomic growth in Macroeconomics I, this course introduces students to modern macroeconomic theories of Real Business Cycles and New Keynesian Economics. Moreover, the course will focus on the micro-founding behavior of economic agents that is absent in introductory macroeconomics by discussing theories on consumption and saving. Finally, the course will cover models on search and matching, a benchmark of modern macro labor theory.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course consists of both required course materials, and some suggested readings. The recommended textbooks for this course are the following:

Romer, D., Advanced Macroeconomics (4th Edition or later)

Gali, J., Monetary Policy, Inflation, and the Business Cycle - An Introduction to the New Keynesian Framework, Princeton University Press

Ljungqvist, Lars, and Thomas J. Sargent, Recursive macroeconomic theory, MIT Press, 2018.

Students are not required to buy these textbooks. PDF versions are easily available online and should be accessed for reference. You are encouraged to ask the library and consult additional resources.

Attendance
Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: There is no attendance policy. However, students are expected to attend and participate in lectures regularly.

Mathematical Physics 2 [PHY-2110] [PHY-2110-1]

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This mathematical physics course is an introduction to differential equations with physical applications, especially those important in undergraduate physics. 

Part 1

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs): Overview and importance. Rate-of-change problems, e.g. radioactive decay, and other simple systems, e.g. logistic curve, population growth, resource depletion and harvesting. First-order linear ODEs. Higher-order linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Integrating factors. Homogeneous and inhomogeneous equations. Green’s functions. Dynamics in the phase plane, systems of coupled first-order linear ODEs. 

Nonlinear ODEs and dynamical systems: phase portraits, flows and vector fields, phase plane analysis, linearisation about fixed points, stability analysis, limit cycles and bifurcations. Topological index of a closed curve and index theorems. Lotka-Volterra model; non-linear oscillators, brief discussion of Poincare-Bendixson theorem, and basic ideas of chaotic dynamical systems.

Part 2

Second-order ODEs: Power series solutions, some special functions, e.g. Legendre, Bessel, and Hermite polynomials. Fourier Series and Fourier integrals with a few physical applications. 

Partial differential equations (PDEs): Linear first- and second-order PDEs.  Separation of variables: illustration through Laplace’s equation, wave equation, diffusion equation. Green’s functions, simple examples. 

Learning Outcomes

A familiarity with linear differential equations and analytical ways of solving them; Also an acquaintance with basic geometric and qualitative ways of understanding nonlinear systems (linearisation, stability, fixed points, flows, phase portraits, etc).

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Multivariable calculus and partial differentiation, besides the differential and integral calculus covered at the senior-secondary-school level. Some familiarity with basic linear algebra: eigenvalues and eigenvectors. (Mathematical Physics 1 or equivalent.)

Books

G F Simmons, Differential Equations with Applications and Historical Notes, 2nd edition (McGraw Hill)

S H Strogatz, Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos, 2nd edition (CRC press) 

Other books useful for reference and supplementary reading are:

C H Edwards and D E Penney, Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems: Computing and Modeling, Global Edition (Pearson)

M W Hirsch, S Smale, and R L Devaney, Differential equations, Dynamical systems and an Introduction to Chaos, 3rd edition (Academic Press)

K T Alligood, T D Sauer, and J A Yorke, Chaos: An Introduction to Dynamical Systems (Springer)

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Students are expected to attend at least 80% of the lectures and discussion sessions.

description:
Macroeconomic Theory II [ECO-2202] [ECO-2202-1]

Faculty Name
Compulsory Econ [compulsory.econ@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors

The process of economic growth and differences in patterns of growth within and across economies are some of the most interesting areas in economics. This course provides an introduction to the study of economic growth. The first two units of the course will be a theoretical exploration on the different sources of growth – population growth, technological change, accumulation of physical and human capital, geography, government and structural change. The analysis of these economic models will set the stage for the last unit, where we will look at empirical studies on current patterns of growth. Students must be mathematically comfortable with concepts of functions, derivatives, integrals, and ordinary differential equations. Some basic knowledge of regression analysis is also required.

Learning Outcomes
  • Students should understand growth concepts like technological progress, capital accumulation, source of growth, and endogenous growth, to name a few
  • Students should be well aware of the growth experiences of various countries or regions in the past few decades
  • Students must be well-read on stylised facts on economic growth
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Introduction to Economic Growth, by Charles I. Jones and Dietrich Vollrath. Third Edition
  • Economic Growth, by David N Weil. Third Edition

Students should have a hard or soft copy of the textbooks.

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: As per the university policy. There may be some changes based on the enrollment numbers; details will be announced in the first week of classes.
Grading
Grading Components
Grading Rubric

There is a weekly discussion section where you can ask doubts or go over practice problems on topics taught in the class. The time slot for the discussion section is to be decided. Attendance is strongly encouraged. We hope that the DS will expose you to more interesting and involved problems in the subject.

prerequisites.RequiredCourses: Macroeconomic Theory I [ECO-2201] , Intermediate Macroeconomics [ECO-201]

description:
Microeconomic Theory II [ECO-2102] [ECO-2102-1]

Faculty Name
Compulsory Econ [compulsory.econ@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is the second part of the compulsory microeconomic theory sequence for Economics majors. It introduces students to strategic reasoning and its implications for outcomes in markets and in a wide range of economic, social, and political institutions. The formal analytical framework that economists use to study strategic interaction is game theory, and the course equips students with a solid understanding of the foundations of non-cooperative game theory, focusing on its two central building blocks: normal-form and extensive-form games.

Students will study static and dynamic games under both complete and incomplete information. The course introduces and applies the key solution concepts of Nash equilibrium, Subgame-Perfect Nash equilibrium, Bayes-Nash equilibrium, and Perfect Bayesian equilibrium to analyze strategic behavior in these environments.

The course also examines several sources of market failure, including externalities and public goods, and explores topics in industrial organization by analyzing the strategic considerations that characterize oligopolistic markets. Issues arising from the presence of asymmetric information in markets are covered in depth, with particular attention to adverse selection and moral hazard. The course concludes by studying “second-best” solutions, such as signaling, for mitigating some of the welfare losses associated with asymmetric information.

Learning Outcomes

Set of Topics covered

We divide the list of topics into tools, environments, and substantive economic questions. This organization highlights how the course integrates (i) the development of formal modeling structures, (ii) their mapping into economic environments, and (iii) their application to a wide range of important economic and socio-political questions.

A.   Building blocks of non-cooperative game theory

1.   Normal form games

2.   Extensive form games

These two basic building blocks of non-cooperative game theory will be used to develop other classes of important games, amongst them Bayesian games, repeated games, and signaling games.

B.   Solution concepts

1. Dominance solvability and the iterated elimination of strictly dominated strategies

2.   Nash equilibrium

3.   Backward induction and subgame perfect Nash equilibrium

4.   Bayes Nash equilibrium

5.   Perfect Bayesian equilibrium

 

C.   Strategic Environments

The following four standard classifications of strategic environments will be studied using the building blocks of the normal and extensive form and the solution concepts mentioned above:

1.   Static environments of complete information

2.   Dynamic environments of complete information

3.   Static environments of incomplete information

4.   Dynamic environments of incomplete information

 

D.  Substantive economic questions

The tools developed in the course shall allow us to analyze strategic considerations in the following important economic topics:

1.   Externalities and public goods

2. Industrial organization and oligopolistic market structures (Cournot, Bertrand, and Stackelberg oligopolies)

3.   Adverse selection with Akerlof’s “market for lemons” model as the leading example

4.  Signaling with Spence’s job market signaling model as the leading example

5.   Moral hazard and an introduction to the principal-agent problem

6. The above themes illustrate how strategic considerations can lead to decentralized market arrangements producing inefficient outcomes—an important economic insight that recurs throughout the course.

 

In addition, instructors may cover topics such as auctions and auction design, bargaining, and voting, as further illustrations of the scope and power of game-theoretic reasoning.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The following textbooks are used in the course:

Strategy: An Introduction to Game Theory (Third edition) by Joel Watson (WW Norton and Company)

Game Theory and Behavior by Jeffrey Carpenter and Andrea Robbett (MIT Press)

Copies of these books are available in the library. 

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.

Faculty Name
Compulsory Econ [compulsory.econ@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is the second part of the compulsory microeconomic theory sequence for Economics majors. It introduces students to strategic reasoning and its implications for outcomes in markets and in a wide range of economic, social, and political institutions. The formal analytical framework that economists use to study strategic interaction is game theory, and the course equips students with a solid understanding of the foundations of non-cooperative game theory, focusing on its two central building blocks: normal-form and extensive-form games.

Students will study static and dynamic games under both complete and incomplete information. The course introduces and applies the key solution concepts of Nash equilibrium, Subgame-Perfect Nash equilibrium, Bayes-Nash equilibrium, and Perfect Bayesian equilibrium to analyze strategic behavior in these environments.

The course also examines several sources of market failure, including externalities and public goods, and explores topics in industrial organization by analyzing the strategic considerations that characterize oligopolistic markets. Issues arising from the presence of asymmetric information in markets are covered in depth, with particular attention to adverse selection and moral hazard. The course concludes by studying “second-best” solutions, such as signaling, for mitigating some of the welfare losses associated with asymmetric information.

Learning Outcomes

Set of Topics covered

We divide the list of topics into tools, environments, and substantive economic questions. This organization highlights how the course integrates (i) the development of formal modeling structures, (ii) their mapping into economic environments, and (iii) their application to a wide range of important economic and socio-political questions.

A.   Building blocks of non-cooperative game theory

1.   Normal form games

2.   Extensive form games

These two basic building blocks of non-cooperative game theory will be used to develop other classes of important games, amongst them Bayesian games, repeated games, and signaling games.

B.   Solution concepts

1. Dominance solvability and the iterated elimination of strictly dominated strategies

2.   Nash equilibrium

3.   Backward induction and subgame perfect Nash equilibrium

4.   Bayes Nash equilibrium

5.   Perfect Bayesian equilibrium

 

C.   Strategic Environments

The following four standard classifications of strategic environments will be studied using the building blocks of the normal and extensive form and the solution concepts mentioned above:

1.   Static environments of complete information

2.   Dynamic environments of complete information

3.   Static environments of incomplete information

4.   Dynamic environments of incomplete information

 

D.  Substantive economic questions

The tools developed in the course shall allow us to analyze strategic considerations in the following important economic topics:

1.   Externalities and public goods

2. Industrial organization and oligopolistic market structures (Cournot, Bertrand, and Stackelberg oligopolies)

3.   Adverse selection with Akerlof’s “market for lemons” model as the leading example

4.  Signaling with Spence’s job market signaling model as the leading example

5.   Moral hazard and an introduction to the principal-agent problem

6. The above themes illustrate how strategic considerations can lead to decentralized market arrangements producing inefficient outcomes—an important economic insight that recurs throughout the course.

 

In addition, instructors may cover topics such as auctions and auction design, bargaining, and voting, as further illustrations of the scope and power of game-theoretic reasoning.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The following textbooks are used in the course:

Strategy: An Introduction to Game Theory (Third edition) by Joel Watson (WW Norton and Company)

Game Theory and Behavior by Jeffrey Carpenter and Andrea Robbett (MIT Press)

Copies of these books are available in the library. 

Attendance

3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.

courseTitle: History of India III (From c. 1000 CE to 1764 CE)
description:
History of India III (From c. 1000 CE to 1764 CE) [HIS-2003] [HIS-2003-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course unravels the profound changes that South Asia went through in the first three quarters of the second millennium CE. We will begin our journey in the early-eleventh century with the maritime invasions of Southeast Asia by the Chola navy of South India and the invasion of North India by Turko-Afghan horse-warriors. We will end with the fragmentation of the Mughal Empire and the rise of regional states in the eighteenth century. Within this time-frame, we will explore the rise and fall of sultanates and kingdoms, the dynamics of commercial production and mercantile traffic, the workings of kingly power, the techniques of military engagements, and the nature of social hierarchies and oppression. We will also closely study the relationships between gender and politics, religion and society, language and power, art and statecraft, language and culture. We will look at sufis and merchants, rulers and slaves, princesses and labourers, horses and elephants. In the process, we will uncover the diversity, dynamism, and connections South Asia embodied during this period.

NOTE: There are no pre-requisites for this course. The four History of India courses can be taken in any order.

Learning Outcomes

This course will impart in students a sound understanding of the history of medieval and early modern South Asia.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Class Participation - 20%
  • Mid-Term Presentation - 30%
  • End-Semester Exam - 50%

Introduction to Philosophy [PHI-1000] [PHI-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Introduction to Philosophy (PHIL 1000/ Spring 2026)

Starting with the working definition of Philosophy as method-conscious, self-reflexive, argumentative thinking about basic concepts (such as the concepts of being, knowing, thinking, understanding, happiness, freedom, justice and equality) by the use of which humans live, know, think and strive for freedom this course would aim at training people to think (a) clearly and (b) self-critically through exposure to a few ancient and modern philosophers of East and West. 

Close reading of Bertrand Russell’s classic “The Problems of Philosophy and P.F. Strawson’s “Analysis and Metaphysics” would provide the basis for practicing philosophy as conceptual analysis, focusing on the concepts of Appearance, Reality, Existence, Truth, Time (and the Future), Consciousness, Knowledge, the Self, Ownership, Justice, Beauty, Freedom and finally Death and the Meaning of Life. 

One relatively new question to be explored in the course will be: “What makes a philosophical question philosophical and a question?”

Buddhist Philosophy [PHI-3360] [PHI-3360-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Buddhist Philosophy (course number: Phil 3360) Spring 2026

Since its inception more than two and a half millennia ago, Buddhism has been the most globally influential and pluralistic tradition of philosophical thinking (about thinking and ethical living). It is a “living philosophy” in the 21st century all over the world beyond practicing Buddhists, given the therapeutic popularity of mindfulness meditation. 

This reading-and-writing-intensive introduction would start with the Buddhist metaphysics of causation as “dependent origination”, arguments for universal impermanence (momentariness), the doctrine of no-self, and a nominalism which rejects universal essences. Next, the (Sautrntika-Yogcra-) Buddhist epistemology will be shown to combine elements of empiricism and rationalism. The empiricist element casts doubt on conceptual thinking, by paying attention to the inner stream of particular fleeting sensations, qualia and affects, rejecting any appeal to testimony or the word of scriptural authority. The rationalist element tightens up the logic of a-priori inferences, using rigorous analytical reasoning to disprove God, substance, objective external world and universals and enduring objects and persons. The course would end with showing how such an epistemology and metaphysics entail and are entailed by the Buddhist atheistic ethics of non-attachment, unselfishness and caring compassion for all suffering fellow-creatures.

The plan is to get into the intricacies of the arguments by which Buddhist schools of atomistic scientific realism, subjective idealism, and emptiness (two truths), developed a vibrant space for internal debates. Reading a text (Dispelling of Disputes) by Nagarjuna (in the latest philosophical English translation), and Mark Siderits’ Buddhism as Philosophy, we shall try to explore the relation between the spirit of radical refutation (that we see, for example in early Buddhist dialecticians like Nagarjuna) and the spirit of compassion and diamond-sharp dazzling clearness of mind, between clarity, contemplation and caring for others, between logic, meditation and morals in Sanskrit and Pali Buddhist Philosophy.

Grading will be based on 5 reading reports in response to prompts, and a final 1500 words essay showing critical, argumentative and imaginative engagement with the readings. 

Learning Outcomes

Acquaintance with, and ability to write succinctly and philosophically about the fundamental doctrines and arguments of Buddha’s Four Noble Truths, Madhyamika Dialectics, the Five Skandha Bundle theory of Self, Buddhist Logic and Epistemology, Yogacara Refutation of the External World, And Buddhist Ethics etc.

Kin, Friends and Enemies [SOA-2104] [SOA-2104-1]

Faculty Name
Can Evren [can.evren@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will introduce students to foundational theories and seminal empirical studies that have shaped how sociologists and anthropologists explain, interpret, and research the diverse types of social ties that make communities worldwide. Homo sapiens is a social creature who universally builds enduring cooperative relations with fellows. While learning to become and remain a social being is a universal human process likely rooted in our evolutionary makeup, the categories and the frames through which humans relate to, socialize, and cooperate with fellow humans display great diversity across history and geography. Studying diverse frames of relatedness, co-residence, and daily cooperation and asking theoretical questions about what is constant across differences is the primary preoccupation of anthropology as a discipline. Marriage, family, and kinship, in particular, have proved to be near-universal frames, provoking generalizing theories to explain their prevalence and underlying logic. War, enmity, conflict, and rivalry, in the meanwhile, present an equally prevalent frame of relating to others. Throughout this course, we will engage with key theories that inform sociological-anthropological inquiry on practices and forms of kinship, friendship, and enmity.

description:
Fiction Workshop [CW-3001] [CW-3001-1]

Faculty Name
Janice Erica Pariat [janice.pariat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This intensive, workshop-based course invites students to deepen their engagement with the art of storytelling by developing a single, sustained work of fiction over the course of the semester. Whether a long short story or the beginning of a novel or novella, this project will serve as the ground for exploring voice, character, structure, and revision — learning how a story evolves through multiple drafts into something layered and alive.

Weekly workshops will centre on close reading and discussion of student drafts, fostering attentive listening, constructive feedback, and reflective rewriting. Interspersed “book club” sessions, led by students, will feature contemporary short novels that illuminate diverse approaches to narrative craft. By semester’s end, each participant will have completed a polished work of fiction of about 5,000 words, alongside a stronger, more deliberate understanding of how stories take shape on the page.

Learning Outcomes
  • Apply imaginative literature for original work
  • Experiment with language
  • Receive and give constructive criticism
  • How to structure
  • Write and revise a minimum of ten/fifteen pages of polished creative work
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Apart from student writing, we will also be reading the following texts for our "book club" sessions:

  • The Diving Pool by Yoko Ogawa
  • The Haunting of Hill House by Shirley Jackson
  • Nutshell by Ian McEwan
  • Silk by Alessandro Baricco
  • Notes on a Scandal by Zoe Heller
  • The Story of Your Life by Ted Chiang

courseTitle: Exploring Life in the Neighborhood Lab
description:
Exploring Life in the Neighborhood Lab [BIO-1002/ ES-2301] [BIO-1002/ ES-2301-1]

Faculty Name
Imroze Khan [imroze.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ];
Overview

Unprecedented loss of biodiversity, anthropogenic activities, exploitation of natural resources, and globalising tendencies in recent decades threaten the balance between the intricate web of life on Earth and the processes that are pivotal to its survival. Although many efforts are being made globally, we are still far from achieving the necessary measures to restore the balance. One of the primary hindrances is the lack of general awareness of how nature drafts the code of life in our neighbourhoods and how various forms of life together respond, shaping the very basis on which natural forces operate in our backyard, much like a feedback loop. To fill these gaps, this course aims to bring students from various backgrounds— i.e., not limited to Biology only, but also from other sciences, humanities and social sciences— and introduce them to their local ecosystem and the intricacies of biological interactions using some basic and simplified concepts of ecology, evolution, and animal behaviour, followed by field observations as well as laboratory experiments. The course will include many open-ended exercises, encouraging students to develop small questions based on classroom discussions and on observing various natural patterns (e.g., diversity of life) and processes (e.g., sexual interactions, prey-predator interactions, disease spread, cannibalism).

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, we expect students to be more connected to their surroundings, develop an intellectual framework to answer how diverse forms of life coexist, and appreciate the nuanced biological wonders that reside in every pattern and process of the living world. Students will learn to connect bigger ecological phenomena and patterns of animal behaviours with their evolutionary origins. Besides, they will also learn how to build testable hypotheses and design experiments with appropriate sampling, as well as the importance of keeping laboratory notebooks and scientific communication.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The required reading material will be provided at the end of each class. 

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
1 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

This is a laboratory course that involves live animals and plants; therefore, repeating the modules is not possible. Therefore, the total number of allowed absences cannot exceed 4.


Grading

Short Assessments / Applied Work (Quizzes, In-class Writings, Presentations, Group Work, Viva or Lab Reports)Students will have to submit weekly lab reports on their experiment. We will consider the best nine reports. 90

International Finance [FIN-3030/ ECO-3303] [FIN-3030/ ECO-3303-1]

Faculty Name
Biswajit Banerjee [biswajit.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The objective of this course is to provide a framework for making macroeconomic policy decisions and corporate financial decisions in an international context. The world economy has become highly globalized. International trade in goods and services has increased severalfold in recent decades, and changes have taken place in the way international trade occurs between countries. Cross border financial transactions also have exploded in recent decades as a result of liberalization of financial markets and technological advances. Because of the growing integration of economies worldwide, vulnerability of countries and enterprises is greater today than in earlier periods. Managing an international business or one exposed to global competition requires an understanding of international financial instruments, markets, and institutions. This course seeks to provide a working knowledge of these issues. The stress will be on an understanding of the intuition behind the theories, not on mathematical proofs or on replicating empirical results from the literature. The course will not shy away from complex ideas but will try to make the ideas as accessible as possible. Solving mathematical financial problems is an important part of the course.

The course will address the following main topics: national income accounting and balance of payments; international financial systems; global economic environment; growth and slowdown of globalization; foreign exchange market and exchange rate determination; foreign currency derivative instruments; arbitrage and international parity conditions; risks in global finance (e.g., foreign exchange risk and country risk), the management of foreign exchange risk with forwards and options; and international capital flows.

Learning Outcomes

Students will develop a strong foundation to follow economic developments across countries and recognize their interlinkages and spillovers.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There will be no single required text book for the course. Recommended books include:

International Finance: Theory and Policy (11th edition) by Paul R. Krugman, Maurice Obstfeld, and Marc Melitz, Pearson.

International Financial Management (9th edition) by Cheol Eun and Bruce Resnick, McGraw-Hill- Irwin. 

The Globalization Paradox, by Dani Rodrik, Norton & Co.

Financial Times; Wall Street Journal; The Economist

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.

The final letter grades in this course will be determined as per Relative grading

The final letter-grading will be on a curve. The distribution of final grades will be such that no more than 15% will receive an "A" grade, no more than 15% will receive an "A minus grade" and no more than 20% of the class will receive a "B+" grade.

description:
Introduction to Neuroscience/ Biological Psychology [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103] [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The goal of this class is to enable students to understand how a biological system mostly composed of salty proteinaceous water bounded by fat is able to signal information, perform complex computations and produce behaviour. We will start by understanding how single neurons can perform computations and can be understand in the same framework as electronic circuitry. We will understand then how complex information processing and calculation can happen as a result of the ways in which multiple neurons signal to and connect to one another. We will then look at how the brain is organized, and study the nervous systems of humans and other animals, approaching this through the lens of the various tools that neuroscientists have historically used to study neuronal connectivity and the brain. We will cover the electrical properties of nerve cells and voltage dependent membrane permeability; channels, transporters, neurotransmitters and their receptors; synaptic transmission; the brain and its development and plasticity. We will also study complex brain functions and the neural basis of complex cognition, learning and information processing. We explore the ways in which the neuronal processes underlying behaviour have been deduced from various animal models of behaviour, and ways in which genetics and the environment shape the systems that produce behaviour during development.

We then turn to the question of how we learn, how we absorb new material, the ways in which our neural systems tend to conflate correlation and causation, and how critical thinking and environmental training can change learning patterns and feedback to change the structure of the brain. We will take a quick look at the neural basis of complex and interesting phenomena such as motivation, emotion, cognition, consciousness, attention. We will end with an exploration of how neural systems can exhibit pathology, how neurodegeneration and trauma can impact the system, and how medication and drugs work, with a focus on the limitations of what we collectively understand and the pressing need for further research to take forward the field. This course eventually hopes to make clear the relationship between brain and behaviour.

Learning Outcomes

This course is offered to both biology and psychology students and covers the same ground as a standard course on Biological Psychology. It aims to introduce neuroscience as a specialized discipline, and to enable students to understand how a biological system is able to signal information, perform computations and produce behaviour. This course will also use teaching tools in the discussion section that enable an intuitive grasp of neural processes, such as simulations to understand how various factors affect neuronal functioning, and experiments to demonstrate neurons in action and how various interventions affect neuronal functioning.

The main expectation of students is that they pay full attention in class, alerting the TF or me, through class discussions or by posting on Canvas if there is anything they do not understand. Canvas posts are encouraged to be public, so that other students can benefit from reading responses to questions asked, although they can certainly be anonymous. Since each week of class builds on the previous week, it is important that everyone is on board, so if there is something that you are not clear on by the end of class, go through the material and attend the discussion section. The weekly quizzes should also provide feedback on what you do and do not fully comprehend, and I will also incorporate mistakes made in the exam into my class structure, explicitly addressing ways in which neural systems tend to be misunderstood.

In order to equip students to become familiar with the level of rigour needed to think through some of these questions, we will also look at how to survey and evaluate literature in the field of biological psychology, how to quickly but accurately read graphs and how to cite literature.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The recommended textbook for this course is Biological Psychology by James W. Kalat (Kalat, J. W. (2008). Biological Psychology. Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning). I have a physical copy of the 11th edition. A soft copy of the 10th edition is also available on Canvas - the 10th and 11th editions do not differ hugely and I’d recommend this for anyone who is comfortable with reading on their computers.

 

For additional reading students can refer to:

Kandel, E. R., Schwartz, J. H., & Jessell, T. M. (2000). Principles of neural science. New York: McGraw-Hill, Health Professions Division.

Purves, D., Augustine, G., Fitzpatrick, D., Hall, W., Lamantia, A.-S., & White, L. (2012) Neuroscience. Sinauer Associates, Inc.: Sunderland, MA.

 

Soft copies of all are available on the class website.

Language diversity - will be enabled upon request.

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Attendance Policy: Attendance will be marked as a component of the participation grade, but not as a barrier to doing exams. Missing class is a students loss mostly due to losing out on the flow of conceptually difficult learning, and will minimally impact the class participation grades. Note, though, that if you miss a quiz, you will not be offered a re-take of that particular quiz. You can take the quizzes offered at the end of the semester based on the full syllabus, as long as you have attempted every quiz before, or have an excused absence for missed quizzes.


Attendance will be calculated bearing in mind the possibility of three unexcused absences. These include all medical issues, co-curricular and sporting events, conferences or events where you represent the University, any interviews or talks, and other unforeseen events. All those who want additional excused absences if they are unable to attend classes due to medical reasons (either their own or for anything involving caregiving for a loved one) are requested to email the TAs (and CC the TFs, but please not Bittu), with a copy of their medical note (with the date clearly mentioned) along with their emails. For students who miss class for unavoidable reasons, they can visit their TA/TF, during office hours for help.

Introduction to Travel Writing [MS-2000/ CW-2012] [MS-2000/ CW-2012-1]

Faculty Name
Tisha Srivastav [tisha.srivastav@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is a contemporary mix of thinking about how we travel, reading travel accounts on India and media writing skills for travel writing. It centres on ideas of travel, be they thinkers, historical and contemporary travel accounts on India, or the panorama mode on your smartphone. This course will give you a broad exposure into the kind of travel writing you didn’t think Indians were writing. Course will include a guest lecture, a documentary screening, a field trip & potential internship opportunity.

The flow of the classes: Each week, one class will centre on critical thought and practice readings of  travel and the other on understanding the fundamentals of media-friendly feature writing on travel.

No prerequisites.

Learning Outcomes

An introduction to a wealth of textual and visual travel related literary material on India.

Honing your curiosity and observation capacities, you will polish a media writing skill set  to produce a publishing worthy travel account.

Industry linkages

Through writing, reading, communicating and thinking through the question - is there any such thing as an Indian travel voice, you will be encouraged to find your own.
