Politics and Society in India, 1937-1977 [HIS-3207/ POL-3039/ IR-3007] [HIS-3207/ POL-3039/ IR-3007-1]

Faculty Name
Mahesh Rangarajan [mahesh.rangarajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course will focus on the key processes and changes that unfolded in politics and society in India between 1937 the year of the provincial elections under the 1935 Government of India Act and 1977 when Congress was first defeated at the polls in independent India.  Beyond the parties of power, it will explore the debates on nationhood and equality, as in the Pune Pact of Gandhi and Ambedkar and the choices of who was the bigger adversary the imperial ruler or its adversary as in the Nehru Bose relationship. The course explores the linkages between the unfolding the Second World War and the Partition of 1947. 

Often specific episodes in sub nationalism as in Nagaland, Assam or Kashmir are seen in isolation and not in relation to one another and only in terms of policies in independent India with less attention to longer imperial legacies. Similarly, the reorganisation of borders of much of India on linguistic lines 1956-66 owed as much to longer term evolution of language based identity politics as to the events of the  immediate post 1947 decades. When and where did the long and short term matter can only be glimpsed at in this course but it can help overcome many gaps in perception. 

Most of all the 1950 Constitution, itself the product of intense debate opened up the possibility of equality across class, caste, tribe, gender and creed but had to contend with the reality of deep disparity in society and the economy. How far economic planning and democratic politics in the first post dependence era fared is worth studying in itself : it is also striking how contemporary some of the debates seem today. Much work has been done now to unearth hitherto hidden voices and equally so to shed light on trends  such as demographic expansion and urban growth.

By 1967, the Congress system was fraying and it was only via great split and reconfiguration completed only in 1971-72 ( assisted by the victory in the Bangladesh Liberation War) and the ascendancy of Indira Gandhi that a new equilibrium emerged. Yet, the oil price shock and the Emergency unsettled things and made for the first peaceful hand over of office in 1977.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, it expected that the student will have a better grasp of why, when and how this was a critical period in the emergence of modern India, not only in terms of transition from imperial rule to independent nation hood but also how political, economic and social changes within India were inter connected with those in the rest of the world at large. India was a major arena and it was in turn affected by end of colonial empire, the Cold war and the Sino Soviet split; equally so by the great economic changes during the Depression and the Second World War.

The regional and social diversity of the country and the way many features we now take for granted like the linguistic states or the language policy emerged from the crucible of contest. What it meant to be an Indian and how became especially important in the context of creation of a nation state over a vast and diverse land of continental proportions. So too the search for equality in a law governed manner in a society marked by multiple hierarchies. 

This course will help understand why and how the Congress dominance of the 1937 provincial elections that prefigured the post 1947 dominance of Indian politics came to an end in 1977, in a democratic free and fair election but after a spell of civil marital law. In this as in so much else these four decades were marked by contrary impulses and movements, and by exploring these we will understand not only India but the world in better light.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

courseTitle: A History of India Pakistan Relations
description:
A History of India Pakistan Relations [IR-2014/ HIS-3807/ POL-2047] [IR-2014/ HIS-3807/ POL-2047-1]

Faculty Name
Pallavi Raghavan [pallavi.raghavan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Objectives

The object of this course is to offer a causative framework to understand the trajectory of India- Pakistan relations.

This course will offer a chronology of the major episodes of conflict in the history of the India- Pakistan relationship, including 1948, 1965, 1971, and 2026. While looking at these episodes, we will probe more deeply a set of analytical frameworks that can help us explain the underlying nature of the India- Pakistan relationship, and whether these can serve as adequate reasons for explaining the outbreak of conflict.

The modules of this course have thus been divided into different schools of thought about the underlying basis of the shaping of Indian Foreign Policy: as a manifestation of an ideologically driven nationalism; a territorialized preoccupation with boundaries; differing assumptions about federalization; the nature of the entrenchment of military elites; the dynamics of a nuclearized rivalry; and the manifestation of religious extremism. We will attempt to situate a specific episode of conflict within each of these frameworks and examine whether or not the framework offers an adequate grounding of the reason for the outbreak of hostility.

The desired outcome of the course, thus, is to enable the student to critically evaluate the relative benefits of different frames of analysis in understanding the precise causes that push the Indian and Pakistani state toward war.

Time Series Econometrics [ECO-6403] [ECO-6403-1]

Faculty Name
Piyali Banerjee [piyali.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The objective of this course is to help students understand important issues and methodologies for forecasting and time series analysis in empirical and theoretical research. Upon completion of the course, students will be able to undertake forecasting and perform time series analysis.

Learning Outcomes

Course Description:

This course covers major issues in financial econometrics and macro-econometrics. Topics include Box Jenkins models, reduced form and structural VAR models, ARCH-GARCH models, and Unit root Models.

Learning Goals:

Students will obtain a thorough and complete understanding of major issues of time series analysis and will be able to conduct their research.

Method of Instruction:

The course will be given primarily through lectures and class discussions. Each student is strongly encouraged to participate in class discussions. Besides, every student is responsible for attending the class and being prepared to contribute substantively to the class discussion. Classroom participation is a vital part of this course.

In each lecture, we collectively share ownership and responsibility for the success of the course.

A minimum requirement for each class meeting is to have read the assigned material from the reference books and articles, and to express opinions, comments, and insights relative to the discussion topic. Students are also expected to participate in all class activities. Tardiness and absenteeism will negatively affect your contribution grade.

courseTitle: Workshop in Creative and Critical Writing
description:
Workshop in Creative and Critical Writing [CW-3003/ CW-4701] [CW-3003/ CW-4701-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Prakash Chaudhuri [amit.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

A novelist may begin to feel that realist fiction, or even fiction itself, is no longer an adequate means to represent reality. A critic might feel one day that the footnoted academic essay closes down certain ways of thinking. One might begin to wonder, confronted with certain works, if criticism is an imaginative act and poetry a form of critical thinking. It's this alternative tradition that this course will aim to explore.

description:
Advanced Ethics [PHI-4730] [PHI-4730-1]

Faculty Name
Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course will focus on the topic of Virtues and Vices. We will overwhelmingly focus on moral virtues and vices.

The course will be divided into three general sections:

1. Broader normative questions: spectrum of virtue theories, objections to virtue theories

2. Metaethical considerations (e.g. what are character traits? how do we apply virtue views? how do we figure out what counts as a virtue/vice?)

3. Narrower normative questions: we will explore the nature of particular virtues and vices (e.g. honesty, generosity, being a good friend, arrogance, stubbornness, etc.) This section will be largely determined by votes from students.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Exact grading structure to be determined by course enrollment but the following expectations will be in play:

  • regular short writing assignments
  • at least one longer writing assignment
  • regular and active participation in course discussion

Introduction to Ethics [PHI-2730] [PHI-2730-1]

Faculty Name
Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Is it acceptable to harm and kill dogs for lifesaving biomedical research? Am I ethically required to let a loved one die if doing so saves the lives of many strangers? Or can I simply do whatever I feel like doing and stop worrying about these thorny issues? Practical ethical questions, large and small, arise every day. To answer them, we must examine more fundamental questions in ethics—questions about what we owe to each other, about what kinds of lives we should live, and about whether there are unbreakable ethical rules at all. We will examine how prominent ethical theories answer these questions and how they apply to our lives.

Learning Outcomes

◊ Consider moral claims and arguments from a philosophical perspective, i.e. a perspective that is sympathetic yet critical and analytical. This includes the capacity to locate their premises, reconstruct their arguments, and evaluate their conclusions by determining whether they contain fallacies, false claims, or other weaknesses and limitations

◊ Understand central philosophical positions in normative and applied ethics and their basis in metaethics

◊ Articulate well-reasoned philosophical ideas in a variety of contexts including discussions with peers and essays

Indian Environmental Politics [ES-2433/ POL-3052] [ES-2433/ POL-3052-1]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Elective Course

Indian Environmental Politics (ES2433-POL3052)

Prof Mukul Sharma

What shapes the idea of ‘nature’ in India - politics, caste, religion, or livelihood? This course explores the vibrant and contested field of Indian environmental politics, where ecological questions are deeply intertwined with democracy, identity, religion and development. From forests and rivers to cities and climate, it examines how environmental concerns have been imagined, mobilised, and resisted across India’s political and social landscape.

Indian environmentalism is not a single movement but a spectrum of voices, ideologies, and struggles. The course highlights how multiple movements redefine environmental action in terms of dignity, survival, and equality, challenging dominant visions of nature. It also investigates how religion, region, identity and nationalism have shaped ecological ideas - from sacred rivers and forests to contemporary forms of Hindu environmentalism - revealing how faith and power intersect in environmental discourse.

By engaging with key environmental movements, and contemporary climate and urban environmental issues and campaigns, students will see how ecological struggles reimagine democracy, citizenship, and rights. Ultimately, students will be encouraged to ask critical questions: Who speaks for the environment? What worldviews define sustainability? And how do caste, indigeneity, and community shape ecological futures? Combining history, theory, and lived experience with case studies, this course offers an interdisciplinary understanding of how struggles over nature reflect the deeper struggles over justice, power and recognition in India today.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): Indian Environmental Politics: An Introduction to Historical, Economic, Ideological and Political Aspects of the Ecological Issues

Unit 2: (Week 3): Democracy, Justice and Indian Environmentalism (with case study)

Unit 3: (Week 4): Nature, Nationalism and Indian Environmental politics (with case study)

Unit 4: (Week 5): Religion, Environment, Politics (with case study)

Unit 5: (Week 6): Ethnicity and Indigenous Environmental Politics (with case study)

Unit 6: (Week 7): Caste, Dalit and Environment (with case study)

Unit 7: (Week 8): Climate, Energy and Indian Environmentalism

Unit 8: (Week 9): Urban Environmental Politics

Unit 9: (Week 10): Movements, Networks & Alliances (with case studies)

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-3]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and, of course, thinking. In effect, you will learn to ask the ‘why’ and ‘how’ questions alongside the ‘who’ and ‘what’ queries you have been posing through your school education. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding—of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing.

The theme this semester for this particular ICT course will be 'Feminisms and Masculinities' where we will read essays and extracts by writers, scholars and activists such as Angela Davis, Rafia Zakaria, bell hooks, James Baldwin, Sanjay Shrivastava, Rahul Roy, Sharmila Rege and Nivedita Menon to explore whether there is one universal Feminism and one accepted Masculinity or is the world around us inhabited by multiple feminisms and several masculinities; we shall also try to look carefully for links between these multiple feminisms and varying masculinities. In exploring these questions, we will also look at a variety of popular cultural references: memes, short films, podcasts, zines, and advertisements. 

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material and documenting these via strategic note-making.

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. These will be specified on a weekly basis on the schedule at the end of this outline. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participatein discussions, and work on exercises and assignments both individually and in collaboration with your course mates. The pedagogy is entirely real-time, hands-on reading, writing and discussion based, so class-participation is super important.

Translation Theories and Multilingual Contexts (SAL) [ENG-4401] [ENG-4401-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Unbeknownst to us, translation plays myriad roles in our everyday and professional lives. From seeking equivalents to names of spices or plants; metaphors of a poem, anatomical knowledge of the body; agony over the Indianness (or lack of it) of ‘secularism’ – all of these are instances of  how translation pervades our very existence. Translation is a mode of understanding other people’s world-views which come to us in their words, idioms, forms of expressions and experiences. Translators escape the arrogance of being authors; and thereby create a bridge and non-threatening environment for mediation between divergent languages; contexts and epistemologies. Translators also collude in forms of epistemic violence. How have different disciplines thought about translation? What are the differences in theoretical perspectives that have emerged from multilingual societies, such as the Indian one? How have philosophers from time immemorial to Derrida perceived translation? This course covers a wide range of theorists from across the world; puts them in conversation with each other; and also turns every now and then to literary examples of translation.

courseTitle: Critical Thinking Seminar: Writing the Self
description:
Critical Thinking Seminar: Writing the Self [ENG-2331] [ENG-2331-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course seeks to examine the autobiography or memoir as a literary genre, an historical archive, and an individual/community narrative.

We will also consider how graphic novels, poems and blogs can be seen as constructions of a specific kind of persona.

As the definition of autobiography has expanded over time, different kinds of memoirs and autobiographies have liberated Identity as a singular noun to self-consciously manage our plural or even desired identities and playfully experiment with different notions of selfhood.

 

In this course, we will examine the idea of “truth telling” that is often associated with autobiographies. We also consider how the study of international autobiographies allows us a view of the local in the context of the global.

Learning Outcomes

Learn about the genre of autobiography.

See the historical development and change in the form and content of  autobiography.

Explore the diverse cultural contexts in which autobiographies are produced.

Question why autobiographies are written.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Texts: You must have.

Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl. (1952)

Marjane Satrapi :Persepolis (2000)  (Graphic Novel)

Azadeh Moaveni: Lipstick Jihad: A Memoir of Growing Up Iranian in America and American in Iran. (2005)

bell hooks. Bone Black (1996)

A. Revathi: The Truth About Me: A Hijra Life Story. (2017)

Riverbend. Baghdad Burning (2005) Excerpts

Jerry Pinto. Em and the Big Hoom (2012)

Yashica Dutt. Coming Out As Dalit: A Memoir. (2019)

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: Attendance is mandatory and will impact your final grade. You may miss 3 classes during the semester without penalty.  After three absences, a letter from your final grade will be deducted for each missed class. If you have 3 unexcused absences, I will reserve the right to fail you for the course.  Coming more than 5 minutes late to class will count as an absence. Participation in class discussions are an essential requirement. This means listening as well as responding and reacting to the ongoing discussions about the readings. Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings. You must complete the assigned readings by the day before so you come prepared to discuss in class.

Nonequilibrium Statistical Mechanics [PHY-4620/ PHY-6620] [PHY-4620/ PHY-6620-1]

Faculty Name
Somendra Mohan Bhattacharjee [somendra.bhattacharjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course explores various approaches to studying non-equilibrium systems, for which no general theoretical framework exists. In contrast to equilibrium systems, non-equilibrium systems lack a well-defined concept of entropy. Topics include the Langevin equation, Fokker–Planck formalism, Martin–Siggia–Rose field theory, master equation, Boltzmann equation, and hydrodynamics, providing a broad perspective on non-equilibrium behavior.

The course will also examine key results such as the fluctuation–dissipation theorem, work theorem, linear response theory, and Onsager relations. If time permits, selected model systems will be discussed to introduce the concept of the renormalization group.

Learning Outcomes

Students will develop familiarity with non-equilibrium systems, their theoretical descriptions, and key results, gaining a deeper understanding of the principles and methods used to study systems outside of equilibrium.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

References:
General
Reif: Fundamentals of statistical and thermal physics
Chaikin-Lubensky: Principles of condensed mattter physics

description:
Public Economics [ECO-6720] [ECO-6720-1]

Faculty Name
Bhanu Gupta [bhanu.gupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will cover the role of government in modern economies. We will dig deep into the study of various instruments used to generate government revenue and analyze efficient ways to spend government monies. You will also be exposed to microeconomic models that are used to study the reaction of agents to government policies.  This course will serve as an introduction to various empirical tools used in modern public economics. Government expenditure, externalities, public goods, taxation, social security programs,  are some of the topics that will be covered in this course. Abstract concepts will be mapped to real-world examples to develop your public economics intuition.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, the aim is to make you comfortable with the fundamentals of public economics theory and develop problem-solving skills that will be beneficial in other economic courses.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The main course material will be papers assigned during the course. In case you haven’t studied public economics during undergraduate studies, please refer to the following textbook:

Gruber, J., Public Finance & Public Policy (I am using the 5th edition).

A list of topics that will be discussed in the course are given below. Please note that subject to time constraints, topics may be added or deleted from this list. List of topics are: Introduction to Public Economics; Defining and Measuring Inequality; Theoretical and Emprical Tools for Public Economics; Tax Incidence and Efficiency costs of Taxation; Optimal Labor Income Taxation; Taxes and Labor Supply; Externalities; Public Goods; Taxes on Capital and Savings; Behavioral Public Finance; Political Economy; Social and Health Insurance; Education and Discrimination.

Media, Culture and Society [MS-1201] [MS-1201-1]

Faculty Name
Chitralekha Dhamija [chitralekha@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The purpose in this course is to familiarize students with significant domains of social science theory that help us think critically about relationships between media, culture, and society. We will discuss some of the seminal sociological, anthropological, political, as well as literary and other writings that influence contemporary understandings about media and its dialectical interventions with self and society. The course is structured in a manner that enables a sense of the historical flows– and disruptions– of these ideas. Our intention is not to learn theory but to use theory from a range of interdisciplinary domains to learn about media and our world in present times. 

Learning Outcomes

Over the semester, we will think about: 

1. Conceptual introductions

2. Marx and Media

3. Cultural Theory/ Postcolonialism 

4. Symbolic Interaction/ Structuration 

5. Gender and Media

6. Postmodernism/ Surveillance

7. Anthropology of Media

8. Project Presentations

Behavioral Economics [ECO-3620] [ECO-3620-1]

Faculty Name
Srijita Ghosh [srijita.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a 300-level research-focused elective course. The main objective of this course is to introduce you to cutting-edge research in behavioral economics. In the first part of the course, we will explore how preferences (risk, time, and social preference) differ from what is typically assumed in the Neoclassical literature. In the second half of the course, we will look into cognitive economics, i.e., how cognitive constraints affect decision making.  We will discuss both experimental findings and theoretical modeling in both cases. The goal of the course is to help students generate research ideas in behavioral economics. In the last 2 weeks, the students will be expected to present their research ideas in class. 

Learning Outcomes
  • Read seminal papers in the behavioral economics and cognitive economics literature.
  • Develop and present own research ideas on related topics

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Micro 1, Micro 2 and Econometrics

We will not use any textbook but refer to the two volumes of Handbook of Behavioral Economics.

courseTitle: Literature and the Age of Empire
description:
Literature and the Age of Empire [ENG-2002] [ENG-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this survey course we will read a selection of texts written by British poets, novelists, painters and philosophers from the late 17th to the 19th century in order to examine how they participated in the creation and construction of Empire. We will read texts ranging from Aphra Behn’s Oronooko and Alexander Pope’s The Rape of the Lock to William Wordsworth’s Lyrical Ballads and Adam Smith’s Wealth of Nations, Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, Emily Bronte’s Wuthering Heights, the Sherlock Holmes novels as well as a few colonial subjects who write back to Empire (mostly from the Urdu literary tradition) such as Sir Syed Ahmed Khan.

courseTitle: Literature and the Age of Empire
description:
Literature and the Age of Empire [ENG-2002] [ENG-2002-2]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, we will look at a range of texts – novels, drama, poetry, letters, articles – that help us consider the ways in which the history of Empire shapes the literary developments of the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries. How does Empire make its presence known in these texts, and how do they constitute our understanding of Empire? One working hypothesis in this course is that the monolithic entity suggested by that capital ‘E’ is itself a (powerful and consequential) fiction—one we can trace in the processes of construction, the internal contradictions and incoherences, and the de- and re-territorializations that went into the development of the British Empire as historical fact, ideological structure, and imagined community. Our readings will range, chronologically, from John Dryden’s Aureng-zebe to E. M. Forster’s A Passage to India. Moving across countries and centuries, this course will study literary and social formations that continue to affect us to this day.

Learning Outcomes

Course objectives:

  • To read Empire and analyse colonial discourse;
  • To acquaint majors/minors with significant works from the ‘English’ canon, while critically scrutinising the formation of canons;
  • To read closely, to read in context, tracing the effects of time and place in creating literary meaning;
  • To become better readers and writers.

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

As a student of History and Literature, have you ever wondered mastering what language can help you in your academic endeavors? Look no further than the 'Persian I'. This course will be insightful journey into the world of Persian language, literature and History. This course equips you with foundational skills, facilitating the learning of related languages like Urdu. The course will also have the opportunity to engage with a native speaker, explore Persian manuscripts, and delve into the works of legendary poets such as Rumi, Saadi, Iqbal. A field trip to Sikandra in Agra will enhance cultural immersion of students.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will have gained not only a grip on language but also a deep appreciation for Persian history, literature, and culture. This course is an great opportunity to expand your linguistic horizons and unlock a new Persianate world.

courseTitle: Dastangoi: The Rediscovered Art of Storytelling
description:
Dastangoi: The Rediscovered Art of Storytelling [CPA-0059] [CPA-0059-1]

Overview

Dastangoi, an ancient art of storytelling comprises of Dastans which were epics and were
often recited. They were a crucial part of our oral tradition. Through this course we aim to analyse and compare different forms of Dastangoi performances using practical examples. Given the linguistic diversity at Ashoka, we would also like to explore the possibility of Dastangoi beyond Urdu language. The sessions would be interactive, and students will get a chance to work on performative aspects of dastangoi like voice modulation, poetry recitation, pronunciation, expressions. Towards the end, the students will be required to present their learnings on stage.

Probability and Statistics [MAT-2020/ CS-1209/ PHY-1208] [MAT-2020/ CS-1209/ PHY-1208-1]

Faculty Name
Abhishek Khetan [abhishek.khetan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Description:
 

The course will be an introduction to probability theory and statistics, with emphasis on discrete probability.

We will start by a quick recap of set theoretic formalism and some discussion of elementary combinatorics. Then we will start the course proper. Following are the main topics of discussion.

Probability spaces, probability measures, conditional probability, Bayes theorem, random variables and their distribution, independence, probability mass function and distribution func-
tion, various special ditrinutiosn (Examples: Bernoulli, Binomial, Poisson, Geometric distributions), expectation, variance, linearity of expectation, moment generating functions, random vectors, marginal distributions, joint moment generating functions, covariance, coupling, continuous random variables, density functions (example: uniform, normal, and exponential distributions) continuous random vector, joint density function, joint distribution function.

We will also discuss concentration results like Chebyshev’s and Chernoff inequalities. 

The law of large numbers and Central Limit theorem will also be discussed (perhaps without proof).

We will look at various combinatorial applications to reinforce the concepts and also go through some paradoxes.

After this we will discuss stats.

Descriptive statistics, distribution of sampling statistics, parameter Estimation and basics of hypothesis testing, simple linear regression with one regressor (only if time permits).

Learning Outcomes

The aim of the student is to help the students aquire probabilistic intuition, be familiar with a variety of standard distributions, and acquaint him/her to the myths and some pitfalls.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will assume familiarity with basic calculus (limits, differentiation, integration). It would be good to know some elementary counting but we will do a quick review.

Suggested Reading:
1) S. M. Ross: First Course in Probability, Pearson.
2) S. M. Ross: Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Engineers and Scien-
tists.
3) J. L. Devore: Probability and Statistics for Engineering, Cengage, 2012.
4) V. K. Rohatgi, E. S. Saleh: An Introduction to Probability and Statistics, Wiley-
Blackwell, 3rd edition, 2015.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-1]

Faculty Name
Biswajit Banerjee [biswajit.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Geoeconomics and Global Governance: From Efficiency to Weaponization

Description:

This course examines the abrupt and fundamental shift in the international economic system from a rules-based, efficiency-driven model (1995–2020) to a power-based, security-driven model (2020–present). We will analyze the collapse of multilateral institutions (GATT/WTO), the weaponization of trade and finance, and the resulting fragmentation of supply chains and currency regimes. Core modules focus on the mechanics of modern protectionism (Reciprocal Tariffs, GVC traps), the financial implications of sanctions (De-dollarization, Gold accumulation), and the strategic visions for the emerging multipolar order as articulated by global leaders (Trump, Xi Jinping, Jaishankar, Macron). The course utilizes case studies from the 2026 US-India tariff crisis and the G20 breakdown to provide real-time policy analysis

(No prior background in economics is required).

 

Learning Outcomes

Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

Analyze Foundational Trade Logic: Distinguish between the classical theories of Absolute and Comparative Advantage and the rationales for protectionism (Infant Industry).

Deconstruct Tariff Mechanics: Explain how tariffs are applied in a Global Value Chain (GVC) context, including the Gross Value vs. Value Added distortion and the cascading/multiplicative cost effect.

Evaluate Financial Weaponization: Articulate the origins of the Dollar's dominance and explain why the use of financial sanctions (asset seizure) has triggered the current de-dollarization efforts by the BRICS nations.

Compare Global Governance Models: Contrast the strategic visions of key global architects (Xi's Parallel Order, Jaishankar's Multi-Alignment, Macron's Strategic Autonomy) in response to the US-led system's decline.

Synthesize Geopolitical Risks: Analyze the structural causes and consequences of institutional breakdown (e.g., the G20 crisis) and interpret the resulting trade-offs between Efficiency and Security in the current multipolar environment

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students are expected to complete the following basic readings, which provide the conceptual and historical foundations for the course:

Rodrik, Dani (2011). The Globalization Paradox: Democracy and the Future of the World Economy. (W.W. Norton & Co.)
– A clear and accessible overview of globalization’s benefits, tensions, and political consequences.

Baldwin, Richard (2016). The Great Convergence: Information Technology and the New Globalization. (Harvard University Press)
– Explains how digital technologies transformed trade, production, and global value chains.

Additional readings, podcasts reference, links to youtube videos will be provided during the class.

Krugman, Paul, and Obstfeld, Maurice (latest ed.). International Economics: Theory and Policy. (selected introductory chapters)
– Provides intuitive explanations of trade, exchange rates, and balance of payments concepts.

Stiglitz, Joseph (2002). Globalization and Its Discontents. (W.W. Norton & Co.)
– A critical account of globalization and its governance challenges, from the perspective of a former World Bank chief economist.

Selected contemporary readings:

IMF World Economic Outlook, overview chapters (latest edition).

WTO World Trade Report (selected sections on trade policy and protectionism).

Project Syndicate or Financial Times op-eds by Dani Rodrik, Martin Wolf, or Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala.

Overview

You will learn the foundation of calculus in this course, like number systems, sequences, limits, functions, differentiation and integration etc. This course is a mandatory course for all students considering mathematics as a major or minor. Students with mathematics at the level of 10 + 2 might find some overlap with this course. However, mathematical rigor and emphasis on problem solving are the keys in this course. Learning Outcomes
  1. Number systems.
  2. Sequences and series. 
  3. Functions of a real variable.
  4. Limits and continuity, Differentiation. Mean value theorem. L’Hospital rule. Taylor series.
  5. Curve tracing.
  6. Riemann integral. Definite and indefinite integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus.
  7. Applications of differential and integral calculus.

courseTitle: Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender
description:
Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender [ENG-3411/ MS-2441] [ENG-3411/ MS-2441-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Bombay cinema, affectionately called “Bollywood” has become the background music to our lives, whether as innocent entertainment or ‘time pass’. However, we often overlook Bollywood’s serious intent and strong ideological underpinnings. Right from its inception, with Dadasaheb Phalke’s Raja Harishchandra (1913), it has shaped the public narrative in India.
 

While the themes of Hindi films have changed over the years --from the patriotic ‘Mother India’ to the sports-feminist ‘Dangal’, the presentation of nationalism, sports and sexualities may just be old wine in new bottles. We will examine these ideologies primarily through the lens of gender.

We will also explore how the language, fashion, music, dance, and social values embedded in Bollywood films are disseminated. International theoretical readings from ideas of nationalism, film, gender, class, and cultural studies, and literature from various parts of the world will underpin our discussions of Bombay’s film industry and our exploration of the values and ideologies embedded in apparently innocent entertainment.
One of the course’s goals is to recognize these themes and develop the analytical tools to effectively “read” a text/film, empowering us to identify and challenge mainstream norms.

[Please note –Supplementary readings and films may be assigned during the course of the semester. Film viewing is mandatory. Even if you have seen the film before it is important to see it again for this class and with a view to the topics and ideas being discussed. Please find a way to view the films on your own. Ashoka may not be able to arrange screenings.]

description:
War and Violence [PHI-3776/ POL-3075] [PHI-3776/ POL-3075-1]

Faculty Name
Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Are war and other forms of political violence ever justified? This course focuses on the nature and justification of violence in the context of war and political conflict. Many defenders of just war theory claim that forms of violence which are unjustified if performed by a lone individual are acceptable when performed by a state or in the name of a political cause. Pacifists, on the other hand, claim that many or all forms of state sponsored or political violence are unjustified. We will examine prominent positions on the justification of violence, and will consider whether specific forms of political violence, such as terrorism and genocide, are distinctively morally problematic. We will seek philosophical clarity through analysis of key theories and application of these theories to specific conflicts and wars.  

Learning Outcomes
  • Display understanding of the most prominent positions on the justification of war: realism, just war theory, and pacifism.
  • Display understanding of key positions on selected issues relating to political violence: genocide and responses to colonialism.
  • Develop well-reasoned philosophical arguments concerning the nature and justification of violence and war that engage with relevant authors and support a clear thesis.
  • Apply philosophical analysis to historical and contemporary conflicts and offer plausible, well-reasoned opinions about their moral status.

Environmental Governance: Institutions, Policy, Politics [ES-2434/ POL-2062] [ES-2434/ POL-2062-1]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Elective Course ES-2434/POL-2062

Environmental Governance: Institutions, Policy, Politics

Prof Mukul Sharma

This course foregrounds some of the critical environmental challenges, by addressing them through diverse ideas and systems of governance. Focusing on environmental governance, it draws its connections with politics, policies, laws, institutions, civil society organisations and environmental movements. The course covers the evolution of various governance systems and their present status, the debates and contests around them, and the emergence of new ideas and mechanisms to govern the use of natural resources through sustainability, justice and equality. It takes a micro and macro, sectorial and broader, and a local and global view, to understand the complex and wide nature of environmental governance in India. With case studies from government and non-government sectors, civil society organisations, and movement groups in different spaces, locations and times, the course explains environmental management and regulation in theoretical and practical terms. Dealing with questions of forests, water, gender, adivasis and climate change, the course encompasses concepts, debates, policies, practices, methods and tools of environmental governance.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): Different Concepts of Environmental Governance: Multiple Issues and Debates

Unit 2: (Week 3 & 4): Environmental Governance: Politics, Constitution, Law, Institution, Policy and Civil Society

Unit 3: (Week 5) New Components of Environmental Governance: Social Audit, Green Accounting, Public Hearing, Environmental Impact Assessment

Unit 4: (Week 6): Environmental Governance, Decentralisation and Local Self Governments

Unit 5: (Week 7): Environmental Governance and Forests: Concepts, Discussions and Case Studies

Unit 6: (Week 8): Environmental Governance and Water: Concepts, Debates and Case Studies

Unit 7: (Week 9): Gender and Environmental Governance: Concepts, Debates and Case Studies

Unit 8: (Week 10): Climate Change and Governance: Local, National and International Politics, Institutions, Policies

Unit 9: (Week 11): Adivasis and Environmental Governance: Issues, Institutions, Contests and Case Studies

Unit 10: (Week 12 & 13): Social Movements, Environmental Protests and Environmental Governance: Issues, Debates, Institutions, Case Studies.

Essential Readings will be given in a google drive.

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): 

Essentail Reading: Robert F. Durant, Daniel J. Fiorino and Rosemary O’ Leary (eds.), Environmental Governance Reconsidered: Challenges, Choices, and Opportunities, The MIT Press, pp. 1-28, 29-68

Unit 2: (Week 3 & 4):

Essential Reading: Robert F. Durant, Daniel J. Fiorino and Rosemary O’ Leary (eds.), Environmental Governance Reconsidered: Challenges, Choices, and Opportunities, The MIT Press, pp. 1-28, 29-68 and further chapters in Part 1 of the book.

Unit 3: (Week 5):

Essential Reading: Andrew Jordon, Rudiger K. W. Wurzel, Anthony R. Zioto, ‘New’ Instruments of Environmental Governance? Frank Cass, 2003, pp. 1-20.

Unit 4: (Week 6): 

Essential Reading: Satyajit Singh, The Local in Governance: Politics, Decentralization, and Environment, OUP, 2016, pp. 1-38.

Unit 5: (Week 7):

Essential Reading: Sharachchandra Lele, Ajit Menon (eds.), Democratizing Forest Governance in India, OUP, 2014, pp. 1-22.

Madhu Sarin, ‘Undoing Historical Injustice: Reclaiming Citizenship Rights and Democratic Forest Governance through the Forest Rights Act’ in Democratizing Forest Governance in India, pp. 100-146.

Unit 6: (Week 8):

Essential Reading: Ramaswamy R Iyer, ‘Water: Charting a Course for the Future – I & II, Economic and Political Weekly, April 2001.

K. J. Joy et. al, Water Conflicts in India: A Million Water Revolts in the Making, Routledge, 2008, pp. xvii-xxxii

Unit 7: (Week 9):

Essential Reading: Bina Agarwal, Gender and Green Governance: The Political Economy of Women’s Presence Within and Beyond Community Forestry, OUP, 2010, pp. 3-30.

Unit 8: (Week 10):

Essential Reading: Navroj K. Dubash, India in a Warming World: Integrating Climate Change and Development, OUP, 2019, pp. 329-399

Unit 9: (Week 11):

Essential Reading: Bengt G. Karlsson, Unruly Hills: A Political Ecology of India’s Northeast, Berghahn Books, 2011, pp. 227-265.

Unit 10: (Week 12 & 13):

Essential Reading: Aseem Shrivastava, Ashish Kothari, Churning the Earth: The Making of Global India, Penguin, 2012, pp. 254-292, 293-308.

courseTitle: Performing the New World: Rituals for an Actor's Imagination
description:
Performing the New World: Rituals for an Actor's Imagination [CPA-0068] [CPA-0068-1]

Overview

The relationship between theatre and ritual is a complex one spanning millennia. There are as many rituals as there are narratives, ideologies, cultures and, indeed, theatrical traditions. But do such acts speak to us even today?

In this course, students will discover how sacred and secular ritual forms have and continue to influence contemporary theatre practices. Through improvisation, collaborative devising, and theatre games and exercises that draw on psychophysical praxis, they will grapple with questions like – What is a ritual? How can the power of ritual awaken, challenge and nourish the actor’s inner life? Can the physical enactment of ritual transform perception and presence? What can theatre practice offer us in an uncertain, rapidly evolving world like ours? Students will also develop their own individual and collective rituals based on personal inquiry into their own lived experiences, creative impulses and immediate needs.

courseTitle: Conservation Policy in the Developing World
description:
Conservation Policy in the Developing World [ES-2002/ POL-2069/ SOA-2226] [ES-2002/ POL-2069/ SOA-2226-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The contemporary world is beset with growing environmental problems. The global focus on economic growth and development has led us onto an unsustainable path: growing scientific evidence now suggests that the Earth may not be able to cope with the demands imposed on it. This has created an urgent need to critically examine complex environmental issues from a variety of perspectives. It is necessary to inculcate holistic thinking on environmental challenges and their purported solutions, that includes concerns of social and ecological sustainability. This course will discuss some of the most current concerns related to the environment, as well as societal responses to them, from a multidisciplinary perspective. Water scarcity, climate change, forest degradation, biological extinction, pollution and agrarian distress are some of the issues that will be studied. After the sessions on different environmental problems, students will be exposed to both top-down governmental responses (regulatory frameworks), disaster management, economic valuation of nature and bottom-up community responses, particularly environmental movements. This course is intended to engender a holistic perspective in understanding causes of environmental challenges and possible solutions through the lenses of science, economics and social equity.

This course will encourage students to synthesize information across a variety of sources. Practically the course will be taught using a combination of lectures, paper discussions, documentaries and  guest lectures. Discussion on assigned readings will engender critical thinking and debate in class. Students will undertake group projects on current case studies (such as river pollution, tiger tourism etc.). Assessments will be based on in-class tests, essays, critical summary writing and class participation. 

Course Topics (Each module=1.5 lecture-hour)

Module 1: Introduction to Contemporary Environmental Challenges The students will be introduced to contemporary environmental issues such as climate change, biological extinction, pollution, food security, waste, water scarcity and forest degradation. The concepts of social equity and ecological and economic sustainability will be introduced as ways of understanding environmental challenges globally and in developing societies such as India.

Module 2,3: Population Growth and Sustainability This module focuses on the relationship between population and the environment. Issues of population growth, stability, consumption patterns, demographic transition, coupled with human development challenges, social security, disease and scarcity will be addressed.

Module 4: Environment as a Commons This module explores the understanding of 'environment' as a common. If indeed it is difficult to set up exclusive access to the environment then what kind of challenges may one anticipate in sharing the environment as a common? The module expects the students to familiarize themselves with Hardin's argument wherein commons are understood to fail, thus qualifying as a tragedy. A counter to this argument is presented through Elinor Ostrom's work which argues for the possibility of successfully governing commons.

Module 5: Resource Scarcity at the Margins This module explores the relationship between poverty, and environmental degradation, asking the larger questions of who suffers the most from environmental problems and disasters, and who pays the price. Do the interests of biodiversity and human well-being necessarily coincide? This module delves into the forms of resource and environmental governance that exist. We revisit the critical role of commons and the varying implications of environmental governance for social-ecological sustainability of ecosystem-dependent livelihoods at the margins.

Module 6,7: Climate Change I : Science and Impacts In this module, the students will be introduced to the scientific debates on climate change and the symptoms and manifestations of global warming, which will be interpreted in context of climate history. The students will explore the impacts of climate change on agriculture, health, livelihoods and biodiversity, based on analysis of three short movies on climate-induced displacement.

Module 8,9: Climate Change II: Mitigation and Adaptation In this module, we discuss climate change mitigation and adaptation, particularly in the context of current international agreements and initiatives. We focus on the apparent inequities between the developed and developing world, and how these may affect the mitigative pathways being adopted, such as recent ‘net-zero’ commitments. There will be a focus on climate justice and carbon markets particularly in the context of the latest international negotiations on climate change at COP-26 held at Glasgow, 2020.

Module 10,11: Biodiversity Loss The students will be introduced to the causes and consequences of species extinction and ecosystem degradation from the scientific and socio-political perspectives. Varied paradigms of biological conservation in terms of their socio-economic, political and biological implications and impacts.

Module 12: Water Scarcity and Conservation Water, the source of all life, has become one of the most contentious issues on the planet. Growing scarcity and pollution of water, as well as the increasing unpredictability of floods and droughts, has necessitated a deeper look at the traditional strategies for water conservation, and how they can be revived.

Module 13: Water Bodies and their Governance Using Indian rivers and lakes as examples, we explore the complex interplay amongst religious traditions, local needs, governmental authority, policy-making and ecological factors in perpetuating water pollution and mismanagement, one of the major environmental issues we are living with. Break-out sessions, created around different stake-holder groups, will debate the problem of river pollution.

Module 14,15: Agrarian Crisis and Livelihoods The agrarian crisis in India has serious implications for rural livelihoods and food security. In this module, we explore the ecological and political perspectives on the abandonment of agriculture and declining productivity in India.

Module 16,17: Human-Wildlife Conflicts With growing degradation and fragmentation of natural habitats, and expansion of human settlements, conflict situations with wildlife are occurring more frequently, resulting in grievous human injury and losses. In this module, we explore the causes and consequences of such conflict from different perspectives- behavioural, economic and social. Students will be encouraged to apply the concept of environmental commons to conflict management.

Module 18: Development as Disaster ? A large number of environmental problems are created by large-scale industrial development and infrastructure that are undertaken without sufficient precautions. Thus it is necessary to explore the repercussions of the adopted development models for ecology and local livelihoods. We then explore the development processes and amelioratory laws and policies for environmental damage caused by infrastructural development in India.

Module 19,20: Governmental Responses: Environment Laws, Policies and Regulation This module explores the historical context of environmental law-making and implementation in India. The role of government in environmental conservation will be analysed by the students, through discussion on key environmental laws in India such as the Forest Conservation Act, Forest Rights Act, the Wildlife Protection Act and the Environmental Protection Act. Regulatory laws such as Environmental Impact Assessment and Coastal Zone Regulation will also be covered. The aim will be to explore not only the contours and details of these laws but also their implementation, as well as their impacts on society and biodiversity.

Module 21: Role of Local Government Local Governance is of utmost importance for environmental sustainability and conservation and rural well-being. Students will be introduced to local governmental mechanisms and institutions in India. The case study of Western Himalaya will be discussed based on the role of forest councils in environmental conservation.

Module 22,23 People’s response: Environmental Movements Environmental movements in India are significant for their grassroots base and role in highlighting (and resolving) growing resource conflicts, particularly in view of the visible contestation among rural communities, corporate sector and governments. Students will compare and contrast various environmental movements in India from the points of view of sustainability. Three landmark environmental movements will be discussed in class: Chipko Andolan, Ralegaon Siddhi and Narmada Bachao Andolan.

Module 24: Ecosystem Services and their Valuation Monetization of ecosystem services has emerged as one of the possible solutions for safe-guarding nature. We will discuss the concept of ecosystem services, their valuation and the potential of such understanding for conservation. The advantages and pitfalls of using this approach will be debated. The concept of green GDP will be introduced as a way to stem the degradation of ecosystem services globally.

Module 25, 26: Traditional Knowledge and the Environment Traditional knowledge has historically been the crucible for understanding and conservation of nature, which empowers indigenous communities and economies. It is important to explore the concept, as well as its applicability and usefulness for human well-being in modern times. Convention on Biological Diversity and Biological Diversity Act will be discussed in the context of safe-guarding indigenous people’s intellectual Property Rights. 

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will create an awareness of, and sensitivity to the complexities of contemporary environmental challenges
  • Students will learn to analyse environmental issues from a multidisciplinary perspective
  • Students will learn to think and write analytically about complex issues 
  • They will be taught to synthesize knowledge from different sources including scholarly papers, visual media and traditional knowledge.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Indicative Readings (full list to be updated):

1. Shahabuddin, G. and K. Sivaramakrishnan (Eds.) 2019. Nature in the New Economy, People, Wildlife and the Law in India. Orient Blackswan, Delhi.

2. Srinivasan, U. and N. Velho (Eds.) 2018. Conservation from the Margins. Orient Blackswan, Delhi.

3. Kothari, A. 2021. The Net-Zero Greenwash. Wall Street Journal, July 13, 2021. https://wsimag.com/economy-and-politics/66356-the-net-zero-greenwash

4. Nepstad,D. 2021. The Net-Zero Bridge to Saving the Amazon. Mongabay.com, November 3, 2021. https://news.mongabay.com/2021/11/the-net-zero-bridge to-saving-the-amazon-commentary/

5. Gadgil, M. 2023. A Walk up the Hill: Living with People and Nature. Penguin Random House, India.

6. Nagendra, H., & Mundoli, S. 2023. Shades of Blue: Connecting the Drops in India’s Cities. Penguin Random House, India.

7. Sharma, M. 2012. Green and Saffron, Hindu Nationalism and Indian Environmental Politics. Permanent Black & Ashoka University.

8. Guha, R. 2006. How Much Should a Person Consume? Thinking through the Environment. Chapter 2 (Pgs 67-90); Chapter 7 (Pgs 224-243); Permanent Black/Black Kite, Delhi

9. Plotkin, M.E. 1993. Tales of a Shaman’s Apprentice. Chapter 1: Through the Emerald Door (Pgs 1-18); Chapter 3: Among the Maroons (Pgs 53 80).Penguin, USA

10. Nabhan, G.P. 1997. Cultures of Habitat, On Nature, Culture and Story. Chapter 4 (Pgs. 209-223). Counterpoint, Washington DC, USA.

11. Ghosh, A. 2019. Disastrous delta: Daily struggles against nature in the Sunderbans. Pp. 29-36 In. Ghosh, A. (Ed.). The Tides of Life: Surviving Between the Margins. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts, India.

12. Mahmud, S. 2019. Adapting to change in the Sunderbans ecosystems: Lay people’s perceptions. Pp. 129-141 In. Ghosh, A. (Ed.). The Tides of Life: Surviving Between the Margins. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts, India

13. Baviskar A. 2020. Uncivil City: Ecology, Equity and the Commons in Delhi. Sage Publications and Yoda Press, India.

14. Richard, A. 2022. The Sloth Lemur’s Song, Madagascar from the Deep Past to the Uncertain Present. William Collins.

15. Rangarajan, M. 2015. Nature and Nation: Essays on Environmental History. Chapter 5: Striving for a Balance: Nature, Power, Science and India’s Indira

Elliptic Curves and Cryptography [MAT-4030] [MAT-4030-1]

Faculty Name
Chandan Singh Dalawat [chandan.dalawat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Elliptic curves are one of the central objects of mathematics. They arise quite naturally and somewhat unexpectedly in many different areas. 

In this course we will be mostly concerned with arithmetic aspects of elliptic curves. Thus, our curves will be defined over finite fields, or local fields, or number fields.  These different kinds of fields will be defined and studied.  We will also define projective spaces in which our elliptic curves live.

We will make a preliminary study of the arithmetic of conics, which are much simpler than elliptic curves.  It turns out that the hilbertian symbol which arises naturally in the study of conics is crucial for the method of descent on elliptic curves.

The presentation of the material will be very concrete, with many examples and exercises.  The content will be tailored to the background of the students.  

Notes of most lectures will be provided.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn that elliptic curves carry a natural group law, and that this group is finitely generated when the base field is the field of rational numbers.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

A basic course in algebra.

courseTitle: Writing About Watching a Film: Being a film critic
description:
Writing About Watching a Film: Being a film critic [MS-2451] [MS-2451-1]

Faculty Name
Tisha Srivastav [tisha.srivastav@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

MS 2451 Writing about watching a film: Being a Film Critic

This course is a reading media course on film. Students do extensive readings in 2/3rds of the course on how media represents film in the history of cinema, with examples from both global and Indian cinemas and they study the work of film criticism. Media representation across cartoons, newspapers, magazines, even school text books are looked at. In the rest of 1/3rd of the course, they look at the emerging media form of the video essay and how that interacts with both film editing and helps paves the way for the short video form, prominent currently.

This course looks at film criticism from the media end and explores it through the newspaper writings of a film critic and the video essay media form. The course may include a workshop with a film reviewer from the Indian media industries.

Learning Outcomes

While there are NO prerequisites, all students with a demonstrated interest in understanding film, popular culture, media or visual storytelling (beyond I like this, I like that) are welcome. Students who have done film, visual arts, psychology and creative writing courses are particularly welcome.

This course will teach you how to write film reviews in various media forms. It will do so by using media writing on film. The course will also provide fundamental clues into ways of watching potent moving images and understanding cinema as a medium of entertainment, communication and representation of ‘reality’.Through studying the writings from media sources and forms, students will learn to think about film reviewing, movie going culture, mass and critical eye, media spaces and practice writing reviews/ making one video essay. The course will also introduce you to lesser known online resources for watching and thinking about film and popular culture in India. From archives to YouTube links.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You will be required to watch two short videos (Note: Not long movies, which will only happen once in the entire course) each week in the first month. Links along with short readings, will be put week on week. Expect class discussion, individual writing and group work.


WEEK ON WEEK BREAK UP (Week 1-7):

Week 1-4 

How cinema going was represented in popular media forms in its  early years

Silent cinema's 'working class' star

Basic building blocks of visual & cinematic literacy

Newspaper film review of American critic Pauline Kael

Practicing film writing for an audience

Clear feedback from best examples of weekly assignment submissions

Week 1

Class 1: Nickelodeons & movie-going at the turn of 20th century America – Popular culture media representations

Class 2: The state, shipping immigrants & ‘silent’ Chaplin.

Week 2 

Class 1: Official American documentation at Ellis Island, betrayal & The Godfather 2.

Class 2: Immigrant to Gangster – America & Kael Godfather 2 review.

Week 3 

Class 1: Class 1 Imitation of life – B&W friendship & the women in film in Early Hollywood

Class 2 Introduction to Pauline Kael as film critic (in video & essay)

Week 4  

Class 1: Learning from Kael's Godfather 2 Review & in-class media writing exercise.

Class 2: Kael’s writing on Clint Eastwood, Violence & Fascism in America.

Week 5

Class 1 In class reviewing exercise

Class 2 Watching and reviewing a popular culture documentary

Week 6

Class 1 Guest Lecture - Film Heritage Foundation of India

Class 2 Feedback session & assignment queries

Mid term break

Week 8-11 classes will look at the video essay form as a media form example of film criticism in popular cultures. 

Week 12 

Class 1: Video essay pitch 1

Class 2 : Video essay Pitch contd

Week 13-14 - Video essay production

Topics in Indian Philosophy [PHI-3400] [PHI-3400-1]

Overview

Experience in Indian Philosophy

This course interrogates the extent to which modern concepts of ‘experience’ can illuminate or distort some important Indian philosophical sources and ideas. We will accordingly be learning about relevant Indian and non-Indian philosophy simultaneously so that students can develop nuanced and well-rounded perspectives on the former. Philosophy of science will have a particularly significant presence due to the importance of science in informing modern ideas about experience and the ways in which people project (rightly or wrongly) those ideas onto earlier Indian sources.

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course, students will have reflected on

  • various topics in Indian philosophy to which the concept of experience is highly relevant,
  • the ways in which distinctly modern notions of experience can influence our understanding of classical Indian sources,
  • and the extent to which various aspects of Indian philosophy may be said to be ‘scientific’.

In each case, students will be able to identify, evaluate, and produce arguments connected to the relevant philosophical literature.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Assignments

Exam: There will be a two-hour exam in which you must produce two short essays. You will choose two (from a selection of about eight) questions and give a critical, reasoned response to each one. The topics appearing in the exam questions (but not the questions’ exact content and wording) will be made known to you before teaching is concluded.

The exam will be handwritten. Exceptions can be made for those with accessibility concerns.

Essay: You will be required to write an essay of around at least 2000 words in response to a prompt that will be given at the beginning of the course.

Student-led sessions: Once per week, a student or students will present on a selection from one of the suggested readings. There are no strict rules about these presentations except that they should explain the content of the selection and give the presenters’ reflections on it. The point is less to have a polished piece of work and more to give students the opportunity to lead the discussion of some literature. Slides or handouts are not required or expected, but would be welcome. This presentation will influence your participation grade.

Force and Motion in Biology [BIO-3454/ BIO-4454/ PHY-4454] [BIO-3454/ BIO-4454/ PHY-4454-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Modern biology is changing rapidly, and it has become unimaginable to teach biology in silos without discussing the underlying physical and chemical processes. One of the main precepts behind this course is to discuss and analyze the physical concepts underlying biological phenomena. This elective course is aimed at students who wish to understand how physical principles governing molecular interactions come together during biological processes. The course will begin with simple order-of-magnitude estimates in biology. We will then move on to the basic quantifiable physical properties of biomolecules. We will then discuss the application of principles of physics to complex biological systems

Learning Outcomes

Key Outcomes will be,

1. Use quantitative reasoning to describe processes such as diffusion, forces at the molecular scale, and during molecular interactions.

2. Interpret and analyze biophysical data from experiments (e.g., optical microscopy, force extension curves).

3. Develop problem-solving and critical-thinking skills to connect physical laws with real biological phenomena, from molecular motors to cell mechanics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Though not mandatory, participants in this course are expected to have taken introductory courses in Cell Biology and Molecular Biology.

description:
Observing the Cosmos [PHY-1080/ AST-1080] [PHY-1080/ AST-1080-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Somak Raychaudhury [somak.raychaudhury@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a hands-on laboratory course with both indoor and outdoor experiments.  Students are given training to handle an optical telescope and a radio telescope, a theodolite, a sextant and other related equipment.  They measure the temperature of the Sun and several other bright stars, learn how to measure distances using parallax and how to infer the latitude and longitude of a location from the position of stars.  Experiments involving important techniques used regularly in Astronomy, including astrophotography, photometry, emission and absorption spectroscopy and the study of Doppler effect, are performed.   The experiments include the measurement of the hyperfine spectral transition of hydrogen, the most abundant element, using a homemade radio telescope.

Learning Outcomes

1. Learning to navigate the sky and recognising different celestial bodies.
2. Learning to use and calibrate telescopes and other associated equipment.
3. Learning various methods of astronomical measurements
4. Developing computing skills for data processing

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended reading:
Experiment handouts and associated material will be provided.
The following books can be consulted as peripheral references:
1. Observational Astronomy, D. Scott Birney, G. Gonzalez and D. Oesper, Cambridge University Press
2. A Practical Guide to Observational Astronomy, M. Shane Burns, CRC Press

The Violent Universe [PHY-3860/ AST-3860] [PHY-3860/ AST-3860-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

Violent phenomena like energetic explosions, jet-like ejection of matter or sudden collapse of stars are very common in the Universe.  These phenomena play a key role in controlling the energetics of gas in galaxies and the synthesis and dispersal of heavy elements.   Of late, major emphasis has been placed globally on the study of such events and new information is emerging rapidly.  This course will acquaint the student with the physical processes associated with these violent events and the wealth of information that can be gleaned from them about the evolution of the universe.

Syllabus:

1. Introduction to violent phenomena - explosions, implosions, ejections, jets - Big Bang, Novae, Supernovae, Gamma Ray Bursts, Solar Flares, Pulsars, Magnetars, Fast Radio Bursts, Accreting compact objects, Active Galactic Nuclei.

2. Loss of Hydrostatic Equilibrium - Gravitational energy - Explosions and Implosions - Thermodynamic and Thermonuclear instability - Magnetospheric phenomena -  relevant time scales

3. Collisions of planets, stars, galaxies and clusters; supernova remnants, Gamma Ray Burst afterglows; Radio Galaxies and Quasars

4. Generation of Electromagnetic radiation, Gravitational Waves and Explosive Nucleosynthesis in violent events.

5. Cosmological impact of violent events

Learning Outcomes

1 Developing familiarity with energetic cosmic phenomena

2. Understanding the diverse physical processes associated with violent cosmic events

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites (desirable): Physical science at the std XI-XII level, FCs on QRMT and PoS

Recommended reading:

1. High Energy Astrophysics, M. Longair, Cambridge University Press

2. Violent Phenomena in the Universe, J.V. Narlikar, Dover

description:
Astrophysical and Geophysical Fluid Dynamics [PHY-4871/ AST-4871/ PHY-6871] [PHY-4871/ AST-4871/ PHY-6871-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

Fluid dynamics is at the heart of most  Astrophysical phenomena, and many of these processes have close parallels in Geophysics.  In this course the fluid dynamical principles will be introduced with specific applications to Astrophysical and Geophysical problems.  The topics covered will include hydrostatic equilibrium, accretion flows, shock waves, radiative gas dynamics and magnetohydrodynamics.

Syllabus:

Continuity, Euler and Navier-Stokes equations, Compressible and Incompressible fluids; Potential flows; Effect of rotation - cyclones and climate systems; Gasdynamics in gravitational field - Hydrostatic Equilibrium, Virial Theorem, Accretion flows; Shock Waves, Radiative Hydrodynamics; Induction equation and introduction to MHD - Terrestrial and Astrophysical Dynamos.

Learning Outcomes

The student will learn to appreciate the wide variety of contexts where the physics of fluids play an essential role in governing phenomena in both terrestial contexts and the Univere at large.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Classical Mechanics, Electromagnetism in the Light of Relativity

Recommended reading:

1. The Physics of Fluids and Plasmas - An introduction for Astrophysicists, Arnab Rai Choudhuri, Cambridge University Press

2. An introduction to Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics, M.J. Thompson, World Scientific

3. Astrophysical Magnetic Fields, A. Shukurov and K. Subramanian, Cambridge University Press

4. Fundamentals of Geophysical Fluid Dynamics, J.C. McWilliams, Cambridge University Press

courseTitle: Wealth and Inequality in China (1500 to the Present)
description:
Wealth and Inequality in China (1500 to the Present) [CHI-3002/ HIS-3511/ SOA-3110] [CHI-3002/ HIS-3511/ SOA-3110-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

 

Among the most vivid images of China’s modern history have been the extremes of decadent imperial courts and starving peasants. China’s sixteenth-century commercial revolution, in the context of the growing international trade in silver, transformed social and cultural life in every corner of society. Since then, arguments about the distribution of resources and the proper remedy for inequality have been central to political and social movements, especially during the twentieth century. In this course we will examine the economic bases of income inequality in Chinese history, investigate strategies Chinese governments and individuals have used to mitigate rural and urban poverty, and come to appreciate how these economic realities affected people at all levels of Chinese society. Wealth and poverty were experienced differently according to factors including (but not limited to) gender, age, level of education, disability, sexuality, ethnicity, and location. We will read primary sources which illuminate a wide range of perspectives and consider, in conversation with the secondary literature, how to synthesise these materials. The written assessment for this class will be a writing portfolio including that will build towards developing expertise on a single Chinese region or locality. It addition to an annotated bibliography, it will include a research paper or storymap (other final project options may be considered).

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prior knowledge of Chinese history is required for this class. A full syllabus will be circulated a week before classes start.

Introduction to Electronics [PHY-3850/ PHY-4850/ PHY-6850] [PHY-3850/ PHY-4850/ PHY-6850-1]

Faculty Name
Susmita Saha [susmita.saha@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Our day-to-day life highly depends on electronic devices. Hence, studying electronics has become more important than ever. In this introductory course on electronics, we aim to study semiconductors and their applications in analog and digital electronics.  This course will be taught in a hybrid mode, where there will be both theory classes as well as six laboratory experiments based on the theories taught in the class.

 Theory:

Introduction with semiconductors, P and N type semiconductors, P-N junction diodes, Band structures of P-N junction diode and their applications

Bi-polar junction transistor (CB, CE, CC modes) and their characteristics. Applications of transistors, Amplifier

Field effect transistor

Operational amplifiers (Op-AMP) and their applications as integrator, differentiator, voltage comparator, rectifier, Schmidt Trigger etc.

Number system, Boolean algebra, Logic gates, Universal gates, Adders, Flip-flops, counters

Experiment:

Characteristics of a diode

Applications of Op-Amp as integrator, differentiator, inverter, Schmidt trigger

The truth tables of all gates, formation of universal gates by using NAND and NOR, half adder, full adder, half subtractor, Flip-Flop.

 

References:

Integrated Electronics by Millman and Halkias

Electronic devices and circuit theory by Boylestad and Nashelsky (for the analog electronics part)

Basic Electronics principals and applications by Saha, Halder and Ganguly

Electronics by Chatterjee and Rakshit

Learning Outcomes

The students will get know about the basic electronics, in both experiemnt and theoretical perspective

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Basic Knowledge of Mathematics and Physics

Indian Literatures [ENG-2003] [ENG-2003-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces students to modern Indian literatures in English translation. We will be discussing the works of Rabindranath Tagore, Premchand, Intizar Hussain, Ambai, Kiran Nagarkar, U R Ananthamurthy, Vaikom Muhammad Bashir and Indira Goswami among others. We will also be screening film adaptations of the key works of some of these authors. The course will pay special attention to such movements in Indian literature as the Progressive Writers movement and regional modernisms. We shall be exploring the questions of caste, class, gender and nation in Indian literatures and study different genres such as the novel, short story and poetry. The theorists and critics we will read, in order to situate our discussion of Indian literature in a wider historical, political and theoretical context, include Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, Walter Benjamin, Gilles Deleuze, Shamsur Rahman Faruqi and G.N.Devy. Is there an “Indian” literature? What is the relation between modern literatures in Indian languages and the forms of the nation? What are the theoretical and political stakes in the debate(s) on realism and modernism in Indian literatures? How do we think the idea of a ‘comparative literature’ in relation to Indian literatures? How do we approach the politics and ethics of translation in the situation opened up by translations from and between Indian languages? These are some of the questions we will address in this course.
