description:
Reading Psychoanalytic Writing [ENG-4812] [ENG-4812-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What makes psychoanalytic writing psychoanalytic?  With equally hovering attention on language, form, and theoretical content, this class will grapple with the work of psychoanalytic writers from a few different schools, geographies, and time periods writing on diverse topics such as the body, art, violence, mourning and the clinic. Amongst others, we will read: Sigmund Freud, D.W. Winnicott, Masud Khan, Osaumu Kitayama, Melanie Klein, Otto Rank and Octave Mannoni. As we read, we will discuss how and to what extent the concepts we read about translate from the language of psychoanalysis into the language of literary English, and from the clinic into other human experiences.

courseTitle: Is There A Modern Indian Literature?
description:
Is There A Modern Indian Literature? [ENG-4405/ CW-4405] [ENG-4405/ CW-4405-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Prakash Chaudhuri [amit.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

I will use the Picador Book of Modern Indian Literature and a few other texts for this course, and also bring in cinema, art, and music as important entry-points into the 'modernity' I'm discussing here. The aim is to free pedagogy, reading, and creative-critical interaction with both Indian and European texts from the interpretative parameters of  'Western modernity', while also rejecting categories like 'non-Western modernity' that serve a merely corrective purpose. Instead, I wish to enquire afresh into the journey of literary and artistic modernity, using writing from India as my starting-point. I also plan to bring in some material from outside India – the stories of Junichiro Tanizaki, for instance.  The question in the course title is one I asked myself as I began putting together the anthology I mention above in the late 1990s. How was one to conceive of a tradition called 'Indian literature'? Was it the total of the various literatures of India? Or was there another way of exploring this category? It was a time when the Indian novel in English and the idea of 'postcolonial literature' had begun to dominate. How did the modernist and avant garde trajectories of literatures in the Indian languages fit into these relatively recent categorisations? One of my own reasons for rethinking and enlarging the frame had to do with my affinities with modernism as a reader and writer, affinities that seemed out of place post-Midnight's Children, but not so out of place within the experimental histories of modern Indian literatures themselves. 

The use of the word 'modern' was, and is, deliberate, to point to developments that the term 'postcolonial' doesn't address. The texts we'll read here would follow, without too much narrow systematising, ‘Indian literature’ and the way its emergence from the late nineteenth century in various languages embodied the trajectory of modernity, modernism, the avant garde, and formal preoccupations in India. The course means to question the largely theme-driven, Anglophone parameters of the ‘postcolonial’ that have been with us for some decades now.

Overview

The Publishing Workshop aims to work with the students to hone their skills at editing their own writing to develop it into a publishable manuscript as well as to have a clear understanding of how their writing would be received by the publishing ecosystem. The pedagogy will include both hands-on exercises and presentations of the students' work.

Students must have their thesis first draft ready when the semester begins. Without that it is very difficult to proceed through the semester.

The Publishing Seminar aims to equip you with the tools to editor-proof your writing and make it ready for submission for publication.

Please note that without a first draft, which will need to be uploaded into a folder shared by the TA in the first week of the semester itself, you might be faced with an early grade cut. The creative component should be there in full, while for the critical component of the thesis, there should at least be a detailed outline.

courseTitle: In Situ: Architecture, Sculpture and Painting in the Western Himalayas
description:
In Situ: Architecture, Sculpture and Painting in the Western Himalayas [VA-3014/ SOA-3104/ HIS-3813] [VA-3014/ SOA-3104/ HIS-3813-1]

Faculty Name
Latika Gupta [latika.gupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Code: VA-3014/ SOA-3104/ HIS-3813-1
Level: 1000/2000/3000
Prerequisites: None

Course Description:

This course is an introduction to the architecture, sculpture and paintings of Buddhist temples and monasteries in the Western Himalayas, with a focus on extant sites in Western Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh. We will study major sites of art historical and cultural importance, while tracing their roots and interconnections to developments in art, religion, and aesthetics in Kashmir and Eastern India. The course focuses on studying monasteries and temples through their geographical location and landscape, their usage, and changes in structure and style in response to religious and socio-political developments as well as changes in local ecological conditions. The artistic strategies employed, the material used in making paintings and sculptures will be explored in relation to their geographic, architectonic and spatial contexts as well as the ritual requirements.

The sites we will study include early stone temples and sculptures in the Kashmir Valley, mammoth rock cut sculptures in Ladakh, major early monastery complexes in Western Tibet, Ladakh and Spiti including Tholing, Tabo, Nyarma and Alchi. We will also study smaller temples such as Ribba, Roba and Nako in Kinnaur (Himachal Pradesh), Sumda and Mangyu in Ladakh. We will undertake a detailed study of courtly material culture depicted in the paintings, along with a focus on textiles as an intrinsic part of Buddhist sacred spaces.

Following an interdisciplinary methodology, we will learn about processes through which lands and sites are recognised as being sacred and the centrality of pilgrimage in practice; we will consider how places are experienced through the senses; how do light, colour, smell and sound create affective ways of inhabiting sites; what is the relationship of a body to a sacred place? The course emphasises the importance and processes of place-making through history, mythology and local belief systems, and how these impact the relationship of communities with places. We will also study the transformations that occur when sacred material culture is moved from sites of usage in the Himalayas to museum contexts.

The course includes field trips to contemporary Buddhist sites and museum galleries in Delhi: (1) Shanti Stupa; (2) Buddhist temples at Majnu-ka-Tilla (3) Buddhist galleries at the National Museum, including the Buddha's relics display.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students:

  • Will be familiar with the basic history of the development of Buddhism and Buddhist cosmological concepts and how and why these are translated into architecture, sculpture and paintings.
  • Will be able to identify major deities of the ‘Tibetan’ Buddhist pantheon and identify iconographic and stylistic features of early Himalayan Buddhist art.
  • Will be conversant with major Buddhist temples and monasteries in Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh, as well as early sites in the Kashmir Valley.
  • Will have the ability to ‘read’ the architectural layout, structure and form of sites, and study the architecture, sculptures and paintings in relation to their usage.
  • Will be familiar with developments in the art of the region in conjunction with changes in religion and socio-political contexts of patronage.

courseTitle: Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures
description:
Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413] [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

The written assessment for this class will build towards a final research paper on a topic of the students' choice.

 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prior knowledge of Chinese history is required for this class. A full syllabus will be circulated the week before classes start.

Quantum Mechanics 2 [PHY-3520/ PHY-4520] [PHY-3520/ PHY-4520-1]

Faculty Name
Somendra Mohan Bhattacharjee [somendra.bhattacharjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is a continuation of Quantum Mechanics I (QM1), focusing on advanced concepts and approximation methods in quantum mechanics. Topics include addition of agular momenta, entanglement, Bell’s inequalities, Berry’s phase, and topological problems such as the Aharonov–Bohm effect and a particle on a ring. The course also examines the role of symmetry, the behavior of identical particles, and the density matrix formalism.

Learning Outcomes

Students will develop familiarity with quantum mechanical concepts and results at an advanced level and gain an understanding of some of the paradoxical aspects of quantum mechanics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prereq: QM1 is essential.

description:
Linear Algebra [MAT-1001/ CS-2210] [MAT-1001/ CS-2210-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Ghosh [sourav.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course we will study the following topics: Real and complex vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation.  Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinant. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

Learning Outcomes

Analyze and picturize multivariate data.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Friedberg, Insel and Spence: Linear algebra, Pearson, 2015.
  • K. Hoffman and R. Kunze: Linear algebra, Prentice-Hall, Second edition, 1971.

courseTitle: Dharma, kingship and violence in ancient India
description:
Dharma, kingship and violence in ancient India [HIS-3217] [HIS-3217-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Dharma and nonviolence are often considered central moral precepts in the Indian tradition. But how did they acquire this exalted status? Was dharma universal and unchanging, or did it depend on class, caste, gender and the climate of the times? Was nonviolence considered in absolute or contextual terms? Were dharma and nonviolence supposed to be guiding principles for rulers, or could they be jettisoned in the ruthless pursuit of power? This course examines the debates on such questions through a close analysis of texts, inscriptions and visual sources of ancient and early medieval India. The main focus is on the intersection of political ideas and practice, with special reference to the state’s relationship with punishment, war, and the forest. The place of gendered violence and the hidden discourse on resistance and rebellion will also be discussed. The old debates on the fine dividing line between legitimate force and illegitimate violence, between righteous rule and oppressive tyranny open a window into an exciting and complex world of ideas that are relevant even in our own time.

 

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn to think critically about the history of ethical and political ideas in early India and about the intersection between political theory and practice. They will also learn how to engage with a variety of important texts from early India.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Cosmic Messengers 1 (Theory) [AST-3870/ AST-4870/ PHY-3870/ PHY-4870] [AST-3870/ AST-4870/ PHY-3870/ PHY-4870-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces to the student how cosmic objects can be studied using various messengers, such as electromagnetic waves at a wide variety of bands,  gravitational waves and various energetic particles.  The course describes how these different signals originate, how they are detected, what information they carry and how to interpret them.
------
Syllabus: 
Overview of Cosmic messengers: Electromagnetic radiation-Neutrinos-Gravitational waves-Cosmic rays-Atmospheric limitations-Ground based versus Space observatories-Coherent versus incoherent detection.
Radiative transfer-Black Body radiation- Optical telescopes-detectors-noise and statistics-photometry-X-ray and Gamma-ray telescopes- Observations of Stars, galaxies, GRBs in continuum.
Bohr Model-Hydrogen atom-Lyman and Balmer series-Optical spectroscopy-Probing star formation, high redshift galaxies-absorption line systems.
 Radiation from moving charges - Bremsstrahlung, Synchrotron and Compton processes-Thermal vs non-thermal radiation - Acceleration of relativistic particles - polarisation from Synchrotron emission and Compton scattering - self-absorption
Radio telescopes-Single dish-Radio interferometers-aperture synthesis-image reconstruction-Probing radio galaxies, quasars, black holes, CMB-coherent emission from pulsars- 21 cm line from galaxies and the EOR- Molecular lines and cold gas
Neutrino detection-Solar and supernova neutrinos-neutrino oscillations-cosmic neutrinos from the Early Universe
Cosmic Ray detectors-highest energy cosmic rays-origin
Gravitational wave detectors-Quadrupole formula-LIGO detections-detecting black holes and neutron star mergers-Stochastic backgrounds as probe of supermassive black holes and early universe

Learning Outcomes

The student will learn to appreciate the messengers and tools astronomers use to observe and understand the diverse phenomena that occur in the universe. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: PHY/AST-2850: “Physics of the Universe” [desirable]; exposure to Electricity and Magnetism and basic Quantum Theory.

Recommended Reading:
1. Astrophysical Techniques, C.R. Kitchin, IoP publishing

2. Astronomy Methods, Hale Bradt, Cambridge University Press

3. High Energy Astrophysics, Malcolm Longair, Cambridge University Press

4. Radiative Processes in Astrophysics, G.W. Rybicki and A.P. Lightman, Wiley

5. Gravitational Waves vol I, Theory and Experiments, M. Maggiore,  Oxford University Press

6. Physics of the Interstellar and Intergalactic Medium, B.T. Draine,  Princeton UniversityPress

Overview


This course will introduce students to the basics of drawing comics and graphic narratives, with a focus on lived experiences, drawing as reportage and graphic journalism. With a hands-on practice based approach, it will explore multiple formats of bringing together image, text, cut outs, collective story building and book making, while consistently raising questions about how visual narratives are shaped by us and around us, their hierarchies in production and circulation, and the politics of representation, especially in drawing comics. It will also offer students the opportunity to critically examine key works in the medium of graphic nonfiction, from India and around the world, so as to have a broad understanding of contemporary graphic narratives and learn the different ways the medium has been adapted and moulded, overtime.

Tango [CPA-0083] [CPA-0083-1]

Overview

An Argentine Tango course teaches the fundamentals of the social partner dance, focusing on posture, balance, walking, connection, and the roles of leading and following to enable improvisation and expression within a harmonious embrace. Students learn basic steps and movements, often in a salon style, to develop non-verbal communication skills and experience the culture, history, and music of tango. Courses are suitable for all genders and experience levels.

Key Course Content
Fundamentals: Posture, balance, weight changes, and comfortable walking are foundational.
Connection & Embrace: Learning the proper embrace and developing a harmonious connection with a partner is central to the dance.
Leading & Following: Students learn to understand and respond to a partner's signals, practicing both roles in the dance.
Steps & Movement: Basic steps, pivots, and turns are taught, emphasizing the social rather than theatrical style of tango.
Musicality: Developing the ability to move in time with tango music is a key aspect.
Culture & Etiquette: Courses introduce the history, music, and etiquette of the Argentine tango social scene.

Advanced Game Theory [ECO-6106] [ECO-6106-1]

Faculty Name
Ratul Lahkar [ratul.lahkar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This will be a course on evolutionary game theory. Evolutionary game theory seeks to provide foundations to Nash equilibrium by weakening some of the rules of rationality. The primary focus of study would be when and under what conditions will a society consisting of a large number of agents converge to Nash equilibrium behaviour. The course will be broadly divided into two parts. In the first part, we will cover the fundamentals of evolutionary game theory. This part will introduce students to large population games and different evolutionary dynamics used in this field of game theory. The second part will be based on the instructor’s research and will cover various applications of the theory including oligopoly, public goods provision, problems of social coordination, implementation theory and evolution of preferences.

 

Learning Outcomes

1. Learn the fundamentals of evolutionary game theory.

2. Population games and examples like potential games and negative definite games.

3. Evolutionary Dynamics and notions of evolutionary stability of Nash equilibrium.

4. Mathematical background of evolutionary game theory.

5. Applications like oligopoly, public goods provision, problems of social coordination, implementation theory and evolution of preferences.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course will be based on my notes. For background reading, I suggest

Population Games and Evolutionary Dynamics by William H. Sandholm (MIT Press).

description:
Aesthetics in International Relations [IR-2052] [IR-2052-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course aims to open up knowledge practices from sites and positions that are usually not immediately addressed or recognized in mainstream debates in International Relations. International Relations is also enacted and performed through various mediums such as popular culture, films, literature, music, art, paintings, museums, sports, etc. The course will enable the students to look
at the two-way relationship between aesthetics and international politics − both shaping and structuring the other. It will also underline that aesthetics and its deployments are deeply political acts and not value-neutral. The course will simultaneously familiarise students with conceptual and methodological tools drawn from different fields to understand the art and craft of international politics by other means. In doing so it explores what counter imaginations may exist to conventional disciplinary understandings regarding statehood, citizenship, borders and boundaries, violence, development, human rights, social change and subjectivity as well as what new political horizons and alternative modes of scholarly engagement might unfold from them.

Bioinorganic Chemistry [CHM-3201] [CHM-3201-1]

Faculty Name
Munmun Ghosh [munmun.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Introductory Bioinorganic Chemistry

Introduction to Bioinorganic Chemistry; fundamentals about the electronic and molecular structure of coordination complexes; Inorganic elements in biological systems, introductory cell biology, biologically relevant compounds: amino acids, proteins, nucleotides, carbohydrates, and lipids; Biochemistry: distribution, biological roles, storage, and transport of cations across membranes, sodium pump, calcium carriers, role in muscle contraction

Electron transfer proteins involving Iron, Cobalt, Copper

Active site structure and functions of ferredoxin, rubredoxin and cytochromes, and their comparisons; Vitamin B12 (Cobalt) & B12 coenzymes and their model compounds; O2 binding properties of heme (haemoglobin and myoglobin) and non-heme proteins (hemocyanin & hemerythrin), their coordination geometry and electronic structure, co-operativity effect, binding of CO to Myoglobin, Hemoglobin, and their model compounds; Study of Hemocyanin, tyrosinase, superoxide dismutase, dopamine-b-hydroxylase, catechol oxidase (Copper)

Metals in medicine (MIM)

Therapeutic applications of cis-platin, transition metal radioisotopes (example: Tc, Co and Cu etc.) and MRI (Mn and Fe) agents; Superoxide Dismutase Mimics, Vanadium-Based Diabetes, Copper Toxicity; Diagnostic agents (Gadolinium MRI Imaging Agents); Drugs Toxicity of metals - Cd, Hg.

Learning Outcomes

Know the various applications of metals in life related process.

Bioinorganic Chemistry is an interdisciplinary subject and has grown interest in Chemistry, Biology, and medicine. This course will teach you various applications of metals in nature and in our daily life.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks:

1. S. J. Lippard & J. M. Berg. Principles of Bioorganic Chemistry, Panima Publ. Corpn. (2005).

2. S. J. Lippard. Progress in Inorganic Chemistry: Bioinorganic Chemistry, Vol. 38, John Wiley, (1990).

3. R. M. Roat-Malone, Bioinorganic Chemistry: A Short Course, Wiley (2002)

courseTitle: Studies in Literature and Film: Existentialism in Literature, Philosophy and Film
description:
Studies in Literature and Film: Existentialism in Literature, Philosophy and Film [ENG-3370] [ENG-3370-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What does it mean to be a human being? What is human freedom? How do we make sense of and give meaning to our existence? These are some of the questions taken up by theistic and atheistic existentialist philosophy, literature, and film, which we will study in this course. While existentialism is often studied in a European context, this course approaches existentialism as a global movement tracing its trajectory beyond its beginnings in Europe to the Americas, Middle East, South Asia and East Asia. We will be studying texts by philosophers such as Soren Kierkegaard, Friedrich Nietzsche, Jean-Paul Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir and Simone Weil as well as texts by writers such as Fyodor Dostoyevsky, Franz Kafka, Albert Camus, V.S.Naipaul and Nirmal Verma.

courseTitle: Letters to self : Cinema as therapy
description:
Letters to self : Cinema as therapy [CVA-0084] [CVA-0084-1]

Overview

Letters to self: Cinema as therapy


Hold the camera and you become the subject, whatever we film is a reflection of our understanding of the world. We can be curious to know the world around us by looking at this viewfinder, still this image creation is never purely observational or objective. It's a very unique and personal view over the things we choose to capture/exhibit.

Who am I ?
How do I feel?
Does it hurt?
Does it heal?
What I look at, when I look at myself

In this creative documentary course, Letters to self : Cinema as therapy, we dive into the art of storytelling through the lens of self and others, and explore the relation of turning the camera on self and other discovering how the both approaches hold the mirror to the human experience of our innermost feelings. The course looks at the image and sound design through the concept of a “scene” and how to craft it, why we need to create it, how to give it a cinematic language to capture our expression. Throughout the course there will be a series of exercises and film screenings revolving around “Personal is Universal” which encourages students to think critically, investigate their own perspectives and engage in self reflection.

description:
Mayurbhanj Chhau: Martial Dance [CPA-0089] [CPA-0089-1]

Overview

In this course there will be an emphasis on learning the basic movement vocabulary of mayurbhanj chhau ,a martial dance form from Mayurbhanj in Odisha. The movements, said to be based on observations of flora and fauna as well as daily village chores,require a combination of various dance skills.These skills are strength,fluidity and balance.The course will introduce the students to all three of these aspects in equal measure.After the exploration of comparatively small units of dance,these units will also be tried out in longer sequences. In addition to the physical practice of the dance, social and historical aspects of the dance and how they influenced the particular aesthetic of chhau will also be discussed

description:
Nature and Nation [HIS-3034/ ES-3020/ POL-3042/ SOA-3058] [HIS-3034/ ES-3020/ POL-3042/ SOA-3058-1]

Faculty Name
Mahesh Rangarajan [mahesh.rangarajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Nature and nation explores the changing relationships of nature and nationalisms mainly in the 20th century world.  Even though nation states are modern entities they often claim ancient lineage not only in language or culture but also with reference to a mountain, a tree, a river or an animal.  The symbolic importance of natural entities apart, these are also subject of contest nowhere perhaps as evident as in the way around 1900 the very classes that had almost hunted the bison to extinction in the US became its protectors. Why did this change occur and was it a sign of a new kind of nationalism. The latter could include as well as exclude and it is no coincidence that the bison parks and the Indian reservations came about within the same decade.

Nature also is important for nation states to generate more wealth and this competition between them is a major driving force of environmental change in today’s world. Yet as with previous empires, Ottoman, French or British empires do attempt also to regulate nature and its use and abuse. Who speaks for nature how and why is itself worth careful study.  This paper offers opportunity to look in comparative ways for instance at how capitalist and communist states, dictatorships and democracies have approached the problem of nature. Often as in post-apartheid South Africa, the legacies of the past and the racial divide remain important as parks game and wildlife mattered hugely to the white minority who governed till 1994. How does nature confer legitimacy and in what ways?

This course takes special effort to look at societies often outside our gaze but subject to in depth research, such as Russia, China and Vietnam, Brazil as well as Scotland, Germany and France. An individual book review by each student with a short class talk is a must though it bear emphasis there will be due consideration we will use the particular case to approach general themes. 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of term each of you will be able to think about this question in an original way.

Why, when and how nature comes to matter to what a nation means and to whom is a critical issue in today's world: in this sense this course could be of value to any student today.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading list

These are among the books that could be reviewed.

Sections will be pre assigned either to class as a whole or to groups of five and we will debate why the piece matters and what insights it provides. Given the breadth of the paper, no student is expected to read all these books ( though you are encouraged to read widely). The excerpts and papers from journals will be shared in soft copy.

All books below are also in the library. This is not a list in which all books have to be read. But it will give an idea of the diversity of nationalisms we will study and choose from electively in our studies. Select chapters may be given to read or study after due discussion in class. This will in turn help students select books. Authors/themes to review later.

Asher, Kiran, Black and Green, Afro Colombians, Development and Nature in the Pacific lowlands, 2009

Blackbourn, Stuart, The conquest of nature; water, landscape and the making of modern Germany,  2006.

Beinart, William, The rise of Conservation in South Africa, A History, Settlers, livestock and the environment 1770-1950. London, 2003.

Grading
Grading Components
Grading Rubric
The final letter grades in this course will be determined as per Relative grading

There will be two take home assignments and a mandatory book review. Students may do a double book review in place of two assignments. All book reviews have to be presented and discussed in class with an open session and a draft submitted for comments by and discussion with the Professor prior to the final submission . 

The essays are to be maximum length 1200 words and the book reviews not longer than 1500 words.

Please note this class is run in seminar mode and students will get a common reading as well as be assigned a paper or chapter in groups or sets but asked to share reflections as part of a discussion.

All will be encouraged to speak, raise points and questions and since this is an inter disciplinary class, many perspectives and approaches will be encouraged.  The emphasis is on how to pose the question and marshal the evidence .

Smart and Biomaterials [CHM-3213/ CHM-4213/ CHM-6213] [CHM-3213/ CHM-4213/ CHM-6213-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ,Santu Bera [santu.bera@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Learning Objectives:

This course will include topics from stimuli-responsive materials. Such systems are referred to as Smart Materials as they can quickly respond to certain external stimuli such as temperature, light, pH etc.

Smart Materials find a wide range of applications in biological as well as device-based applications. Houses having windows coated with smart materials can keep the house cool during the hot summer days by preventing the heat penetration, and same time can generate electricity as well. Self-healing materials can repair small fractures caused by applied stress and thereby increase the lifetime. For example, if car gets scratches, it may heal itself. Smart biomaterials have recently evolved as a highly fascinating area to become an integral component in the modern-day improvement of human condition and quality of life. These are said to impact the modern medicines in various ways. Tissue engineering, drug delivery systems, medical devices are some of the areas where smart biomaterials have significant role to play. Nevertheless, apart from biomedicine, biomaterials also play a crucial role in developing green technology.     

Under this course, we will study about the various types of smart and biomaterials that find applications in biomedical sciences, electronic materials, and modern displays. We will learn the fundamental principles behind properties that make them unique in their classes. Topics that will be discussed in more details are Hydrogels, Self-healing materials, Liquid crystals, and brief introduction to single molecule electronics and molecular machines. Different classes of natural biomaterials including their properties and functions will be discussed. Design of synthetic biomaterials that requires knowledge and understanding of chemistry, materials science, biology, engineering, and medicine, will be covered. The course has been designed to provide students a comprehensive idea and in-depth understanding of biomaterials.

Course contents:

1. Introduction: Smart Functional and Biomaterials: Optical Materials, Shape Memory Systems, Materials for drug delivery, Tissue engineering etc.

2. Soft Matterials

  • Introduction: hydrogels and their applications
  • Chemistry behind solidification of liquids (water)
  • Forces responsible for gelation: Noncovalent molecular interactions
  • Structural features of a gelator: Amphiphiles
  • Characterization of a gel 

Self-healing materials

  • Introduction to self-healing materials and their applications
  • Design of self-healing and self-restoring materials
  • Chemistry behind self-healing process

3. Smart Optical Materials

  • Chromogenic Materials
  • Photochromic compounds: Chemistry and application in ophthalmic lenses
  • Smart transparent glass

Organic light emitting devices (OLED)

  • Introduction: light emitting devices (LED)
  • Emission of light: Fluorescence & Phosphorescence
  • Developmental history of LED
  • Work principle of LEDs
  • Materials used in LED
  • Drawbacks of LED
  • Organic LED (OLED): Generations of OLED

4. Liquid Crystals

  • Liquid crystals and their applications
  • Types of liquid crystals

5. Introduction to Biomaterials  

6. Natural Biomaterials

  • Structure and properties of cell components (proteins, DNA, carbohydrates)
  • Biocompatibility
  • Mechanical property/elastic moduli
  • Biodegradability
  • Cell-matrices interaction/ host response to foreign materials

7. Artificial/synthetic Biomaterials

  • Natural materials-based (proteins and peptides like collagen, Cellulose)
  • Polymer-based (Poly(methyl methacrylate ))
  • Ceramics (Hydroxyapatite)

8. Applications

  • Next generation medical implants like artificial tissue, dental implants, vascular grafts
  • Interface of biotechnology and engineering
  • Green energy harvesting
  • Bioelectrodes and biomedical sensors
  • An emerging industry
Learning Outcomes

Student will learn:

  • About various systems that are categorized as smart materials
  • Smart materials have huge industrial importance and are materials for future devices
  • This course will offer a basic understanding about the design and working principle
  • Topics that will be discussed in this course are from modern day research & technology problems and are still under developmental stage
  • The fundamental concepts of materials science as applied for biomaterials science
  • Biological properties need to be evaluated to understand the potential of a system as biomaterials
  • The preparation and properties of different artificial biomaterials

Stereochemistry and Heterocyclic Chemistry [CHM-3214/ CHM-4214] [CHM-3214/ CHM-4214-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sourav Chatterjee [sourav.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The term “stereochemistry” has its origin in the Greek word “stereos” which means solid. As the name suggests, stereochemistry is the branch of chemistry that explores the properties of any compound that depend on the three-dimensional arrangement of the atoms/groups in the molecule. Compounds studied under this topic have identical chemical structures. Such compounds, called as stereoisomers, despite having exactly same elemental composition and formula may display huge differences in their properties, especially the way they interact with biological systems. A very basic example is found in the naturally occurring sugars which predominantly have D-chirality. We all know that the D-glucose is primary source of energy but L-glucose is totally different in that aspect. It is quite commonly observed fact that a particular enantiomer of the drug is biologically active while other remains silent. All this could be explained if their stereochemical aspects are considered. This course is designed to provide explanation about how certain subtle differences in spatial arrangements of atoms/groups in a compound can give rise to prominent effects. Stereochemistry is of particular importance in the field pharmaceuticals industry where it can provide great insights about designing new drugs.

This course will also have some selected topics from heterocyclic chemistry. The contents within this part will provide a broad understanding of the major classes of heterocyclic compounds.  Emphasis is given on the nomenclature, structure, properties, syntheses, and reactions of the simple 5 and 6-membered ring heterocycles, such as pyridines, pyrroles, furanes, thiophenes, indoles, quinoline and isoquinolines.

 

Course contents:

Introduction & Applictions:

  • Importance of stereochemistry in real life: some examples and a short history of stereochemistry, experiments & methods
  • The Significance of Chirality in Drug Design and Development
  • Chemistry in 3D space, Chirality and its origin

Nomenclature and Terminology:

  • Absolute (R/S and D,L) and relative configurations
  • Stereoisomers

Conformatonal Analysis and its effect on recativities:

  • Conformations of acyclic systems and of cyclopentane and cyclohexane (mono and disubstituted)
  • Stereoelectronic and steric principles in reactions: Substitution, elimination and addition; selectivity and specificity

Chemistry of Heterocyclic compounds:

  • Introduction, Importance, Classification and nomenclature
  • Structure, aromaticity in 5-numbered and 6-membered rings containing one heteroatom
  • General Synthetic Methods of some Biologically and Medicinally imporant Heterocylcic Compounds:
  • General methods of synthesis for: Furan, Pyrrole, Thiophene, Pyridine, Indole, Quinoline and isoquinoline

 

References:

-Stereochemistry by Eliel

-Stereochemistry by Nasipuri

-Introduction to the Chemistry of Heterocyclic compounds, John Welly& Sons (1976) by R.M. Acheson.

-The Chemistry of Heterocycles, 2nd Edition. By Theophil Eicher and Siegfried Hauptmann. 2003 Wiiey-VCH Veriag GmbH & Co. KGaA

-Heterocyclic Chemistry, 3rd edition, J. A. Joule, K. Mills, and G. F. Smith, 1995, Stanley Thornes (Publishers) Ltd

Learning Outcomes

This course is designed to provide explanation about how certain subtle differences in spatial arrangements of atoms/groups in a compound can give rise to prominent effects.

Students will be able to learn the fundamentals of chirality and properties related to chiral and heterocyclic compounds. These two topics are important part of carbohydrate chemistry and pharma industry.

War and Strategy [IR-2048] [IR-2048-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course offers an introduction to war and strategy in international politics. The first part of the course deals with the conceptual and normative dimensions of war through engaging with the canon- Clausewitz, Tilly, Schelling among others. It goes on to unpack the leading explanations for war—rationalist-bargaining, misperception, domestic institutions and identity issues among others. The second part traces how technological change (cyber operations, AI, drones, hybrid/grey-zone tactics) reshape war in the 21st century. The last section of the course aims at making students engage with critical approaches (feminist, postcolonial, STS, and sensory/ecological perspectives), foregrounding the human experience of war and the politics of knowledge that mediate it.

 

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives:
Evaluate competing causal theories of war
Analyse nuclear, cyber, and AI-enabled warfare within deterrence and escalation frameworks
Integrate critical perspectives to assess the ethical, ecological, and sensorial dimensions of warfare

description:
Introduction to Political Theory [POL-1009/ PHI-1820] [POL-1009/ PHI-1820-1]

Faculty Name
Bastian Steuwer [bastian.steuwer@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Politics makes appeal to ideas and ideals. Political debate often centers around ideals like nationalism, secularism, liberty, justice, constitutionalism, democracy and the like. Some skeptics believe that when politicians appeal to ideals, they always do so self-servingly in the pursuit of power. But even power is a political concept. Understanding political concepts are therefore important for participants in politics – and all of us are participants in politics as citizens. But understanding political concepts is also important to analyze and explain political events. After all, explanations often involve political concepts like democracy, federalism, the rule of law, and so on.

Political theory is the sub-field of political science that critically engages with political concepts and ideas. There are two main approaches to political theory: history of political thought – studying the development and history of ideas – and political philosophy – studying political ideas systematically. Students can meet their political theory requirement through a course in either of the traditions. Introduction to Political Theory focuses on political philosophy, although we will read some historic texts both from Europe and India.

The course is divided into four big parts. We begin by studying democracy and constitutionalism. Is there a will of the people? Is democracy possible? Is constitutionalism a compromise with democracy? Ideas of constitutionalism are often associated with liberalism and secularism. The second part discusses these ideas. What is the basis for human rights? How should we understand secularism? Do liberty and equality conflict? The last question points towards another domain of politics: social justice. In the third part we look more closely at social justice. We look at questions of caste, class, and gender. Some of these questions are often framed as identity politics. One form of identity is that of shared citizenship. Another threat that binds us together is our shared humanity. How should we think of these two connections, nationalism and cosmopolitanism? How should we do political theory in light of this?

courseTitle: War in the Early Modern World
description:
War in the Early Modern World [HIS-3020/ IR-3030] [HIS-3020/ IR-3030-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What is the Military Revolution? How did the advent of firearms transform military tactics, strategy, and culture in sixteenth-century Japan, Europe, and Korea? What role did military techniques have in the European colonisation of Africa and the Americas? How did warfare relate to the international state-system in Russia, Iran, and the Ottoman Empire? Why did the traditional military use of elephants and horses continue in South Asia and Southeast Asia even after the spread of gunpowder weaponry? These are some of the questions this course addresses. It offers an exploration of the global history of warfare in the early modern world (1500-1800). It especially looks into the rapid changes in technology, tactics, strategy, logistics, and military culture vis-à-vis growing international rivalry between empires and nation-states during this period. We will explore war in the European nation-states, European colonies in the Americas, the Russian Empire, African kingdoms, the Ottoman Empire, Indian empires, the Safavid Empire in Iran, Southeast Asian kingdoms, the Ming and Qing Empires in China, the Tokugawa Shogunate in Japan, the Korean kingdom, and European maritime empires.

NB: This History elective is corss-listed with International Relations.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will have a sound understanding of military history for different parts of the early modern world against the backdrop of the political processes of state-formation and empire-building.

description:
International History [IR-1010] [IR-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, we will analyze the major events of the Cold War through the
prism of three analytical lenses: interests, individuals, and ideology. We will
attempt to evaluate the extent to which each of these factors, either singly, or
in combination, affected decision making on inter-state relations during the
decades of the Cold War and in the post-Cold War decades.
Secondly, the course will also highlight how the progression of the Cold War
decades also witnessed the making of deeper inter-connections across the
globe. For example, we will consider how the distant developments of the
Cold War were also of relevance in shaping India’s position in the world.
Furthermore, we will examine how the developments of the Cold War were
equally shaped, not just by the superpowers, but also by smaller, poorer, and
recently decolonized countries. The course will also show the role trade and
technology played in sparking a new Cold War between the superpowers.
Enabling an evaluation of why developments unfolded in the way that they did
during the Cold War, therefore, the course
will show how the appraisal of events from more than a single point of view, is
necessary to understand the impact of the Cold War more fully on present day
international politics.
Finally, we will also explore the newer directions of the historiography on the
Cold War, including the ways in which its debates influenced popular culture
and the international perceptions of technological aid. Ultimately, we will ask,
in what ways can our analysis of the Cold War help us in shaping our present
day understanding of the conduct of international affairs in the present?

Learning Outcomes

This elass will equip students to study international relations by providing essential context, analytical framework and a deeper understanding of the forces that shape today's global affairs.

Understanding the Image [MS-2232] [MS-2232-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a 13-week undergraduate course designed for a 2000-level Media Studies minor. The course explores visual cultures and image making through theoretical and practical lenses. Through a study and practice of photography it will analyse and assess the impact of images on cultural and social understanding of politics and representation in journalism, advertising and documentary art forms by integrating theories with practice. Students will and apply them to real-world media production.

The course blends hands-on training field activities, and case studies with critical readings and discussions.Students will be given technical instruction on the use of the camera and be introduced to the craft of phorography, studying composition, perspective, framing and light.

Assignments will be a combination of practical and written work.

Learning Outcomes

Students interested in media, media theory, still photography and cinema will find this course gives them the foundation to inspect our image driven societies through a variety of perspectives. It will also give them an introduction to creating and disseminating carefully thought through photographs, graphics/ memes and videos. 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Susan Sontag, On Photography

John Berger, Ways of Seeing

Guy de Bord, Society of the Spectacle

Roland Barthes, Image, Music, Text 

Nicholas Mirzoeff (ed.), Visual Cultures Reader

Applied Econometrics [ECO-3515] [ECO-3515-1]

Faculty Name
Digvijay Singh Negi [digvijay.negi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course includes advanced topics in micro-econometrics which are used for data analyses, specifically for impact evaluation. It builds on the course work in introductory econometrics, and its main objective is to equip students to carry out empirical data analyses in economics. Both theory and its application will be the thrust of this course. Theoretical instruction will involve class lectures and discussions, while applications will be learned through in-class demonstrations and assignments. STATA will be used for the instruction of applications. By the end of this course, you should be able to understand and apply the econometric methods to data. 

Learning Outcomes
  • Grasp advanced topics in micro-econometrics and understand how they are applied in data analyses, particularly for impact evaluation.
  • Carry out empirical data analyses in economics by applying both the theoretical and applied components of micro-econometrics.
  • Understand and apply the econometric methods to data, demonstrating the ability to translate theory into practice.
  • Effectively use the STATA software for instruction, application, and completion of assignments, assessments, and demonstrations.
  • Engage in class discussions based on circulated articles and papers, demonstrating critical evaluation of existing econometric research.
  • Complete a replication exercise and class presentation based on replication, showing the ability to reproduce and critique empirical findings.
  • Apply econometric methods to real datasets to solve homework problems and complete assignments.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  1. Jeffrey M. Wooldridge [JMW], Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition.
  2. Angrist, J.D and Pischke, J.-S [MHE]. Mostly Harmless Econometrics, Princeton University Press, 2008.
  3. Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K [CT]. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010

description:
Corporate Finance [FIN-2050] [FIN-2050-1]

Faculty Name
S K Shanthi [sk.shanthi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Corporate Finance
In this introductory course we will introduce the students to a world looked at from a finance manager’s point of view. The three broad sets of decisions that finance managers undertake are—decisions on where to invest the resources or funds that the business has raised, either internally or externally (the investment decision), decisions on where and how to raise funds to finance these investments (the financing decision), and decisions on how much and in what form to return funds back to the owners (the dividend decision). The course will include the central concepts of modern finance: basic accounting principles and financial statements analysis, net present value, IRR, Discounted cash Flow and other valuation models, fundamentals of capital structure and an introduction to corporate dividend policies and their implications for valuation (if time permits). The course uses a mix of theory and practice for exposition.
The course involves 26 class room sessions, each of 90 minutes duration. 
List of topics and session details:
1.    Basic accounting, Balance sheet and income statement analysis, cash flow analysis and financial models (5 Sessions)
2.    Capital Budgeting: Discounted cash flow analysis, Time value of Money, NPV, IRR and other investment rules, Capital investment decision making (4 Sessions)
3.    Bonds and bond valuation, government bonds, corporate bonds, pricing of bonds, risks associated with investing in bonds, bond yields and their determinants and the yield curve. (2 Sessions)
4.    Quiz (1session)
5.    Stock valuation – methods of valuation, ratios for comparisons, introduction to stock markets, exchanges and trading (2 Sessions)
6.    Risk and return – Market history, CAPM (3 Sessions)
7.    Weighted Average Cost of capital (2 Session)
8.    Discounted Cash Flow valuation and other valuation methods (2 session)
9.    Capital structure – Basics, use of debt and valuation and capital budgeting for a levered firm (3 Sessions)
10.    Quiz (1 Session)
11.    Dividend Policy (If time permits)

 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Textbook: Corporate Finance by Stephen A. Ross, Randolph W. Westerfield, Jeffrey Jaffe, Bradford D Jordan and Ram Kumar Kakani McGraw Hill. 11e edition

S K Shanthi [sk.shanthi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Corporate Finance
In this introductory course we will introduce the students to a world looked at from a finance manager’s point of view. The three broad sets of decisions that finance managers undertake are—decisions on where to invest the resources or funds that the business has raised, either internally or externally (the investment decision), decisions on where and how to raise funds to finance these investments (the financing decision), and decisions on how much and in what form to return funds back to the owners (the dividend decision). The course will include the central concepts of modern finance: basic accounting principles and financial statements analysis, net present value, IRR, Discounted cash Flow and other valuation models, fundamentals of capital structure and an introduction to corporate dividend policies and their implications for valuation (if time permits). The course uses a mix of theory and practice for exposition.
The course involves 26 class room sessions, each of 90 minutes duration. 
List of topics and session details:
1.    Basic accounting, Balance sheet and income statement analysis, cash flow analysis and financial models (5 Sessions)
2.    Capital Budgeting: Discounted cash flow analysis, Time value of Money, NPV, IRR and other investment rules, Capital investment decision making (4 Sessions)
3.    Bonds and bond valuation, government bonds, corporate bonds, pricing of bonds, risks associated with investing in bonds, bond yields and their determinants and the yield curve. (2 Sessions)
4.    Quiz (1session)
5.    Stock valuation – methods of valuation, ratios for comparisons, introduction to stock markets, exchanges and trading (2 Sessions)
6.    Risk and return – Market history, CAPM (3 Sessions)
7.    Weighted Average Cost of capital (2 Session)
8.    Discounted Cash Flow valuation and other valuation methods (2 session)
9.    Capital structure – Basics, use of debt and valuation and capital budgeting for a levered firm (3 Sessions)
10.    Quiz (1 Session)
11.    Dividend Policy (If time permits)

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Textbook: Corporate Finance by Stephen A. Ross, Randolph W. Westerfield, Jeffrey Jaffe, Bradford D Jordan and Ram Kumar Kakani McGraw Hill. 11e edition

description:
Economics of Discrimination [ECO-6671] [ECO-6671-1]

Faculty Name
Ashwini Deshpande [ashwini.deshpande@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course familiarizes students with theories and empirical tools to understand and measure economic discrimination based on social group identities, such as caste, race, gender, tribal status, ethnicity and so on. The course will focus on evidence related to caste and sex in India. 

The first part of the course will take students through theories of discrimination such as statistical discrimination and taste for discrimination, based on the work of Kenneth Arrow, Gary Becker and George Akerlof.  This will lead to a discussion of the overlap between economics of discrimination and related sub-disciplines that are relatively new but are rapidly expanding, viz., “Identity Economics”, pioneered by George Akerlof and Rachel Kranton, “Feminist Economics”, and “Stratification Economics”. 

The second section will introduce students to concepts in social psychology such as stereotype threat and implicit bias that produce discriminatory outcomes. 

The third part of the course introduces students to some of the key methods of empirically gauging discrimination in market settings. This section would familiarize students with decomposition analyses applied to the labour market (what part of the wage gap between two groups is due to differences in abilities, and what part is due to discrimination), using standard techniques from Labour Economics. We would also discuss experimental methods – both field-based as well as lab-based experiments to gauge discrimination outside the labour market (e.g. housing market), or in the field of charitable giving, or even in labour markets but during the job search process (before applicants find jobs).  

Students will be familiarized with literature that applies these methods in the Indian context, particularly to the study of caste and gender discrimination. 

The final part of the course will deal with policy options to deal with group-based disparities and discrimination, with a focus on affirmative action policies. This section will outline the various types of affirmative action, including quotas or reservation, and discuss debates around affirmative action, focusing on evidence-based research gauging its impact.

Real Analysis [MAT-2003/ ECO-5003] [MAT-2003/ ECO-5003-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Maddaly [krishna.maddaly@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Real and complex number system.  Sequences, limits, monotonic sequences, limits superior and limits inferior.  Convergence of a series, absolute and conditional convergence.  Power series over complex numbers and their radii of convergence.   Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem, Cantor and Heine-Borel Theorems.  Pointwise and uniform continuity.  Pointwise and uniform convergence of sequence of functions.   Integrals and derivatives of  sequences and series of functions.   Elementary transcendental functions.  Improper integral.  Riemann-Stieltjes integral.  Idea of Lebesgue integral.  Weierstrass approximation theorem.

Learning Outcomes

The course aims to give a solid foundation in the basic concepts of Analysis.

description:

Faculty Name
Parush Arora [parush.arora@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course discusses why data analysis is a required skill among social scientists. The course not only focus on theory but aims to teach students how to analyze data and apply techniques. The core topics will include prediction, supervised-unsupervised learning, bias-variance trade-off, cross-validation, regularization, how linear regression is used from the perspective of prediction Vs causation etc. The course will also introduce some of the machine learning techniques like lasso, k-nearest neighbours, decision tree etc. The course aims to teach students to analyze data on RStudio and R.

description:
Chemistry for beginners [CHM-0124] [CHM-0124-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Chemistry for Beginners is designed to be suitable for students from science as well as non-science background. This is an introductory course that focuses on development of a conceptual understanding of the fundamental principles of chemistry. It serves the purpose of giving students a solid and diverse introduction to the discipline. Various topics that will be covered include the atomic structure, atomic orbitals & electronic configurations, periodicity of elemental properties such as electronegativity, ionization energies and their impact, radioactivity, principles of acid/base theories, pH, buffers, acid-base indicators, empirical and molecular formulae, chemical bonding, molecular geometry, etc. The course objective is for students to gain competency (in recognizing concepts and problem solving) in basic areas of general chemistry.

No Pre-requisite for this course.

 

 

Course Contents: The topics that will be covered are as following-

Chemisty and its Importance in Eeeryday Life

  • Role of chemistry in medicine and food industry
  • Soaps, detergents and disinfectants
  • Polymeric materials in textile, rubber etc.

Materials, Molecules, Elements and Atoms

  • States of matter: Solid, liquid, gas and Plasma
  • Molecules, elments and atoms
  • Avagadro number, molecular weight, molarity and molality

Basic Chemical Properties

  • Solubility/miscibility rules
  • Principles of acid/base theories, pH and buffers
  • Oxidation-Reduction Reactions
  • Functional groups, classes of compounds and IUPAC nomenclature system

Structure of the Atom and Elemental Properties

  • Bohr model of the atom
  • Orbitals, n, l, m and s quantum numbers and their significance
  • Complete electronic configuration of atoms
  • Periodic table & Periodicity: Size of atoms and ions, electron affinity and ionization energy
  • Radioactivity: Nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, critical mass; radioactive decay; Half-life and average life period; applications of radioactivity (isotope dating, nuclear medicine)

Chemical Bonding: General Concepts 

  • The octet rule and how it can be used to write ionic compounds and covalent molecules.
  • Chemical Bonds: Ioninc, Covalent, and on-covalent bonds
  • Shapes of mlecules

 

Learning Outcomes

As this course covers the fundamental principles and laws of chemistry, upon completion, students should be able to demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental chemical laws, and the concepts as needed in higher level chemistry courses as well as other topics where knowledge of chemistry is expected.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No Pre-requisite for this course.

 

Suggested Books:

  • J. D. Lee, Concise Inorganic Chemistry, 5th Ed., Blackwell Publishing, 2006.
  • B. M. Mahan & R. J. Meyers, University Chemistry, 4-th Ed., Pearson Education, India, 2009.

description:
Theory of Computation [CS-3330] [CS-3330-1]

Faculty Name
Aalok Dhaval Thakkar [thakkar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Most computer science courses teach how to compute: how to write programs, implement algorithms, and build systems. This course asks a deeper question: what is computation? Different disciplines offer different answers. Logicians understand computation as symbol manipulation (Gödel, 1931; Post, 1943); mathematicians as the effective evaluation of functions (Church, 1936); linguists as the generation and recognition of grammatical structure (Chomsky, 1956); and engineers as the control of physical processes (von Neumann, 1945; Shannon 1948). In CS-3330, we will answer this question as computer scientists: computation is the execution of an abstract machine acting on an input according to unambiguous rules (Turing, 1936). With this perspective, we will unify the symbolic, functional, linguistic, and physical views of computation, and address three fundamental questions: What can be computed? What can be computed with resource constraints? And what cannot be computed at all?

This course is divided into four modules: 

  1. Finite State Systems: In the first module, we study computation with bounded memory and develop the theory of finite automata and regular languages. We compare different models of computation: deterministic, nondeterministic, and stochastic, as well as finite controllers with bounded data structures. We also introduce the connection between logic, automata, and grammar (and, time permitting, algebra and games), highlighting how simple computational models give rise to rich mathematical characterizations.
  2. Infinite State Systems: We move beyond finite machines to models with unbounded memory, expressed through stacks, tapes, and other extensible data structures. We examine their grammatical counterparts, such as context-free grammars, and show how these systems capture deeper forms of computational structure. This module clarifies why seemingly different models of general-purpose computation are equivalent in power and presents the Church-Turing Thesis as the unifying principle behind them.
  3. Decidability and Undecidability: In this module, we study the boundary between solvable and unsolvable problems. Using diagonalization, reductions, and fixed-point arguments, we identify problems that no algorithm can solve. Examples include the Entscheidungsproblem, problems about Turing machines, first-order logic validity, grammar problems, and tiling problems.
  4. Computational Complexity: When problems can be solved, we examine their time and space complexity, polynomial-time computation, and the notion of intractability. We also discuss the open problem P vs. NP and provide a framework for understanding why some solvable problems remain practically out of reach, and how resource constraints shape the landscape of computation.

More details are available at the course webpage.

 

Prerequisites: The course will require a certain level of maturity, at least at the level of CS-2212 (Data Structures and Algorithms). It is recommended that students also have familiarity with algorithmic concepts, including reductions, at the level of CS-3210 (Design and Analysis of Algorithms).

Audit Requirements: Students auditing the course will be evaluated based only on the assessments, and do not need to take the final exam. Auditing students are required to score at least half the points on each assessment.

Policies: Please note the following policies:

  1. Regular attendance is expected but not mandatory. Students arriving more than 5 minutes late may not enter, to minimize disruption. Eating in class is not allowed, and the use of laptops or cellphones is prohibited unless specifically required for course activities. Students are encouraged to take notes on paper by hand (unless granted an exception by OLS or OAA). 
  2. As outlined in Ashoka's Academic Integrity Policy (see MyAshoka → Information and Documents → Office of Academic Affairs), plagiarism and other violations (including but not limited to unauthorized use of AI tools) are serious offenses. Any violation will result in a failing grade (F) for the course. Please review the policy carefully.
Learning Outcomes

description:
Information Security [CS-3610] [CS-3610-1]

Faculty Name
Aalok Dhaval Thakkar [thakkar@ashoka.edu.in] ,Subhashis Banerjee [suban@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Are your secrets safe? Is your data truly private? What do they really know? 

The answers to these questions depend on how we design the systems that manage our information and the assumptions built into them. This course offers a formal, rigorous study of the security of these systems—its theory, its practice, and its implications. 

We will examine foundational concepts including threat models, confidentiality, privacy, authentication, cryptography, and access control. Alongside the technical framework, we will consider the human, organizational, and societal dimensions that influence real-world security outcomes. 

The course is divided into three modules: 

  1. Theoretical Foundations: We begin by establishing security definitions and introducing threat models to formalize how we think about adversaries and protection goals. This is followed by a review of the two major perspectives of modern information security: cryptography (which relies on complexity-theoretic assumptions), and verification (which uses logic and formal reasoning to prove that systems behave securely).
  2. Practical Cases: We then shift to real-world systems and their failures. The case studies include the Heartbleed vulnerability, private or “incognito” browsing modes, prompt injection risks in large language models, and the security challenges surrounding electronic voting machines. These examples illustrate how security can break down due to implementation errors, design trade-offs, usability constraints, and human assumptions.
  3. Advanced Topics: Finally, we look at a few emerging and future-facing areas of security research, such as zero-knowledge proofs, secure multiparty computation, and post-quantum cryptography.
Learning Outcomes

This course will help students reason concretely about real-world problems through case studies. This course will not cover design of security systems, but will cover requirement analysis methods and threat modelling. It will also familiarise them with commonly used security tools and measures in everyday life.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Matthew A. Bishop, Computer Security: Art and Science, 2nd Edition, Pearson, 2018

2. Bruce Schneier, Applied Cryptography, John Wiley & Sons, 1996.

3. William Stallings, Cryptography and Network Security: Principles and Practice, 8th Edition, Pearson, 2022

4. Ross Anderson, Security Engineering: A Guide to Building Dependable Distributed Systems, 3rd Edition, Wiley, 2020

5. Charlie Kaufman, Radia Perlman, and Mike Speciner, Network Security: Private Communication in a Public World, 3rd Edition, Pearson

Students are encouraged to take notes on paper by hand (unless granted an exception by OLS or OAA).
  2. Students are expected to attend the weekly quizzes on Wednesdays. There will be no make-up provisions for missed quizzes.

description:
Computer Networks [CS-3620] [CS-3620-1]

Faculty Name
Dheeraj Sanghi [dheeraj.sanghi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The dynamic field of computer networking involves many concepts, protocols, and technologies that are woven together in an intricate manner. The Internet is the largest computer network that interconnects hundreds of millions of computing devices throughout the world. This course will use the Internet as the principal vehicle for discussing computer networks and their protocols. Despite the fact that the Internet is extremely large and has numerous diverse components and uses, there exist guiding principles and structures that can provide a foundation for understanding such an amazingly large and complex system. This course will ensure that students grasp a comprehensive understanding of the guiding principles and overall structure, empowering them to navigate the intricacies of computer networking with confidence and expertise.

Learning Outcomes

In this course the students will learn about how a network works. They will specifically understand the roles and responsibilities of each layer in the network protocol stack: physical, data link, network, transport, and application layers. The students will develop an understanding of how data moves across layers from one device to another across the internet. This course will only cover the basics and will not consider design, configuration, management or performance evaluation of computer networks.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach. James F. Kurose and Keith W. Ross. Pearson Publication.

2. Computer Networks: A Systems Approach. Larry L. Peterson and Bruce S. Davie. Morgan Kaufmann Publishers.

description:
Dealing with doom [POL-3112] [POL-3112-1]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Climate crisis, spread of diseases, worsening quality of air, water and life, civil unrest, collapse of democracies, anxiety, fear and a sense of hopelessness – in this course we shall explore this sense of doom and the ways in which various scholars - political scientists, historians, philosophers, theologists - have examined it. 

But instead of spending  thirteen weeks thinking about catastrophes or kismet, we shall explore a more critical question: in what ways can this sense of doom be interpreted, and read as signs of impending revolutions, of change and hope? For, ever so often, this sense of doom is intricately linked to the stories of our origins, to the creation self-regulating communities, to fashioning of languages, to possible futures.

Learning Outcomes

- To understand the dialectic of hope and doom; pasts and futures, action and theory. 

- To build critical thinking, reading and writing abilities.

- To ask and explore good and pertinent questions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings: All the mandatory readings would be made available to the students electronically at least a week before the lectures on the said topic. Note: you are encouraged to read the text entirely, but the essential pages are marked below.

Public Economics [ECO-3630/ PUB-3630] [ECO-3630/ PUB-3630-1]

Faculty Name
Bhanu Gupta [bhanu.gupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will cover the role of government in modern economies. We will dig deep into the study of various instruments used to generate government revenue and analyze efficient ways to spend government monies. You will also be exposed to microeconomic models that are used to study the reaction of agents to government policies.  This course will serve as an introduction to various empirical tools used in modern public economics. Government expenditure, externalities, public goods, taxation, social security programs,  are some of the topics that will be covered in this course. Abstract concepts will be mapped to real-world examples to develop your public economics intuition.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, the aim is to make you comfortable with the fundamentals of public economics theory and develop problem-solving skills that will be beneficial in other economic courses.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The main course material will be papers assigned during the course. In case you haven’t studied public economics during undergraduate studies, please refer to the following textbook:

Gruber, J., Public Finance & Public Policy (I am using the 5th edition).

A list of topics that will be discussed in the course are given below. Please note that subject to time constraints, topics may be added or deleted from this list. List of topics are: Introduction to Public Economics; Defining and Measuring Inequality; Theoretical and Emprical Tools for Public Economics; Tax Incidence and Efficiency costs of Taxation; Optimal Labor Income Taxation; Taxes and Labor Supply; Externalities; Public Goods; Taxes on Capital and Savings; Behavioral Public Finance; Political Economy; Social and Health Insurance; Education and Discrimination.

description:
Resource Economics [ECO-3519/ PUB-3519] [ECO-3519/ PUB-3519-1]

Faculty Name
Digvijay Singh Negi [digvijay.negi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The objective of this course is to equip students to develop an understanding and capability to analyze important economic issues in resource economics. We will review recent empirical evidence on the various causes of natural resource exploitation. We will also discuss the social and economic impacts of resource exploitation and environmental degradation. The subject will focus extensively on developing the ability to think about issues and problems in resource economics through empirical models. Students must be comfortable with mathematics for economists, basic statistics, and econometrics.

Learning Outcomes
  • Acquire a fundamental understanding of resource economics and the capability to analyze important economic issues related to natural resources.
  • Review and critically analyze recent empirical evidence concerning the causes of natural resource exploitation and the social and economic impacts of resource exploitation and environmental degradation.
  • Develop the ability to think about resource economics issues and problems using empirical models.
  • Comfortably apply mathematical, statistical, and econometric tools necessary for advanced analysis in resource economics.
  • Participate actively in class, demonstrating the ability to contribute to class participation and discussion of course material.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading list for a course structured like this will be multi-layered and highly current. It will primarily consist of seminal and cutting-edge research articles from top academic journals. These journal readings will be supplemented by policy reports and data-driven analyses from public sector organizations and prominent think tanks, ensuring that we are able to connect academic concepts to real-world policy debates on resource exploitation and environmental degradation.

Crafting Space [CVA-0096] [CVA-0096-1]

Overview

This course will introduce students to the idea of designing and crafting a scale model of a habitable space of their choosing. During the course of the semester students will be introduced to the meaning of space and how it has been crafted through precedents over time imbibing cultural and social values and how those parameters can influence its design and usage. We will be looking at a historical timeline from cave dwellers, emperors as patrons and modern-day architects and how they have created spaces varying in scale to create habitats over time.

Keeping these in mind, students will begin to explore what space means to them individually and how each person’s idea of space will be different depending on their cultures and histories. Their assignment will be to design a single habitable space for themselves.

Students will make sketches and scale models through the design process that best represent their design intent. Materiality – the study of how different materials express different intent - will be explored so that the models that each student makes best represent the space that they are designing.

Kashmiri through Literature [CLA-0053] [CLA-0053-1]

Overview

This course is an introduction to the Kashmiri language and its abundant yet dust-ridden literary corpus with an aim to inspire the next generation of readers — this is a longshot — and future translators. Students will gain a rudimentary knowledge of speaking, reading, and writing Kashmiri, while becoming familiar with the historical and cultural contexts that have shaped its literature. By engaging with literary texts, music, and popular media, we will start with questioning the very need for this course and proceed to cultivate an appreciation for the language and its literature by engaging with texts (in English translation) ranging from the poetry of Habba Khatoon to contemporary poets like Meem Hai Zaffar as well as modernist short stories by writers like Hari Krishna Kaul, Akhtar Mohiuddin, Habib Kamran, and Amin Kamil.

We will also briefly talk about Kashmiri Marsiya — a performative literary genre — exploring the themes of mourning and loss. Alongside this, we will examine how this foreign literary genre has evolved within Kashmiri cultural and literary context, reflecting both its adaptation and transformation over time. No prior knowledge of Kashmiri language is required — just a curiosity for languages, literature, and storytelling.

Bharatanatyam: A Glimpse [CPA-0103] [CPA-0103-1]

Overview

Bharatanatyam is a beautiful, intense, creative, enchanting, aesthetic and spiritual classical dance tradition from Tamil Nadu. The course ' Introduction to Bharatanatyam' intends to introduce the students to many aspects of this art form which will enable them to engage with the vocabulary of movements , gestures and expressions. The course will help them understand how this dance form brings the essence of other art forms in the interpretation of music , rhythm and literature. The course aims to educate the students about the richness of this dance language and how it has crossed various cultural boundaries to become a universal language of creative expression and experience.

They will learn a few movements, gestures, rhythm exercises, swara( musical notes) patterns and 'Madhurashtakam', a composition of Saint Vallabhacharya.
