Financial Markets and Asset Pricing [FIN-3001/ ECO-3203/ MAT-4202] [FIN-3001/ ECO-3203/ MAT-4202-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course focuses on the pricing of financial assets. We will talk mainly about assets in the equity market, but later, we will also discuss options (puts & calls). The course revolves around different models, methods, and approaches that might help us identify mispriced financial assets, which could help us design a reasonably good portfolio. These methods and models have some economic or accounting rationale behind them, and some are based on groundbreaking papers published in the last century. Despite all that, a student in this course would eventually realize that no one model/ method is enough to help us understand the true value of a financial asset. In fact, it is extremely hard to explain why a given object has a particular value and check whether that object is overpriced/ underpriced. Renowned statistician George Box once said, "All models are wrong, but some are useful." That is what we will try to do in this course: study some models that have been useful in the context of asset pricing. To be specific, we will start with a modern interpretation of Talmudic investing strategy, Markowitz portfolio selection (and maybe some of the later variants if time or your interest permits), factor/ index models, capital asset pricing model (CAPM), and its variants, arbitrage pricing theory, Fama-French three-factor model (maybe briefly discuss the more recent 5-factor model), efficient market hypothesis, equity valuation models, and later we will study options, put-call parity, Black-Scholes' options pricing.

This is a rigorous, math- and statistics-based course. If such things tire you, if you are looking for a storytelling, case studies-based approach, or only a DCF-based approach, then this course is probably not for you.

 

Prerequisites:

ECO 2400 (Econometrics) or MAT 2020 (Probability and Statistics)

 

This course is open to:

  • 4th-year/ 3rd-year ECO/ FIN majors
  • Math majors at the 4000-level

description:
Economic Forecasting and Analysis [ECO-3402/ MAT-4203] [ECO-3402/ MAT-4203-1]

Faculty Name
Piyali Banerjee [piyali.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is an introduction to time-series forecasting analyses and techniques and is dedicated to teaching students the latest tools in time-series econometrics to enable them to make knowledgeable judgments about various types of data. This course is especially useful for forecasting business time series such as sales, and expenditures, and macroeconomic time series such as GDP, interest rate, inflation, etc.

The course will introduce some of the basics of time-series econometrics before moving on to the main topics in forecasting. You will learn the ways to examine and prepare data before forecasting. Various useful techniques will be taught about improving the precision of forecasting. Time series topics will include linear regression, ARIMA models, Box Jenkins models, reduced form VAR models, ARCH-GARCH models, and Unit root Models. With an emphasis on applications, this course will walk you through the methods of analyses of both macro and micro-level data.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

This course covers major issues in financial econometrics and macro-econometrics. Topics include Box Jenkins models, reduced form VAR models, ARCH-GARCH models, and Unit root Models.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Texts:

Walter Enders, Applied Econometric Time Series, 4th edition, Wiley, 2014. ISBN 978-0-470-50539-7

Martin, V., St. Hurn, and D. Harris, Econometric Modelling with Time Series, Specification, Estimation and Testing, Cambridge University Press, 2013, ISBN 978-0-521-13981-6

Reference Texts:

James Hamilton, Time Series Analysis, 1st edition, Princeton University Press, 1994. ISBN 0-691-04289-6

R. Tsay, Analysis of Financial Time Series, Wiley, 3rd edition, 2010.

courseTitle: Built Environments, Design and the Architectural Imagination of Sultanate and Mughal Cities from the 13th to the 17th centuries
description:
Built Environments, Design and the Architectural Imagination of Sultanate and Mughal Cities from the 13th to the 17th centuries [VA-2345/ HIS-2800/ SOA-2246] [VA-2345/ HIS-2800/ SOA-2246-1]

Faculty Name
Priyani Roy Choudhury [priyani.choudhury@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course examines the making of cities during the Sultanate and early Mughal periods. Students will learn to interpret architecture as both cultural expression and technical accomplishment. The creation of a city reflects a society’s power, wealth, knowledge, and imagination, often embodying its aspirations through the built environment, spatial organization, and ecological relationships. In Islamicate cultures moreover, oral narratives, Sufi lyric traditions, and illustrated manuscripts are crucial in defining cities. They shape the discourses through which cities are perceived and remembered. This course integrates architectural, visual, poetic, and narrative materials that inform the spatial imagination of early modern South Asian cities.

Mughal Painting, Akbari Period, c. 1585. Krishna and the Golden City of Dwarkafrom the Harivamsha (Geneology of Vishnu), Artists: Miskin and Kesu Kalan. National Museum of Asian Art, Smithsonian, Washington D.C

 

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn to:

1. Understand the cultural exchange and innovation that defined Sultanate and Mughal Architecture.

2. Analyse how local and global influences, and environmental factors intersect in urban design.

3. Explore the representation of cities in art, literature, and history.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings will be shared in class. Students will be required to participate in Two Onsite Workshops ( Itineraries subject to modifications). Attendance for the field trips is compulsory.

1. Tughlaqabad, Tomb of Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, Begampuri Masjid/Khirki Masjid, Kotla Firoz Shah/Hauz Khas (Date: Early/Mid-February)

The Tughlaq heritage of Delhi is pivotal to understanding the evolution of planned cities in the region. However, it is often overlooked in architectural histories, which tend to focus on early Sultanate and Mughal architecture. The workshop will aim to bring this heritage into focus.

2. Dinapanah (Purana Qila), Khair-ul Manzil (Maham Anga's Mosque), Monuments within Lodhi Gardens/ Humayun's Tomb Complex (Date: Early March, before mid-semester break) Or Old Delhi Walk (To be confirmed)

This workshop will provide an understanding of the diverse functions of urban structures such as stepwells, forts, mosques, and tombs, while exploring mid-16th century Delhi's architectural transition between Lodhi, Suri, and early Mughal styles.

Audit students: Are expected to keep up with course readings and moderate discussion during site presentations.

Chemical Analysis [CHM-3210/ CHM-2601/ CHM-4208] [CHM-3210/ CHM-2601/ CHM-4208-1]

Faculty Name
Munmun Ghosh [munmun.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

1. Qualitative Analysis

a. Sodium-Fusion test for Elemental Analysis

b. Systematic qualitative analysis of the given organic compounds containing monofunctional groups:

  • Carboxylic acid
  • Ester
  • Amine
  • Nitro
  • Amide
  • Thiourea
  • Phenol
  • Ketone
  • Aldehyde
  • Halides

c. Systematic qualitative analysis of the given organic compounds containing multifunctional groups:

  • Glucose, Fructose, Lactose, Maltose, Sucrose
  • Glycine, Alanine, Aspartate, Tyrosine

d. Inorganic Qualitative Analysis of Metal Salts

  • Different Anions (including interfering ones) & Cations (including rare ones)

2. Quantitative Analysis

a. Analysis of food-dye using UV-Vis spectroscopy

b. Determination of caffeine in Tea Samples (chemical method), Detailed analysis of caffeine

Learning Outcomes

Chemical analysis is the process through which nature of any substance and identity of its constituents is analysed. In this course we will perform tasks to identify some constituent ions (cations & anions) of some inorganic salts and learn methods to find out functional groups present in certain organic compounds. Procedures opted in qualitative analysis of any compound involve reactions that produce easily observable changes such as precipitation, colour change, gas release, smell etc. Generally, a simple three step scheme is followed. These three steps differentiate the ions in major groups, then into subgroup and then finally individual ion is characterized.

Rethinking Development and Sustainability [SOA-2243/ ES-2006/ POL-2130] [SOA-2243/ ES-2006/ POL-2130-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course critically examines the processes of “development” and “sustainability,” and the ways in which the two interact with each other. The course provides a critical overview of development theories, including classical political economy, modernization theory, dependency theory, postdevelopmentalism, feminist theories of development, sustainable development, and so on. It traces the ideas of development from the 19th century onward, with a particular focus on development thinking in the post-World War II period. At the same time, the course examines certain development projects for a more grounded understanding of how “development” occurs, to whose benefit, and why there is little consensus on what development entails. It then engages with the multiple ways in which development processes interact with and reshape the environment, thereby affecting the realities of people around the world, and the Global South in particular. To this end, the course specifically focuses on debates and theories around "sustainability," and critically evalutes them in the broader contexts of the climate crisis, wars and conflicts, and environmental injustice. At least one field visit will be organized to help students gain a firsthand experience of some of the concepts covered in the course. 

Upon completing this course, students are expected to learn: 

- A set of theoretical tools and analytical lenses by which to understand the processes, relationships, and phenomena involved in what we call “development” and “sustainability.”  

- The distinct implications that different theories of development have for policy, academic work, and social activism and change.

- The environment-development relations across geographic scales and their planetary and local impacts.

courseTitle: Rise of China and the Shifting Balance of Power in Southeast Asia
description:
Rise of China and the Shifting Balance of Power in Southeast Asia [IR-2035/ POL-2102/ CHI-3305] [IR-2035/ POL-2102/ CHI-3305-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course will look at China’s rise as a hegemon against the backdrop of Southeast
Asian politics and big power competition. We will follow the Southeast Asian
countries’ struggle to achieve unity around ASEAN, modernize their economies and
democratize their polity. We will also follow the evolving role of Japan, India and
South Korea in the regional balance. A major focus of the course would be the
emergence of China from a poor communist country to a superpower dominating the
neighbors and rising to challenge the United States for global hegemony.

Learning Outcomes

This course will provide students with historical and diplomatic background  necessary to understand current Asian developments. In particular the course will enable students the historical context of China's rise and background of its political, economic and military development.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. History, culture, and region in South-East Asian perspectives by O.W. Wolters
2. Southeast Asia in World History by Craig A. Lockard
3. Southeast Asia: Past & Present by D. R. SarDesai
4. Brother Enemy: The War after the War by Nayan Chanda
5. China’s Asia by Lowell Dittmer
6. Under Beijing’s Shadow: Southeast Asia’s China Challenge by Murray Hiebert
7. Where Great Powers Meet by David Shambaugh
8. The Deer and the Dragon: Southeast Asia and China in the 21st Century by
Donald K. Emmerson (Editor)
9. Overreach: How China Derailed Its Peaceful Rise by Susan L. Shirk
10. India’s Eastward Engagement: From Antiquity to Act East Policy By S.D.
Muni and Rahul Mishra
11. Superpower Showdown: How the Battle Between Trump and Xi Threatens a
New Cold War by Bob Davis and Lingling Wei
12. The Indo-Pacific: Trump, China, and the New Struggle for Global Mastery by
Richard Javad Heydarian

Trauma, Recovery and Repair [PSY-3048] [PSY-3048-1]

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course will cover the neurobiology of trauma, psychological mechanisms and dysfunctions that underlie traumatic response. We will also discuss concepts related to the somatization of trauma. The second section of the course will cover the link between trauma and psychopathology- we will cover the genetics, epigenetics, and behavioral perspectives underlying this link and discuss how trauma affects behavior at an individual and collective level. We will further explore collective and intergenerational trauma perspectives. The third and final section of the course will focus on interventions and trauma-informed care, strengths and weaknesses, pitfalls and planning of future interventions. The instructor will use a flipped classroom in half the classes, where students will present papers, and the instructor will serve as a mediator. We will assume an intersectional lens when we analyze specific examples. The instructor will pick case studies from South Asian and Indian contexts in particular for students to appreciate how cross-cultural differences in norms and attitudes can have long-lasting effects on how trauma is experienced, addressed and processed.

Learning Outcomes

Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to 

  • Understand the universality of trauma and demonstrate the ability to recognize the epidemiology of traumatic exposure and outcomes, specifically:
    • a. Prevalence, incidence, risk and resilience factors, and trajectories.
    • b. Subpopulations (e.g., children, adolescents, young and middle-aged adults, older adults; men, women; veterans, civilians) and settings (e.g., primary care, general or specialized mental health, forensic, juvenile justice).  
  • Develop an enhanced understanding of the nature, etiology, assessment, and treatment of the spectrum of traumatic stress responses, including those reflected in DSM-5 and ICD-11.
  • Demonstrate basic knowledge of findings, mechanisms, models, and interactions among social, psychological, neurobiological factors (e.g., relational, developmental, cognitive and affective, economic, genetic/epigenetic, health and health behaviors). 
  • Learn to view trauma within a social-ecological framework
  • Develop a comprehensive perspective and sensitivity to the etiology of trauma in various presentations of trauma-related symptoms and narratives
  • Develop an intersectional lens of how social identities influence the development of trauma and resilience as well as informed by a strong base of the neurobiology  and somatic understanding of trauma
  • Demonstrate understanding of the social, historical, and cultural context in which trauma is experienced and researched. 
  • Learn about current theoretical approaches to interventions and unaddressed areas of the field
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will pick several readings from the two books listed below, however, we will also read several other journal articles, cross over articles from online publications such as Aeon, Psyche, Behavioral Scientist etc. as well as reviews and scholarly book chapters. A full reading list will be shared at the beginning of the course.

  • Van der Kolk, B. (2014). The body keeps the score: Brain, mind, and body in the healing of trauma. Penguin Books, NY. Access Link.
  • Hermann, J. L. (1992). Trauma and recovery: The aftermath of violence - from domestic abuse to political terror. BasicBooks, NY. Access Link.

Biology Research Thesis II [BIO-CP-4998] [BIO-CP-4998-12]

Faculty Name
Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ];
Overview

An undergraduate capstone thesis in biology is a year-long research project focused on an original question. Under faculty supervision, students design and conduct their research. The goal is to demonstrate the ability to formulate testable hypotheses, gather and analyze data, and interpret results within the context of existing scientific literature.

The written thesis typically follows the structure of a scientific paper. It includes an introduction and literature review for background and rationale, a methods section describing the study design, a results section presenting the data, and a discussion interpreting the findings, addressing limitations, and suggesting future research directions.

Learning Outcomes

Upon completion of the capstone thesis, students will demonstrate the ability to formulate a focused biological research question grounded in current scientific literature; design and implement a rigorous study using appropriate experimental, field-based, or computational methodologies; collect, manage, and analyze data using suitable quantitative or qualitative tools; interpret results within a biological context while acknowledging study limitations and proposing future research directions; communicate research findings effectively in written form according to the conventions of scientific writing; present and defend their research orally; exhibit scientific integrity and adhere to ethical standards throughout all stages of the research process; and manage a substantial, independent project from proposal to final thesis.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading list and other materials will be shared weekly with the students.

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Grading
Grading Components
ComponentDescriptionWeightage
Short Assessments / Applied Work (Quizzes, In-class Writings, Presentations, Group Work, Viva or Lab Reports)Presentation: 15 minutes presentation and 5 minutes Q&A. All the attending faculty members will evaluate the presentations.40
Final Assessment (Final Exam, Term Paper, Final Lab Report or Project)Thesis: The thesis format will be the same as for a typical research paper, including an Abstract, Introduction, Materials, and Methods, Results, Discussion, and Conclusion. It should not be more than 4000 words, excluding references. The write-up will be evaluated by the supervisor and another faculty member nominated by the Head of the Department (from the previous semester) The examiners will grade the write-up out of 30 and send the marks to the coordinator within 60

courseTitle: To be Continued: Serial Narratives on Paper and Screen
description:
To be Continued: Serial Narratives on Paper and Screen [CT-2424] [CT-2424-1]

Faculty Name
Antony Arul Valan [antony.valan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Serial narratives have been voraciously consumed for the past two centuries: we have always been readers watching out for the next episode, holding within us the discomfort of not knowing what is going to happen in the next episode/instalment, savouring the small plates we’ve received, running various interpolations and plot progressions within our minds all the while waiting to be challenged, assuaged or gratified. In this course we will focus on two specific forms of the serial narrative through just two literary works: the serialised novel (Harriet Beecher Stowe’s Uncle Tom’s Cabin) and the web series (Shogun, 1980 and 2024). We will read and watch these narratives episodically throughout the semester along with contemporary reader/viewer responses in the form of letters to the editors and YouTube reviews, and supplement our discussions of anticipation and narrative movement with scholarship from the burgeoning field of critical serial studies (e.g. Frank Kelleter, Jennifer Hayward and Ryan Engley). Students can choose to work on academic papers or write a serial narrative for their assignments in addition to maintaining a reading/viewing journal. 

Learning Outcomes

description:
Mockingly Yours: Eighteenth-Century Satire [ENG-3366] [ENG-3366-1]

Faculty Name
Antony Arul Valan [antony.valan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The eighteenth century witnessed a global profusion of literary works that ridiculed social conventions, human vices and structures of power. In this critical thinking course, we will delve into texts across linguistic traditions—English, French, Arabic, Sanskrit, German, Japanese and Tamil—and study how they stage incisive and biting critique of their respective societies. Spanning several forms—the novel, mock epic, poetry, fable, drama, graphics—the course will train students to closely read for the various techniques these satirists handle to elicit laughter and seriously provoke. We will read works by canonical satirists including Jonathan Swift, Voltaire and Alexander Pope, and non-canonical writers such as Mary Leapor, mdn al-Shwir and Vancesvara Diksita. Students can choose to write academic papers or playful satirical pieces for their assignments.

description:
Welfare, Inequality and Poverty [ECO-3655/ ECO-4655] [ECO-3655/ ECO-4655-1]

Faculty Name
Bhaskar Dutta [bhaskar.dutta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course is based on the premise that our concern with an equitable income distribution stems from the goal of maximizing social welfare.  The first part of the course will focus  on how to derive  measures of (income) inequality and (income) poverty from social welfare functions. Subsequent lectures will discuss more recent literature on measures of multidimensional poverty. While much of the course will be on conceptual issues, the course will also discuss patterns of change in income distribution in India, intercountry comparisons of inequality and poverty,  globalization and inequality, as well as some policy issues. 

Learning Outcomes

Familiarity with the literature. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The background reading for the course is :

Amartya Sen   : On Economic Inequality (latest edition)

Martin Ravallion : The Economics of Poverty :History, Measurement and Policy

Additional readings will be distributed later on.

courseTitle: Texture, Taste, and Storytelling: Reading Gender, Sexuality, and the Self in Multivalent Narratives
description:
Texture, Taste, and Storytelling: Reading Gender, Sexuality, and the Self in Multivalent Narratives [CT-2363] [CT-2363-1]

Faculty Name
Hannah Meher E V [hannah.ev_phd22@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How can we read and articulate what lies beyond the written or conventional, like what is felt through taste, touch, and listening? Can we understand, experience, and articulate gender and sexuality through the flavours of chocolate with a hint of spice, a traditional home-made meal, or the ritual of casting a fishing net into the sea? What can we learn by not remaining bound to what is considered 'valuable' or the 'right' kind of knowledge or text, and what can different ways of telling stories, or constructing them visually or narratively, tell us about the construction of the self? Can a film on a young man’s life-long association of himself with a colour, or an essay on popular romance texts or cookbooks give us different lenses with which to approach gender and sexuality? ln this course, we will explore the multivalent ways in which we can read gender, sexuality, the self, and affect beyond only the written word, and with various modalities or narratives of historical romance, poetry, films, online series, which traverse oceans and borders, encompassing food culture, time, class-caste dynamics etc. instead. We will also engage with the work of scholars including Diana Taylor, Erving Goffman, Arjun Appadurai, Chandra Talpade Mohanty, Sara Ahmed, Stuart Hall, and Judith Butler. We will be watching movies like The Great Indian Kitchen, Moonlight, and Kumbalangi Nights, and reading novels and graphic novels including Like Water for Chocolate and Persepolis to explore variant ways of approaching storytelling and the self, and of seeing, experiencing, and articulating the complex intersections of gender, sexuality, caste, language, consumption, etc.

Learning Outcomes

1. Students will learn to analyse how gender, sexuality and the self are articulated or expressed in texts from different cultural contexts and in varied forms.

2. Through classroom discussions, short writing exercises, and written responses, the students will learn to think about and articulate how gender, the self, and sexuality are moulded, experienced, and expressed through sensorial experience, music, or oral narratives etc., and how they are woven into storytelling.

3. The students will also think about the importance of storytelling and narratives other than only the written and official historical records to different cultures, and the possibilities offered by different ways of understanding, experiencing and portraying cultural experiences.

description:
Reading Marx's Capital [ENG-4376] [ENG-4376-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Karl Marx’s Capital is a strange piece of writing. It blends economic analysis, philosophy, history, and the literary, a book in which pages devoted to abstract formulae will suddenly give way to vampires, werewolves, and dancing tables. Capital is no mere polemic against the evils of capitalist production; instead Marx takes the very premises of liberal economics as his own to demonstrate on the classical economists' own terms how, far from being a rational system for the distribution of resources and the creation of wealth, the production of surplus value causes (and often depends on) cycles of crisis, concentrates power and capital in the hands of a shrinking few, all while immiserating ever greater numbers of others as they fall into the proletarian class. The argument is powered by a form of dialectical critique (Kritik), a self-reflexive style of thought that is not simply about exposing the problems of its object, but also bends back on the thinker themselves, illuminating the extent to which thinking itself is circumscribed by contingency. Much of our work in this class will be devoted to seeing how such thinking operates, and how it might help us in our own thinking and writing, regardless of how we might feel about Marx’s own arguments from our contemporary vantage point. The core of this class, then, will follow the spirit of Marx’s dialectical critique through a close reading of Capital Vol. I, exploring the work in its historical specificity while also considering both its explanatory power and ways in which its ideas might need to be repurposed and revised if we are to account for the realities of contemporary neoliberalism.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Marx, Karl. Capital, Vol. I. Trans. Paul Reitter (Princeton: Princeton UP). ISBN: 0691190070

description:
Prejudice, Pride and Bigotry [ENG-3901] [ENG-3901-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In The Souls of Black Folk, published first in 1903, William Edward Burghardt Du Bois, asks a question so powerful that we are yet to entirely understand its immense profundity: “How does it feel to be a problem?” In the posing of such a seemingly prosaic question, Du Bois radically alters the ways in which we apprehend the “systemic” machinations of “power,” by framing them in uncompromisingly experiential terms. In this course, we will be endeavoring to work with such a framing in understanding the fundamentals of a field of inquiry often referred to as Critical Race Theory. While this course will focus largely on critically examining race, race consciousness and racism in literary and cultural texts across Europe and the United States, it will also look at race at the intersections of and in counterpoints with other marginalities such as gender and gender identity, class, caste, sexuality, and nationality. We will be attempting to map the contours of a wider landscape of bigotry, and in doing so reflect upon the insights that such a cartography can offer regarding the “systemic” forces that shape our own experiential locus and locations.

Philosophy of Logic [PHI-3060] [PHI-3060-1]

Overview

Philosophical Logic, Meaning, and Truth

This course will bring under scrutiny the core elements of philosophical thought itself. What is so special about logic that it can be used to judge our thinking? What sort of thing is the meaning of a word, or of a sentence? We may think we use logic and language to find the truth, but what is it for something to be true? We will start by considering a debate in 10th century Baghdad on the merits of Aristotelian logic followed by a look at the development of Indian logic. With that foundation, we will work through some of the big ideas of the 19th and 20th centuries.

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course, students will have reflected on

  • philosophical implications of developments in the global history of logic,
  • the connections between logic and the philosophy of language,
  • and influential theories in the philosophies of logic, meaning, and truth.

In each case, students will be able to identify, evaluate, and produce arguments connected to the relevant philosophical literature.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Exam: There will be a two-hour exam in which you must produce two short essays. You will choose two (from a selection of about eight) questions and give a critical, reasoned response to each one. The topics appearing in the exam questions (but not the questions’ exact content and wording) will be made known to you before teaching is concluded.

The exam will be handwritten. Exceptions can be made for those with accessibility concerns.

Essay: You will be required to write an essay of around at least 2000 words in response to a prompt that will be given at the beginning of the course.

Student-led sessions: Once per week, a student or students will present on a selection from one of the suggested readings. There are no strict rules about these presentations except that they should explain the content of the selection and give the presenters’ reflections on it. The point is less to have a polished piece of work and more to give students the opportunity to lead the discussion of some literature. Slides or handouts are not required or expected, but would be welcome. This presentation will influence your participation grade.

Reading List

The following is a suggested reading list segmented by topic (not week). The only required readings are the student-led session (SLS) sections (indicated below). No reading is required for the first week.

You are expected to explore the other readings (and/or any other appropriate scholarly literature you find) on your own, at your own pace. Evidence of that exploration should appear in your essay and exam.

The al-Srf – Matt debate

Abed, Shukri. "Language." In History of Islamic Philosophy, edited by Seyyed Hossein Nasr, & Oliver Leaman, 898-925. London: Routledge, 1996.

Mahdi, Muhsin. "Language and Logic in Classical Islam." In The Early Islamic Grammatical Tradition, edited by Ramzi Baalbaki, 135-167. Burlington: Ashgate, 2007.

Vaccines: Science, Myths, and Economics [BIO-3219] [BIO-3219-1]

Faculty Name
Rama Sundari Akondy [rama.akondy@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course provides an interdisciplinary exploration of vaccines through the lenses of immunology, social perceptions, and economics. Students will study key vaccines in depth—Smallpox, HPV, MMR, and COVID-19—to understand their scientific basis, the myths and misinformation that shape public attitudes, and the economic challenges influencing vaccine access and distribution worldwide. Through case studies, critical discussions, and applied assignments, students will develop foundational skills to analyze and communicate vaccine-related issues in global and local contexts. This course is ideal for students interested in public health, science communication, health policy, or biomedical research. It is also suited for anyone curious about how science, society, and policy intersect in real-world health decisions.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Describe the biological principles underlying vaccine development and immune protection.
  2. Critically evaluate common myths and misinformation surrounding vaccines and their impact on public health.
  3. Analyze the economic challenges affecting vaccine access and distribution.
  4. Compare and contrast the development, challenges, and impact of different vaccines including Smallpox, HPV, MMR, and COVID-19.
  5. Design evidence-based strategies for public health communication to address vaccine hesitancy and improve vaccine uptake.
  6. Develop foundational skills to analyze and communicate vaccine-related issues in global and local contexts.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

  • Basic understanding of biology (equivalent to introductory undergraduate biology).
  • No prior specialized knowledge in immunology or economics is required; relevant concepts will be introduced during the course.
  • Willingness to engage with interdisciplinary perspectives and critical thinking assignments.

The reading list will be provided by december 15th.

Multimedia Journalism [MS-2014] [MS-2014-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This 13-week Multimedia Journalism course offers a comprehensive overview of core concepts, practical skills, and ethical considerations in modern news production across multiple formats. Students begin by exploring convergence journalism and its impact on newsrooms and audiences, followed by critical examination of news values, bias, ethics, and source reliability.
The syllabus includes hands-on practice in writing for broadcast, mobile and video reporting, photojournalism, video editing, and social media storytelling, with various fieldwork opportunities.

 

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn to analyze, pitch, script, edit, and present multimedia stories, culminating in a final project featuring an edited multimedia news feature and live reporting.

courseTitle: The world of the Indian New Wave
description:
The world of the Indian New Wave [MS-3821] [MS-3821-1]

Faculty Name
Aakshi Magazine [aakshi.magazine@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

 

The Indian new wave or Parallel Cinema movement, which began in 1969 and lasted till the end of the 1980s, combined artistic experimentation with a desire to challenge power structures and transform Indian society. According to Chidananda Das Gupta, it was a movement with a "social conscience". This can be seen in the work of New wave filmmakers like Mrinal Sen, Saeed Mirza, Shyam Benegal among others. This course is interested in exploring the legacy of cinema interested in social transformation. We will watch a range of films across different time periods and languages, going beyond the New Wave, which offer an alternative and radical perspective on caste, nationalism and gender. And which experiment with film form while doing so. Through these films, we will think closely about the great possibility and challenge of cinema interested in societal change and transformation. 
 

Learning Outcomes

Craft of Creative- Nonfiction [CW-2045] [CW-2045-1]

Faculty Name
Janice Erica Pariat [janice.pariat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course invites students to explore the vibrant and elastic form of creative non-fiction — a space where fact meets imagination, and memory, observation, and reflection intertwine. Through reading, discussion, and practice, we will examine how writers transform lived experience into artful narrative. Students will engage with a range of subgenres — personal essay, travel writing, memoir, literary journalism, and nature or place-based writing — while developing their own distinctive voices. We will study key techniques of the craft: scene-making, structure, narrative voice, pacing, research as texture, and the ethics of representing real people and events. Emphasis will be placed on the relationship between form and subject — how language, tone, and perspective shape truth on the page. Alongside close readings of established and contemporary writers, students will produce their own work through prompt exercises and writing for workshops. By the end of the semester, students will have developed a portfolio of original creative non-fiction, deepened their understanding of the genre’s possibilities, and honed the critical vocabulary needed to discuss both their own work and that of others. The course is designed for those who already have some experience in creative writing and wish to move toward more nuanced, risk-taking, and reflective practice. To register for this course, students must have successfully completed Introduction to Creative Writing.

Learning Outcomes
  • Identify and apply key techniques of creative nonfiction—including scene, structure, voice, pacing, and research—to craft vivid, engaging narratives from lived experience.
  • Compose original works across a range of subgenres, such as personal essay, memoir, travel writing, place-based writing, or literary journalism, demonstrating an emerging and distinctive narrative voice.
  • Use observation, memory, and research to enrich nonfiction writing with sensory detail, context, and reflective insight.
  • Revise drafts thoughtfully, incorporating peer and instructor feedback to develop more intentional, coherent, and artfully shaped pieces.
  • Engage ethically and responsibly with real people, events, and places in their writing, demonstrating an understanding of the complexities of truth-telling, representation, and perspective.
  • Participate actively in workshop discussions, offering constructive critique and employing appropriate critical vocabulary to analyse both their own work and that of others.

courseTitle: Symmetry and Group Theory in Physics
description:
Symmetry and Group Theory in Physics [PHY-4151/ PHY-6151/ MAT-3212] [PHY-4151/ PHY-6151/ MAT-3212-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ,Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This graduate level course will focus on the physics of symmetry using the mathematics of group theory and representation theory. Symmetry is a fundamental
concept throughout physics, be it particle physics and field theory, condensed matter physics, cosmology, quantum mechanics/quantum information or atomic and
molecular physics.


The basic concepts of geometrical symmetry, finite groups and their representations will be covered. A physics oriented introduction will be given to Lie algebras and Lie
groups and their (unitary) representations. The emphasis throughout will be on the particular rather than the general. Familiar concepts from quantum mechanics will
be used repeatedly - for example, the hydrogen atom spectrum and its symmetries will arise repeatedly during the study of Lie groups. Instead of developing the
general theory of semi-simple compact Lie groups, the important concepts will instead be illustrated through particular examples. For example, the groups SO(2),
SO(3), SU(2), SU(3) etc. as they arise in physics and their unique and distinctive features and representations.

Learning Outcomes

description:
Reading for Writers [CW-1006/ ENG-2006] [CW-1006/ ENG-2006-1]

Faculty Name
Saikat Majumdar [saikat.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How does one capture in English lives that are not lived in English? That is one of the defining challenges for the writer for whom English arrives as a literary language as a legacy of colonialism and globalization in contexts beyond the Anglosphere. In this course, we shall watch the paths taken by others who have grappled with this question, reading a selection of English fiction, poetry, and nonfiction by writers from sub-Saharan Africa, south Asia, the West Indies, and other possible locations on the globe where English co-exists with other indigenous and creolized languages. We will then turn to our own experience and discuss the possibilities before us as writers and translators who work with English as a medium of literature, with the chaos of many tongues around us.

Asian International and Strategic Thought [IR-3042] [IR-3042-1]

Faculty Name
Kanti Prasad Bajpai [kanti.bajpai@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is about Asian international and strategic thought, specifically the international and strategic thought of China, India, Japan, Indonesia, and Singapore. It asks: how have these five key societies thought about international order and national security? The objective here is to identify key values, principles, concepts, line of argument, and practices and to compare these to each other and to Western thought. What is the range of thinking in Asia? How has Asian thought changed over time?

At the heart of International Thought is the question of order. Is order based on the threat and use of force, the existence of rules and institutions, or deeper acknowledgment of a common humanity? Should order be primarily between countries or should order transcend national boundaries and apply to all human beings? How should global public goods be dealt with?

At the heart of Strategic Thought is the question of how states can use their national resources – military, diplomatic, economic, cultural – to enhance their security from external and internal threats.

How have Asians thought about these issues? How does Asian thought compare to various streams of Western thought? What are the similarities and differences between various Asian currents? How does Asian thinking influence their policies? These are the questions that will be central to the classes and assignments.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

This course is aimed to help students:

Get an overview of the main streams of international and strategic thought in China, India, Japan, Indonesia, and Singapore by reading leading thinkers and important secondary interpretations.

Develop a comprehension of the range of thinking and why it is important for the policies of these countries.

Understand key thinkers and conceptualizations.

Think critically and analytically about Asian thought.

Assess if and how Asian thought gives us insights into international life and strategy and what the similarities and differences may be between the five traditions as well as between Asia and the West

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The readings will be journal articles and book chapters. No text book. As far as possible, we will read authors from the societies we are studying rather than Westerners or others based in the Western academy writing about China, India, Japan, Indonesia, and Singapore. Readings will be about 70-100 pages a week. I am in the process of finalizing the readings.

Reading Rumis Masnawi [HIS-3003] [HIS-3003-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Jall al-Dn Muammad popularly known as Rumi was a 13th-century poet, jurist, theologian and Sufi mystic. His Masnavi (a poetic form) is a series of six poetic sections that together amount to around 25,000 couplets. The Masnavi is one of the most influential works of Sufism. It has been viewed by many commentators as the greatest mystical poem in world literature. It is a spiritual text that teaches the disciple how to reach their goal of being truly in love with the Master. It also explains the various dimensions of spiritual life and practice to Sufi disciples and anyone who wishes to ponder the meaning of life.

During the course, we will closely read sections of the text in its original Persian like the story of Musa-o-Shabaan (Moses and the Shepherd) to unpack the poetic diction and imagination. Basic knowledge of the Persian language is therefore mandatory if you wish to enroll in the course. Discussions will be encouraged and students will be expected to participate in class to share their inferences and observations.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, students will have a richer understanding of key sections of the Masnavi,  ability to closely read classical Persian; hence the pre-modern sources of History, and hopefully, a greater appreciation for Rumi's literary marvel.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-Requisites

Persian I

Waivers may be granted to those who can demonstrate exceptional command over Urdu Poetry or for those who are native speakers of Persian.

The reading materials will be provided in the class.

description:
Ageing, Family and Well-being [SOA-2254] [SOA-2254-1]

Faculty Name
Anindita Chatterjee [anindita.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course conceptualizes the meaning of ageing in cross-cultural contexts. This course will connect ageing with the theme of well-being. It will cover population belonging to several groups – people who opt to remain single, married couples without children, and people who are disabled. The course will study the impact of ageing on different groups of people. The first half of the course will cover the theoretical concept of ageing and what it means to have an improved quality of life through literary foundations and visual sources. The second half of the course will introduce case studies. This course is intended to be inter-disciplinary and cross-cultural in its approach as we will cover topics across a range of disciplines and cultures.

Learning Outcomes

After completing the course, students will,

  1. Identify ageism with collective family-structure, kinship-network, single/divorced, widows and disabled group of people in South Asia.
  2. Apply ways to understand the cross-cultural perspective based on different demographic group.
  3. Infer knowledge through texts and cases of real life voices and media representations, creative writing and, movies
  4. Demonstrate a clear understanding of theories and concepts and their everyday applications through rephrased and concise communication, both oral and written

Pedagogical Techniques used

Intensive reading

Interactive, discussion oriented

Utilization of visual, literary, and media sources

Story-circle (group work)

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

will find from the attached document

(Anthropological theories, print media, multimedia, anthology of short stories and comic books)

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Teaching Approach

The classroom is a collaborative learning space, meaning that everyone is responsible for creating and sustaining an engaging learning experience.  My selection of topics and materials in this syllabus offer one guide for developing knowledge and reflecting on the topics of the course. Your contributions to the knowledge-building process include offering your thoughtful questions and comments about materials. Your comments will contribute to create a participatory forum among your other cohorts. The quality of our interactions depends upon the commitment of each student to prepare readings and assignments thoroughly, engage actively with course materials and attentively with other learners. I believe that it is often better to be constructively curious and engaged than to be always right.

Naquashi, the Master's Way [CVA-0115] [CVA-0115-1]

Overview

This course introduces students the artistic and cultural heritage of Kashmiri Naqashi (papier-mâché), a craft that travelled from Persia to Kashmir in the 14th century. The course offers students an opportunity to explore this living art form through hands-on work.

Students will learn the foundational techniques of Naqashi, including surface preparation, brushwork, pigment mixing, and motif design, while also examining its historical evolution, symbolic vocabulary, and place within the wider traditions of South Asian art. Through practice-based learning, they will gain an appreciation for the precision, patience, and imaginative vision that define the craft.

The course will be taught be an award-winning master artisan; drawing from decades of practice and teaching at institutes and cultural forums, the instructor will guide students in understanding Naqashi both as a material process and as a cultural dialogue that continues to evolve in South Asian arts and crafts.

courseTitle: The Travelling "I"- the Art of Self-Portraiture
description:
The Travelling "I"- the Art of Self-Portraiture [CVA-0116] [CVA-0116-1]

Overview

The Travelling ‘I’ is imagined as a conversation between the creator and the art. It is a dialogue where both are entangled, porous, and inseparable. How does the self in self-portraits freeze or melt the definitive gaze and body of the artist, and of the world that looks back ? How might this encounter turn the gaze outwards, challenging the usually introspective pull of self-portraiture? And what do the mediums of self-making offer us today, in an age when we already live beside our digital twins?
I invite participants to journey with me through questions of becoming.
Together, we will explore the concept of doubleness in painting—echoing the surrealist inventions of Frida Kahlo. We will borrow from Agnes Varda’s art of gleaning, gathering fragments of the self to assemble into a collage, a model, a living machine. Our path will lead us into the tactile realm of second skins—through mask-making, we will celebrate both disguise and revelation.
As we move through these processes, we will listen to what the materials whisper, and keep a process journal—a living map of thoughts, gestures, and transformations that chart our shared passage through the unfolding.

courseTitle: Making Meaning: Photography, Storytelling and the Human Connection
description:
Making Meaning: Photography, Storytelling and the Human Connection [CVA-0117] [CVA-0117-1]

Overview

This course explores photography as both a craft and a language. Beginning with the fundamentals of camera use and digital editing, students gradually move beyond
technique to explore the deeper act of seeing — how awareness, emotion, and
intention shape the images we make. Through guided exercises and critiques,
students learn to use their cameras — whether DSLR, mirrorless, or phone — as
tools for observation, storytelling, and self-expression.

Through the course, students engage with themes such as intimacy, narrative,
documentary practice, and ethics. You will learn to tell personal and meaningful
stories, examine how truth is constructed in photography, and reflect on your
own responsibilities as image-makers. By the end of the program, you will have
developed both technical fluency and a creative vision, learning how images can
connect, question, and reveal meaning.

description:
Explorations in Concept and Art Forms in Engaged Art in the Social Realm [CVA-0118] [CVA-0118-1]

Overview

This course provides an introduction to the fundamentals of contemporary artistic practices, focusing on both the conceptual and practical aspects of  Engaged Art in the social realm. The curriculum explores the history, creative processes, stages, strategies, and ethical considerations related to these art forms. Additionally, the course connects themes from various disciplines, including sociology, history, environmental science, gender and media studies, and urban studies, all within social contexts. Students will also gain hands-on artistic experience that extends beyond traditional studio settings.
The purpose of this project is to provide an opportunity for meaningful engagement with the neighbourhood and community, both within and beyond the university. The goal is to develop a practical outcome that prompts a series of inquiries while creating the body of artwork. The culmination of this process will be an exhibition, performance or another form of public event.

courseTitle: Critical Sound Design and Computational Arts
description:
Critical Sound Design and Computational Arts [CPA-0113] [CPA-0113-1]

Overview

This course explores sound as a critical medium, not just as a tool for composition but as a lens to investigate culture, space, and society. Students will interrogate how sound operates politically, socially, and materially, with exploring experimental approaches such as field recordings of urban environments, sound interventions, noise mapping, and electroacoustic manipulation. Emphasis is on critical listening, questioning assumptions of “pleasant” or “correct” sound, and designing projects that provoke awareness and reflection. Students will also learn some computational tools to create, manipulate and warp sound.

Workshops will include learning some basic open source computational tools like Supercollider, Strudel and Tidal Cycles, Live spatialization, and Conceptual sound scores. Students will also engage with theory from acoustic ecology, sound studies, and media arts. The course culminates in an experimental public sound installation, documenting and reconfiguring urban sonic environments. Students will leave with both creative artifacts and critical frameworks to approach sound as research, art, and intervention.

Objectives

1. To develop critical listening skills and awareness of sound in built and natural environments.
2. To introduce techniques of field recording, editing, and sound design.
3. To explore the relationship between space, architecture, and sonic experience.
4. To create collaborative works that integrate research, sound, and coding.

Rhythms of the World [CPA-0114] [CPA-0114-1]

Overview

This course will take learners on a journey through rhythms from around the world, focusing on sound and percussion. They will explore the rich rhythmic traditions of Africa, Latin America, and Asia, and see how rhythm shapes different musical cultures. From the lively polyrhythms of West Africa that bring people together in dance and storytelling, to the deep drumming traditions of Egypt with their ancient roots, rhythm will be shown as a way of expression and connection. In Indonesia, learners will experience the layered patterns of gamelan music, while in Kyrgyzstan they will discover how percussion and jew harps echo the movements of horses and wide open landscapes. Through listening, hands-on practice, and creative activities, the course will help learners understand how rhythm connects to identity, nature, and community spirit.

courseTitle: Wounded by the Word: The World of Indian Mystics
description:
Wounded by the Word: The World of Indian Mystics [CPA-0116] [CPA-0116-1]

Overview

Step into the world of South Asian mystics through the power of song and communal singing. In this course, we will learn and discuss the verses of mystic saint-poet-musicians, including Kabir, Mira, Akka Mahadevi, Ravidas, Nanak, and Andal. The timeless wisdom of the mystic saints and fakirs from Bhakti and Sufi traditions provides paths to the divine through the medium of song and poetry and the emotive register of love. Many saint-musician-poets came from subordinated caste and class groups and provided heterodox and, in some cases, anti-hierarchical spiritual orientations. These traditions paved a path for an alternate value system through ecstatic song and the possibility of social mobility. What better way to invite these radical saint-singers into our lives than to move and sing with them?

courseTitle: Sensory Awareness in connection with the "use' of the 'self'
description:
Sensory Awareness in connection with the "use' of the 'self' [CPA-0117] [CPA-0117-1]

Overview

Drawing from principles of the Alexander Technique and western somatic practices developed from the mid-twentieth century onwards, this course will help participants to sense, listen and think with their internal and external environment. FM Alexander (1869-1955), who developed the Alexander Technique, took seriously the idea that the whole ‘self’ is a generative and deep subject of inquiry and developed a technique based on a set of principles that would help a person in this process. From the 1950s onwards, a number of teachers developed their own methods of study and practice focused on the body and mind. In this course, we will attempt to understand some of these approaches. Our classes will include a combination of practical work and reading selected texts to encourage an attitude of exploration, inquiry and reflection while approaching concepts like ‘feeling’ and ‘thinking’ in rest and activity. We will aim to consider and develop our individual understanding of the ‘self’ in relation to the demands and needs of the group and shared spaces in everyday life.

description:
Contemporary Dance: Composition and Performance [CPA-0041] [CPA-0041-1]

Overview

Contemporary dance is a form of movement that evolved globally in mid-20th century by building upon and adapting from foundational forms like ballet, jazz, bharathanatyam, chhau. Used for abstract visualization as well as storytelling, the form constantly expands to accommodate practitioners' chosen modes of self expression.

The course will involve practical explorations of sources, techniques, practices and evolving concepts of Contemporary dance in its present form. Making the body available to movement, exploration and performance are the key priorities of this course.

Classes will include:

-strength and mobility exercises for the body
-training in foundational technique from ballet, jazz, hip hop, and some genre defining concepts like release, grounding, contact, floorwork
-task based improvisation
-composition of movement
-introduction to performance techniques

Prior training in any movement practice will help the student but is not a requirement for the course.

Advanced Sanskrit III [SAN-3006] [SAN-3006-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Bruce Watson [alex.watson@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is for those who have taken Intermediate Sanskrit and it will involve reading philosophical Sanskrit.  We will start with the beautifully written masterpiece, Nyyamañjar ("Blossoms of Reasoning"), by Jayanta Bhaa, who was a poet as well as a philosopher.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course you will have a good acquaintance with the various features of philosophical Sanskrit: its terminology, common grammatical structures, ways of putting an argument (such as through a prayoga, "syllogism"), and back-and-forth between prvapakin and siddhntin.  You will have a sense of the philosophical issues that mattered to thinkers in pre-modern India and how they were thought about and argued for.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No advanced preparation is required for this course.  Make sure you turn up at the first class for a discussion of how the course will proceed.

courseTitle: Nader to Nothing. Iran and Turan in the Changing World Order of the 18th Century
description:
Nader to Nothing. Iran and Turan in the Changing World Order of the 18th Century [HIS-3103] [HIS-3103-1]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Amir Hakimi Parsa [mohammad.parsa@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course focuses on the history of Western and Central Asia (centred on Iran and Turan) in the long eighteenth century (c. 1680s–1850s), exploring themes of empire, identity, war and globalisation as the Turco-Persianate world underwent convulsion, resurgence, and was eventually eclipsed by the new colonial empires of Europe. A major component of the course will be devoted to studying Nader Shah’s imperial state and its quest to dominate the Islamic world. This will be followed by an examination of the Naderid successor states of Ahmad Shah (in Afghanistan), the Manghits (in Uzbekistan), and the Zands (in West Iran). The course will end with the Qajar dynasty ruling over a reunified Iran and the Afghans retaining their fragile independence in the First Anglo-Afghan War (1838–1842). The importance of this period in forging Iranian, Afghan, and Uzbek identities will become apparent, as will the changing power relations between Turco-Persianate empires and European colonial empires. The early eighteenth century was defined by the colossal land empires of Asia, such as those of Nader and Ahmad Shah, firmly rooted in Turco-Mongol, Persianate, and Sufi thought. In contrast, the turn of the century saw these former great powers desperately emulating the rising European colonial empires rooted in Capitalism, Industrialism, and Enlightenment thought. Thus, the transition of the global order and the inversion of power between “East” and “West” in the long eighteenth century is an overarching theme in the course. Consequently, there will also be several digressionary sessions looking at other powers of the period, including the Ottomans, Omanis, and Japanese.

Learning Outcomes

To understand the fundamental transition of global power that occurred in the eighteenth century, especially in Iran and Turan. Many of the oldest and most prestigious dynastic orders of the world, including the Safavids, the Mughals (Timurids), and the Chinggisids, were brought to an end in the long eighteenth century, replaced by new dynastic founders from lowly backgrounds, such as Nader, the son of a shepherd. Students will understand the ideological, cultural, and institutional reasons for this radical transition.

Students will also understand how this period saw the shaping and re-shaping of important identities that remain part of our contemporary world, including Iranian, Afghan, and Uzbek identities. Students will appreciate that the construction of these identities was influenced by Turco-Persianate imperial culture and ideas on genealogy and lineage (prior to the encounter with the European idea of race).

Students will also gain a nuanced appreciation for how the European presence in these regions fundamentally changed, going from supplicating traders to superior conquerors. The course provides a historiographically critical reading of this sudden and lasting transition in the global order, and students will reflect on the imagined and real causes behind this reordering of the world.   

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

M. A. H. Parsa, Imperial Iran in the Eighteenth Century: Identity and State Formation under Nader (Edinburgh University Press, 2026)

Thomas Barfield, Afghanistan: A Cultural and Political History, 2nd edition (Princeton University Press, 2023)

J. C. Sharman, Empires of the Weak: The Real Story of European Expansion and the Creation of the New World Order, (Princeton University Press, 2019)

courseTitle: People, Power, and Popular Sovereignty: A World History
description:
People, Power, and Popular Sovereignty: A World History [HIS-3850] [HIS-3850-1]

Faculty Name
Mohammad Amir Hakimi Parsa [mohammad.parsa@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course provides a critical look at how political communities around the world have conceptualised and implemented popular sovereignty – the notion that it is the people who ultimately hold the legitimate claim to political power. The Eurocentric historiography of this idea will be examined critically, exploring how and why scholars have traditionally sought its origins in the West. Popular sovereignty is commonly assumed to have only been adopted and adapted by non-Western cultures in their unequal encounter with Western colonial empires. In contrast, this course demonstrates that the different notions of popular sovereignty were developed in different political cultures around the world, derived from very different intellectual genealogies and philosophical traditions. The course does not ignore the “West”, of course, and still includes discussions on Athenian democracy and the Roman Republic, as well as the most commonly touted beacons of popular sovereignty in the early modern period: Britain, France, and the United States of America. However, there will be a very detailed look at early modern political cultures beyond these, most prominently Iran, Mughal India, the Ottomans, and the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. The different intellectual and cultural foundations for popular sovereignty will be carefully studied and juxtaposed across these examples from across the world. The course will then culminate in the contemporary era, with popular sovereignty taken as a near-universally accepted principle of politics around the world, including even the most dictatorial governments, such as the "Democratic People's Republic of Korea". Why has this idea come to dominate world politics, and how does it differ conceptually and practically across nations?

This is a Level 4000 course, and primarily targeted at students in the History, International Relations, and Sociology departments.

Learning Outcomes

To understand the Eurocentric paradigm that has dominated the scholarly discourse on the origins and spread of the idea of popular sovereignty.

To gain an appreciation of how popular sovereignty is not a new or modern idea, despite its overwhelming presence in the contemporary world.

To understand that the idea of popular sovereignty in most early modern European nations was firmly rooted in the Greco-Roman Republican tradition and Enlightenment thought. More importantly, to identify how other early modern political cultures outside the West formulated very different articulations of popular sovereignty; Instead of Greco-Roman and Enlightenment thought, these other political cultures rooted their ideas of popular sovereignty in intellectual and cultural traditions such as Islamic jurisprudence, Sufism, nomadic confederalism, and Turco-Persianate notions of imperial community.

To understand how and why the idea of popular sovereignty has come to be a dominant principle in the politics of the modern world, from East to West. To understand how it is used as a tool for political legitimation, and how it takes many different forms, in service of different ideologies and institutions.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reinhard Bendix, Kings or People: Power and the Mandate to Rule, (University of California Press, 1978)

Viatcheslav Morozov (ed.), Decentring the West: The Idea of Democracy and the Struggle for Hegemony, (Routledge, 2013)

courseTitle: Imagined Worlds, Lived Realities: Anthropology of Literature
description:
Imagined Worlds, Lived Realities: Anthropology of Literature [SOA-3164/ ENG-2164] [SOA-3164/ ENG-2164-1]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Description

This course investigates literature as a mode of cultural practice—an arena where imagination, social experience, and systems of meaning converge. It treats literature not only as an artistic form but as a site of ethnographic knowledge: a space where societies represent themselves and others, and where narrative becomes a way of knowing, remembering, and contesting the world. We will trace the shared genealogies of anthropology and literary studies—from the ethnographic realism of Malinowski and the structuralism of Lévi-Strauss to the interpretive and reflexive turns inaugurated by Clifford, Geertz, and Said. Throughout, we will explore how the act of reading can become ethnographic: how attention to form, metaphor, and voice illuminates the lived textures of social life. Conversely, we ask how ethnographic writing borrows from the literary—its tropes, genres, and moral dilemmas of representation. What happens when the ethnographer becomes a storyteller and the novelist an ethnographer? How do texts construct “others,” produce authority, or negotiate the ethics of speaking for and about others?

The course will culminate in a final project that brings together ethnographic sensitivity and literary interpretation, inviting students to inhabit the borderlands between narrative, theory, and culture.

description:
Ethnographic Film [MS-3059/ SOA-3167] [MS-3059/ SOA-3167-1]

Faculty Name
Chitralekha Dhamija [chitralekha@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Anthropology has used filmmaking since the onset of cinema, and filmmaking in anthropology has significantly evolved with advances in technology. But what do anthropological ways of seeing bring to practices of filmmaking? Does the anthropological film in fact have a better chance to portray other people’s ways of life more `truthfully’? What relationships do anthropology’s struggles with questions of representation, reflexivity and subjectivity have with its modes of doing film? What makes a film `ethnographic’? 

This course will address questions such as these as it engages with particularities (and dilemmas) of visual anthropology and its product: the ethnographic film. It will introduce students to methodological and epistemological challenges in the domain as well as engender understanding of the task of studying (and making) moving images with the tools of anthropology. Students will watch classic ethnographic films which helped to shape and redescribe the discipline. Through the discussions that follow, we will consider the filmmaker’s perspective, their modes of representation of their subjects, and the technical, epistemic and ethical challenges involved. Students will work on a collective ethnographic film project that will involve substantial field and lab work.

Learning Outcomes

We will acquire an understanding of anthropology’s complicated relationship with the camera, traversing originary entanglements with colonialism, to critical historical shifts and more recent disciplinary reconjurings. Students will be familiarized with contemporary directions (and debates) of visual ethnography and their intersections with (and digressions from) traditional ethnographic methods. 

We will watch a diverse range of classic ethnographic films as well as acquire an appreciation of ethnographic film practices in the subcontinent, with particular attention to India.

Through this process, students will research, initiate, and complete an ethnographic film of their own.

Philosophy and the Arts [PHI-2873/ MS-2019] [PHI-2873/ MS-2019-1]

Faculty Name
Aditi Chaturvedi [aditi.chaturvedi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Philosophy and Film 
How do we think, experience, and understand reality with films? This is the fundamental question that will propel us this semester. Guided by philosophers such as Stanley Cavell, Robert Pippin, George Wilson, Paisley Livingston, and Noël Carroll as well as by film theorists such as André Bazin, Siegfried Kracauer, Christian Metz, Francesco Casetti, and David Bordwell. we will explore how films pose and sometimes answer philosophical questions about seeing, knowing, and acting. Our approach will be neither “philosophy of  film” (which applies philosophical frameworks to films) nor philosophy through film (where a film is used to illustrate some philosophical notion — e.g. free will through Gattaca). We will, instead, see how film’s formal possibilities, i.e. its ways of showing and concealing, framing and cutting, aligning or withholding a point of view, open up questions that are at once epistemological, ethical, and aesthetic. This will involve exploring questions such as: What is the difference between an objective and a subjective camera shot? Is it possible to construct a fictional narrative movie world entirely out of subjective camera shots? What distinctive about documentary films? What is a cinematic point of view? We will also tackle some questions that are fundamental both to aesthetics and to film theory: What does it mean to say that a painting or a film is “realistic”? What difference does it make, if any, that film has a photographic basis? Can film ever be a transparent medium? What does film inherit, and what does it transform, from older representational arts such as painting and theatre? Each week, we will watch three to four films (with one required screening per week) and other readings will include short selections in film theory and philosophy. Assignments will emphasize sustained attention to the experience of watching and interpreting film: weekly viewing notes, two short close-analysis essays, and a final paper.

Learning Outcomes

Computational/Mathematical Biology [BIO-3513/ BIO-4313/ BIO-6513/ PHY-3513/ PHY-6313] [BIO-3513/ BIO-4313/ BIO-6513/ PHY-3513/ PHY-6313-1]

Faculty Name
Sudipta Tung [sudipta.tung@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In the present century, exceptional advancements in computational power and numerical optimization routines have made quantitative methods critically important for solving biological problems. This course lays a basic foundation of model thinking and provides exposure to quantitative treatments of various biological processes.

During this course, the students will actively participate in learning several key quantitative biology techniques, including ODEs, cellular automata, phase plane analysis, stability analysis, steady-state analysis, quantifying chaos and population stability, through active participation in the class. Upon completion, the students will appreciate the rationale, principles and methodology of constructing and analysing models in various fields of biology, inter alia, population dynamics, microbiology, enzyme kinetic, epidemiology, and evolution.

The primary focus of this course will be on graphical interpretations and hands-on training sessions. The amount of mathematics involved will be minimal. Basic knowledge of coding in any computational programming language will be helpful for this course.

Learning Outcomes

Quantitative thinking and modelling intuition in Biology

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There are no prescribed text books for this course. Suitable reading materials will be shared after the lectures. Interested students may to go through the following books for additional reading.

Murray, J.D., 2007. Mathematical biology: I. An introduction (Vol. 17). Springer Science & Business Media.

Otto, S.P. and Day, T., 2011. A biologist's guide to mathematical modeling in ecology and evolution. Princeton University Press.

Strogatz, S.H., 2018. Nonlinear dynamics and chaos with student solutions manual: With applications to physics, biology, chemistry, and engineering. CRC press.

Railsback, S.F. and Grimm, V., 2019. Agent-based and individual-based modeling: a practical introduction. Princeton university press.

Frankfurt School and Critical Theory [POL-3060/ SOA-3168] [POL-3060/ SOA-3168-1]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

With the rise of Nazism, Stalinism, and monopoly capitalism during the interwar period in Europe, a group of intellectuals came together to examine and diagnose some of challenges that came with this modernity — rise of bureaucracy, mass politics, capitalism, culture industry and the increasing obsession with astrology. While this group of scholars were influenced by Hegel, Marx, Weber, Freud, among others, their analysis moved beyond traditional approaches in political and social theory.

Focusing on the transformative and revolutionary potential of theory, the writings of Max Horkheimer, Walter Benjamin, Theodor Adorno, Herbert Marcuse, Jurgen Habermas—as critical theory—has influenced disciplines as varied as political science, sociology, gender studies, film and cultural studies, comparative literature among others.

Apart from reading the texts written by this first generation of Frankfurt School intellectuals, in the course we will simultaneously study the responses to the development of their thought, particularly their migration to the United States, and their impact on the New Left. 

Learning Outcomes

- Understanding critical theory

- Building analytical and writing skills

- Learning how to frame a good question

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Lectures: Students are expected to attend all lectures and to have completed the reading assigned for that day before class. Students are expected to be able to participate in colloquies conducted by the professor.

Readings: All the mandatory readings would be made available to the students electronically at least a week before the lectures on the said topic. Note: you are encouraged to read the text entirely, but the essential pages will be marked in the syllabus.

More than 5 absences will lead to a straight F for the course. For any long-term medical assistance and absence (more than three absences in a row), please submit a medical certificate to the OAA.

courseTitle: Modernism Unbound: Queer Aesthetics, Global Temporalities
description:
Modernism Unbound: Queer Aesthetics, Global Temporalities [ENG-4353] [ENG-4353-1]

Faculty Name
Selen Erdogan Evren [selen.evren@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In Modernism at Night, Heather Love argues that queerness is not a supplement to modernism but rather “at the heart of it” -that modernism has always already been queer in its attachments to marginality, indeterminacy, opacity, exile, and non-normative desires. Taking Love’s claim as our point of departure, this seminar approaches modernism as a fundamentally queer formation. We begin with canonical texts by Virginia Woolf, Radclyffe Hall, and E. M. Forster to trace how queer subjectivity is articulated through experiments in narrative form and temporality. We then expand outward, reading modernism as a global constellation rather than a strictly Euro-American movement. Works from the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa allow us to examine modernisms shaped by uneven modernization, aspirations to contemporaneity and feelings of belatedness, colonial histories, multilingual literary fields, and minoritized positions. These texts challenge linear-historical narratives of modernism and illuminate how different cultural contexts produce their own queer aesthetic innovations. Throughout the course, we engage central debates in queer theory, asking how affects such as shame, refusal, envy, opacity, or loneliness structure both queer experience and modernist experimentation. Ultimately, the seminar positions queer modernism as a global, comparative project -one that redefines modernism as a field where alternative worlds, temporalities, and forms of relation become imaginable. Students will leave with the tools to rethink modernism through the lens of global, minor, and antinormative literary practices.

Learning Outcomes
