courseTitle: Doing Digital Humanities: Research Methods, Data, and the Everyday Digital
description:
Doing Digital Humanities: Research Methods, Data, and the Everyday Digital [ENG-3353] [ENG-3353-1]

Faculty Name
Justy Joseph [justy.joseph@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course frames the digital as both a lens for studying the humanities and a humanities object that must itself be studied. We will move along these two paths at once. On one path, we treat texts, images, sound, and space as materials that can be cleaned, mapped, modelled, or visualised with digital tools. We will write small pieces of code not to become programmers, but to understand what happens when language is broken into tokens and patterns. We will follow texts into archives and databases, asking what must be structured to be read at scale. We build maps that reveal spatial patterns and also explore what happens to literature when it becomes electronic, and/or platform bound.

On the other path, we turn the tools back on themselves. The digital may deal in numbers and code, but its consequences are always, human. Every day you leave a trail of digital footprints, searches, swipes, maps, images, and sounds. This course treats those traces as our objects of inquiry. We read algorithms the way we read poems, interfaces the way we read political rhetoric, and datasets the way we read archives - as artefacts shaped by assumptions, omissions, power, and design. We slow down the digital and examine the infrastructures that quietly organise our life starting from metadata standards and preservation systems to ranking algorithms, language models, multilingual frictions and ask what they enable, what they exclude, and how they might be reimagined.

The course moves through the following areas:
Basics of programming (Python) for the humanities; text analysis; archiving and digital preservation; data modelling, metadata, and documentation; visualisation; image analysis; computational analysis of music; GIS and spatial humanities; electronic literature; platform studies; multilingual DH; and AI ethics.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course asks for openness and a willingness to work across methods. Though no prior technical background is expected, readiness to experiment, to make mistakes, and to learn by doing is expected. Much of our collective experiments will be through DH Workshops (collaborative, practical hands-on sessions). Continuous engagement and progress in them will account for 50 percent of the final grade. The remaining 50 percent will be based on a final project, presentation/s and overall class participation.

courseTitle: Labour Urbanization and Migration : Past and Present
description:
Labour Urbanization and Migration : Past and Present [SOA-3165/ POL-3137/ HIS-3817] [SOA-3165/ POL-3137/ HIS-3817-1]

Faculty Name
Anindita Chatterjee [anindita.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will introduce students to the study of labour issues through the lens of tracing the historical roots till the recent developments that have taken place. Drawing from labour history and current labour anthropology, the course seeks to interrogate cross-cultural experiences of development. The objective is to familiarize students with various categories of work and labouring lives associated with work, and the relationship with different developmental paradigms, such as globalization, urbanization and migration.  We will draw upon scholarship from cross-cultural spaces to analyze the intertwined links between material inequality and power asymmetry in society. The readings will be supplemented by lectures and conversations with scholars and policy framers who are engaged with issues of migration, labour rights, and gender justice. The course aims at intensive interaction with a wide range of sources, ranging from policy briefs, NSSO classificatory schemes, and trade union documents. The course will provide an overview of the trajectory of labour, particularly in the current scenario, and locate it within other contexts in the developing world. It will analyze women’s organizations and NGOs who are working towards a collective mobilization for change.

Making of Indian Republic [HIS-2202/ SOA-2247/ MS-2081/ POL-2144] [HIS-2202/ SOA-2247/ MS-2081/ POL-2144-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What does it mean for a citizen to belong to a country which is a young republic but one with claims to an ancient civilization? This course is an invitation for you to explore this question. It requires you to imagine yourself as a flaneur or a flaneuse - a person who leisurely strolls, pauses and observes the history of India from the British Raj's twilight to the early decades of the Indian Republic. The story here may be a familiar one - the second world war, the coming of the independence, partitioning of the British Empire, the making of the Indian constitution and the beginning of planned industrialization, big science, love and intimacy - but it is examined from a different lens. The focus is on the civil society drivers and the lesser-known figures, regional movements, grassroot workers, histories of labour, food, cinema, literature and everyday technology and not just the big political leaders, the state policies, and realpolitik. This course lies at the intersection of history, politics, literature, cinema, and sociology. 

Starting our journey at the Ganga ghats to observe the immersion of Gandhi’s ashes, we will enter the refugee colonies and detention camps to have conversations with women and children living there, make our way through the new borders with your passport and ration cards, encounter sex workers holding up the constitution asking for their rights, watch the farmers and village folks flicker on the TV screen as we purchase new luxuries in the multilingual city bazaar, and listen to the radio belting out Lata Mangeshkar songs as we make our way across India’s post-colonial history. Along the way we will see films, documentaries, posters, advertisements, theater, art, literature, cartoons and encounter peoples and voices that will introduce us to new ways of understanding what it means to be an Indian citizen or a young person living in India today.

Learning Outcomes

1. Understanding what it means to be a citizen or a student in a post-colonial Republic 

2. History is not simply a story of big statesmen and statist realpolitik

courseTitle: Art in Public Space: Concepts and Experiments
description:
Art in Public Space: Concepts and Experiments [CVA-0119] [CVA-0119-1]

Overview

This course begins with a simple premise: art emerges when the world becomes a site of conversation, and when artistic practice responds to and reflects on the structures that shape everyday social life. Students will explore how artistic form can grow from lived experience through experimentation with performance, drawing, installation, video, and game-based approaches.

Balancing research and production, the course emphasises both conceptual clarity and the practical aspects of making, testing, and presenting work within real contexts. Readings, discussions, and studio investigations will support students in understanding how artistic choices are shaped by broader historical, political, and cultural forces.

Students are encouraged to work in the medium that best aligns with their way of thinking—whether participatory action, site-responsive experimentation, performance, or moving image. Alongside developing their projects, they will examine the ethics and dynamics of working in public spaces, including questions of collaboration, visibility, and accountability.

Throughout the semester, students will move fluidly between research, creation, and reflective critique, investigating how art can spark dialogue, create encounters, and invite new forms of engagement. The course culminates in a final project that brings together inquiry and execution, demonstrating how artistic practice can open conversations and re-imagine relationships within shared environments.
